text:
[1896-12-21 00:42:47] At home | I saw that they were discussing inviting Paul for the first time to have dinner at home. I heard Robert say that unfortunately Professor Goedel was currently away on a trip, and she herself had completely cut off contact with Matthew, otherwise these two guests would have interested the outgoing ambassador.
[1896-12-21 00:42:52] At home | I heard James answer that guests of honor such as Professor Gaudier, a distinguished scholar, would greatly enhance the table.
[1896-12-21 00:42:57] At home | I heard that "Matthew, who loved to show off and was desperate for others to know he had made contact with high-ranking officials, was actually a vulgar fake, and de Paul would use the word 'disgusting' to descri be Matthew."
[1896-12-21 01:13:02] Home | I thought I needed to explain Steven's answer to James a bit.
[1896-12-21 01:13:07] Home | I know some people may still remember that Professor Goedal was once quite unremarkable, and that Matthew was both modest and tactful in social situations, always refined and proper.
[1896-12-21 01:13:27] At home | I knew that Matthew, the old friend of Steven's parents, had acquired another new title (and it would not be his last) besides "Little Matthew" and "Matthew of the The Union"—that of John's husband.
[1896-12-21 01:13:47] Home | I know that he had subjected his usual instincts, desires, and wit to the vulgar ambitions of that woman, striving to establish a new status suitable for his companion, a status that both of them shared, and which was greatly below his former standing.
[1896-12-21 01:14:07] At home | I thought that, therefore, Steven felt as if he were a different person.
[1896-12-21 01:14:12] Home | I knew that since he had begun this second life (although he still continued to meet his friends individually; he was unwilling to impose John on them, provided they did not themselves ask to meet her), a life shared with his wife, one that existed among his new acquaintances.
[1896-12-21 01:14:32] Home | I now understand it easily: in order to measure the status of these new friends, that is to say, the pleasure their visits brought to his self-esteem, he used as a standard not the most outstanding figures from his pre-marital social circle, but rather John's former friends.
[1896-12-21 01:14:37] Home | I know that, however, even when people knew he liked associating with vulgar officials and the vases at government balls—women of ill repute.
[1896-12-21 01:14:57] At home | I was surprised that he actually took pleasure in boasting that the wife of a certain office deputy had once visited John.
[1896-12-21 01:15:02] At home | I knew because he had once (and still did) gracefully remained silent in the face of invitations to Twickenham or Buckingham Palace.
[1896-12-21 01:15:22] At home | I thought that perhaps people saw the simplicity of the once dashing Matthew as just a refined form of vanity.
[1896-12-21 01:15:27] At home | I thought that perhaps they considered Steven's old friend Paul, like certain Jews, to be alternately displaying the states his race had continuously undergone, from the most unembarrassed affectation to the most naked brutality, all the way to the most refined politeness.
[1896-12-21 01:15:32] At home | I thought, but the main reason—and this generally applies to human beings—is that the virtues of Stevenes are not always some kind of floating thing that is at the mercy of Stevenes.
[1896-12-21 01:15:37] Home | I thought that in Steven's mind, virtue was closely linked to the actions he believed one should take to practice virtue. Therefore, when another type of activity arose, Steven was at a loss and never even considered that the same virtue could be practiced in this activity as well.
[1896-12-21 01:15:42] Home | I knew that Matthew was extremely attentive to his new acquaintances, eagerly listing their names with great enthusiasm.
[1896-12-21 01:16:02] Home | I thought of this attitude, which was similar to that of great artists who are humble or generous: in their later years, they might try cooking or gardening, taking pride in their favorite dishes or flower beds, and they would only accept praise, not criticism.
[1896-12-21 01:16:07] Home | I thought that, once their own masterpieces were involved, they were willing to listen to criticism; or rather, they could generously give away a famous painting, but would be thoroughly upset if they lost forty sous at a game of dominoes.
[1896-12-21 01:16:12] Home | I knew that when it came to Professor Goald, the Marceaux would have long reunions with him again, much later, at the Palais de Raspail, at Madame Verdurin's.
[1896-12-21 01:16:32] Home | I thought at that moment, regarding him, it was first of all necessary to draw attention to one point.
[1896-12-21 01:16:37] Home | I thought that Matthew's change, strictly speaking, could not have surprised Steven, because when Steven saw Michael's father on the Champs-Élysées, the change had already been completed, though it had not yet been perceived by Steven.
[1896-12-21 01:16:42] Home | I thought about how he hadn't spoken to Steven at that time, so he couldn't have boasted to Steven about his political friends (and even if he had, Steven probably wouldn't have immediately detected his vanity).
[1896-12-21 01:16:47] Home | I thought of how the long-standing preconceptions about a person could make the Stevenes turn a blind eye and deaf ear to him.
[1896-12-21 01:16:52] Home | I knew Robert was the same; for three years, she hadn't noticed the lipstick on her niece's lips, as if it had dissolved into the fluid and vanished completely.
[1896-12-21 01:17:12] Home | I knew that one day, the overpowering lipstick or some other reason caused what is called a supersaturated phenomenon, and then the lipstick that had previously gone unnoticed crystallized.
[1896-12-21 01:17:32] At home | I knew that Robert, suddenly seeing a burst of color, would exclaim it was shameful, just as she had in Sunrise, and almost cut off all contact with her niece.
[1896-12-21 01:17:52] Home | I know the opposite about Professor Goedal; the period when he witnessed Matthew entering the social world had already been very distant, and the passage of time had brought him honor and titles.
[1896-12-21 01:18:12] Home | I thought that, in the first place, a person can lack cultural refinement, can indulge in silly homophonic word games, yet still possess a special talent that no cultural refinement can replace, such as the talent of a great strategist or an outstanding physician.
[1896-12-21 01:18:17] Home | I knew that, in the eyes of his colleagues, Professor Godard was not merely an obscure nobody who had finally become a renowned physician throughout Europe.
[1896-12-21 01:18:37] Home | I knew that the top young doctors had declared— at least for a few years, since standards, once created to meet changing needs, were themselves in constant change—that if they ever fell ill, Professor Godard was the only one they could entrust their lives to.
[1896-12-21 01:18:57] Home | I knew they certainly wanted to associate with certain head physicians who had deeper cultural refinement and stronger artistic sensibilities, discussing Unknown_Nietzsche and Unknown_Wagner with them.
[1896-12-21 01:19:17] Home | I know that Madame Godard receives her husband's colleagues and students, hoping that one day her husband will become the dean of the medical school.
[1896-12-21 01:19:37] Home | I knew that people at the party appreciated the music, but Professor Godard had no interest in listening; instead, he went to the next living room to play cards.
[1896-12-21 01:19:57] Home | I thought of his remarkable eyesight, his swift, profound, and accurate diagnosis, which was truly admirable.
[1896-12-21 01:20:02] Home | I was thinking about the third point, regarding the tone and attitude that Professor Goedal adopts towards people of James's type, and it should be noted:
[1896-12-21 01:20:07] Home | I thought that the essential nature of the Stevenes in the second part of life might be a development or decline, an expansion or weakening of the first essence, but not always. Sometimes it was the opposite nature, a genuine opposite.
[1896-12-22 00:40:02] Home | I knew that during his youth, Professor Goedel's hesitant expression, excessive shyness, and kindness often made him the target of mockery, except in the Verdurin family, who were infatuated with him.
[1896-12-22 00:40:07] Home | I wondered which compassionate friend had advised him to adopt a cold expression, which was easily done given his important position.
[1896-12-22 00:40:12] Home | I knew that at the Verdurins' he would naturally revert to his true self, but elsewhere he would remain cold and distant, often saying nothing at all.
[1896-12-22 00:40:17] Home | I knew that when he was forced to speak, he often took a blunt tone, deliberately making people uncomfortable.
[1896-12-22 00:40:22] Home | I knew he applied this new attitude to his patients, since they had never met him before and therefore could not make comparisons.
[1896-12-22 00:40:27] Home | I thought they would be greatly surprised to learn that Professor Gaudet was not by nature rude.
[1896-12-22 00:40:32] Home | I knew that Professor Goard was making every effort to keep his face expressionless.
[1896-12-22 00:40:37] Home | I knew that when he was on duty at the hospital, he would tell puns that made everyone— from the chief physician to the new interns—laugh heartily, while his facial muscles remained completely still.
[1896-12-22 00:40:42] Home | I knew that because he had shaved off his mustache, his face had completely changed.
[1896-12-22 00:40:47] Home | I know I should finally say something about M. de Paul. Before the war, he had been an ambassador. During the crisis on May 16th, he was still an ambassador.
[1896-12-22 00:40:52] Home | I know that, to the great surprise of many, he later undertook several important missions on behalf of France, even going to Egypt as a debt supervisor, where he demonstrated his extraordinary financial abilities and achieved notable success. These missions were entrusted to him by the radical government.
[1896-12-22 00:40:57] Home | I knew that ordinary reactionaries generally refused to serve in this cabinet, and Paul was even less likely to do so: his background, social connections, and views were enough to make him a suspect in the eyes of the cabinet.
[1896-12-22 00:41:02] Home | I knew, however, that the radical ministers seemed to realize that this appointment could show their openness of mind, their devotion to the highest interests of France, and their difference from ordinary politicians, thereby justifying the "Journal des Débats" labeling them as men of state.
[1896-12-22 00:41:07] Home | I knew that in the end, they would benefit from the prestige of noble family names and the attention generated by the unexpected appointments.
[1896-12-22 00:41:12] Home | I knew they understood that employing Paul was entirely to their advantage, and they had no reason to fear he would betray his political loyalty, because the marquis's background did not arouse their suspicion at all, but rather gave them reassurance.
[1896-12-22 00:41:17] Home | I thought that the republican government had not been wrong in this regard.
[1896-12-22 00:41:22] Home | I know this because certain aristocrats, from childhood on, have considered noble surnames as an intrinsic advantage that never fades (their peers, or those of even higher birth, were well aware of the value of such an advantage).
[1896-12-22 00:41:27] Home | I knew that they were well aware that they didn't have to go to the trouble, as so many bourgeois people did, of expressing opinions (though with no real effect) and cultivating the company of upright gentlemen, since such efforts would add no prestige to them.
[1896-12-22 00:41:32] Home | I know that, on the contrary, they would do everything possible to raise their own status in the eyes of a noble or someone like Samuel, and to achieve this, they had to add things to their family name that they hadn't had before: political influence, literary or artistic reputation, or great wealth.
[1896-12-22 00:41:37] Home | I knew they had no intention of wasting their time on the useless gentry that bourgeois people pursued, and besides, gaining the ineffectual friendship of a country gentleman would not lead to the gratitude of a monarch.
[1896-12-22 00:41:42] Home | I knew that they devoted a great deal of effort to politicians who could help them secure positions at the embassy or run for office (even Freemasons didn't care about that), to renowned artists or scholars who could help them make "breakthroughs" in their own fields, in short, to everyone who would help them gain fame and marry into wealth.
[1896-12-22 00:41:47] Home | I knew that Paul had absorbed, from his long diplomatic experience, that passive, conventional, and conservative spirit, the so-called "government spirit," which is common to all governments, especially to the various embassies under them.
[1896-12-22 00:41:52] Home | I know that the diplomat's profession has made him detest, fear, and despise the methods of the opposition—those somewhat revolutionary, at the very least improper, methods.
[1896-12-22 00:41:57] Home | I thought that only common people and a few ignorant individuals in the social world considered so-called different types to be mere empty talk, but in most cases, the closeness between different types came not from sharing the same views, but from a common spiritual lineage.
[1896-12-22 00:42:02] Home | I knew that men like Léautre were part of the classical faction, yet he applauded Maximilien Dugan or Méslier's eulogies of Unknown_Victor Hugo, but refused to applaud Cladel's eulogy of Boileau.
[1896-12-22 00:42:07] Home | I know that the same nationalism brought Baille to close quarters with his voters—who did not distinguish between him and Mr. George Béry—but it could not bring Baille closer to his colleagues at the French Academy, since although they shared his political views, they were spiritually quite different.
[1896-12-22 00:42:12] Home | I knew that they even disliked him and preferred the opponents, M. Léon Daudet and M. Deschanel; loyal royalists felt close to Léon Daudet and Deschanel, yet distant from Moras and Léon Daudet, although these two men also wished for the restoration of the monarchy.
[1896-12-22 00:42:17] Home | I knew Paul was taciturn, not only because of his cautious and prudent professional habits, but also because, in the eyes of such people, words carried greater value and deeper meaning.
[1896-12-22 00:42:22] Home | I knew that their decade-long efforts to bring the two countries closer had, in their speeches and agreements, been reduced to nothing more than a simple adjective, which seemed trivial but to them represented an entire world.
[1896-12-22 00:42:27] Home | I knew that Paul, who was known in the committee for his icy demeanor, was sitting next to James during the meeting, so people began to congratulate James on having won the favor of this former ambassador.
[1896-12-22 00:42:32] Home | I thought James himself was also surprised, because he was not an easygoing man; apart from a small circle of close friends, he had few contacts with others, and he himself did not hide that fact.
[1896-12-22 00:42:37] Home | I thought of how he had realized that the diplomat's courtesy was based on a completely independent point of view, decided by himself.
[1896-12-22 00:42:42] Home | I thought that when someone makes the Stevenes bored or unhappy, his entire spiritual qualities or sensitivity become useless; they are not as effective as another person's straightforward and easygoing manner, which wins the Stevenes' favor, even though that person seems hollow, superficial, and worthless in the eyes of many.
[1896-12-22 00:42:47] Home | I heard everyone in the committee talking in surprise: "De Paul has invited Steven to dinner again, that's quite a big deal." I knew that he had no contact with anyone in the committee.

[1896-12-22 00:42:52] Home | I heard James say, "Steven is sure he'll tell Steven another thrilling story about the 1870 war."
[1896-12-22 03:32:02] Home | I knew that James knew Paul was perhaps the only one who had drawn the Emperor's attention to Prussia's military buildup and warlike intentions; I also knew that Unknown_Bismarck had expressed admiration for De Noailles' wisdom.
[1896-12-23 04:09:49] Home | I know that just recently, at a grand evening event at the opera house for Emperor Theodosius, the press noted that the emperor had held a long audience with Paul.
[1896-12-23 04:10:09] Home | I heard James, who was interested in foreign policy, say to the Stevenes: "Steven should find out whether the Emperor's visit is really important. Steven knows that old Paul keeps his mouth shut, but he talks freely with Steven."
[1896-12-23 04:10:14] Home | I thought that, in Robert's eyes, the ambassador himself might lack the kind of intelligence that most interested her.
[1896-12-23 04:10:19] Home | I knew that Paul's conversation was a complete example of an old form of language specific to a certain profession, a certain social class, a certain period—perhaps not entirely abolished for that profession and social class.
[1896-12-23 04:10:39] Home | I felt sorry that Steven had not been able to transcri be what he had heard, for then he could have easily created the effect of linguistic old age without any effort.
[1896-12-23 04:10:44] Home | I know, just like that actor at the Palais-Royal: someone asked him where he found those astonishing hats, and he replied, "Not found. Preserved."
[1896-12-23 04:11:04] Home | I thought that in short, Steven felt that Robert found Paul a bit "out of date."
[1896-12-23 04:11:09] Home | I thought that in terms of behavior, he didn't make her unhappy, but in terms of thought—actually Paul's thoughts were very up-to-date—perhaps he was far less attractive than in terms of language, which had no charm at all in her eyes.
[1896-12-23 04:11:14] Home | I thought that, if she were to praise the diplomat in front of her husband, who had shown such an unusual favor toward him, her husband would secretly feel pleased.
[1896-12-23 04:11:19] Home | I saw that she confirmed James's favorable opinion of Paul, and at the same time led him to form a favorable opinion of herself. I thought of how she was aware that she was fulfilling her duty: to make her husband happy, just as one would make a dish delicious or keep the servant who brings the food quiet.
[1896-12-23 04:11:24] Home | I saw that she was bad at lying to James, so I began to cultivate an appreciation for the ambassador in order to sincerely praise him.
[1896-12-23 04:11:34] Home | I had seen Steven once walk with his tall figure straight as a rod, but when he saw Steven's mother driving by in her carriage, he would immediately throw away the cigar he had just lit and lift his hat in greeting. I thought to myself, after all, she certainly appreciated his kind expression, his somewhat outdated manners (and overly formal).
[1896-12-23 04:11:39] Home | I thought of how she also appreciated his measured conversation—he avoided talking about himself as much as possible and always sought topics that would please the other person—and the astonishing speed with which he replied.
[1896-12-23 04:11:44] Home | I saw James had just sent a letter when he received a reply, and I saw the handwriting of Paul on the envelope. I thought his first reaction would be that the two letters had just happened to miss each other.
[1896-12-23 04:11:49] Home | I wondered if the post office gave him special treatment, staying overtime to receive and send his letters.
[1896-12-23 04:11:54] Home | I thought of Robert praising him for responding quickly despite his busy schedule, and for being amiable despite his wide circle of acquaintances.
[1896-12-23 04:11:59] Home | I thought that what she hadn't considered these "althoughs" were actually "because"s, only she hadn't recognized them.
[1896-12-23 04:12:04] Home | I thought about how she had not thought (just as people are surprised by an old person's longevity, a king's disregard for etiquette, or a provincial's well-informed nature), Paul was precisely governed by the same habit, busily occupied yet quickly responding to letters, pleasant in society yet kind to Steven.
[1896-12-23 04:12:09] Home | I thought, once again, that like all excessively modest people, Robert's mistake lay in placing things concerning herself below those of others, that is, outside of them.
[1896-12-23 04:12:14] Home | I thought it was remarkable that she believed James could reply immediately, when in fact he wrote numerous letters every day, and this was just one of them, yet she regarded it as an exception among many.
[1896-12-23 04:12:19] Home | I thought that she couldn't see that Paul coming to eat at Steven's house was merely one of his many social engagements, because she didn't realize that the ambassador, in his former diplomatic career, had been accustomed to regard an invitation to dinner as a duty, and to display his usual courteous manners.
[1896-12-23 04:12:24] Home | I thought it would be too much to ask him to, for once, abandon his usual attentiveness at Steven's house.
[1896-12-23 19:18:40] Champs-Élysées Street | I know that in the year Paul first came to dine at our house, Steven still often played along the Champs-Élysées.
[1896-12-23 19:59:59] Home | I thought about how this meal would remain in Steven's memory, because that afternoon Steven finally got to see the matinee performance of "Phedre" starring Arthur.
[1896-12-23 20:00:04] Home | I thought of it also because the conversation with Paul suddenly made Steven feel in a new way how different the feelings that Michael and her parents aroused in him were from those they would arouse in anyone else.
[1896-12-23 20:00:09] Home | I know the New Year's holiday is coming. I thought of Steven, who was growing increasingly listless, because Michael had told him herself that he would never see her again during the holidays.
[1896-12-23 20:00:14] Home | I saw that Robert had probably noticed Steven's mood, and to cheer him up one day, she said to Steven. I heard, "If you still really want to see Arthur's play, Steven thinks James will agree, and David can take you."
[1896-12-23 20:00:19] Home | I knew it was because Paul had once told James that Steven should go see Arthur's play, which would be a precious memory for a young person.
[1896-12-23 20:00:39] Home | I knew that James had finally changed his usual attitude—he had opposed Steven for wasting time on what he called trivial matters (a view that shocked David) and risking getting sick and staying in bed.
[1896-12-23 20:00:59] Home | I thought and almost believed that since the ambassador had advised Steven to go to the theater, going to the theater had apparently become one of the secrets to success.
[1896-12-23 20:01:04] Home | I knew that David always believed Steven could learn a lot from Arthur's performances, but for Steven's sake she gave up going to the theater, making great sacrifices for his health.
[1896-12-23 20:01:24] Home | I thought, at that moment, she was extremely astonished, because a single word from Paul had made Steven's health seem trivial.
[1896-12-23 20:01:29] Home | I thought that she placed a rationalist's firm hope in Steven's habit of taking fresh air and going to bed early, and therefore believed that breaking such a habit would bring about disaster.
[1896-12-23 20:01:34] Home | I saw her painfully say to James. I heard, "You are too reckless!"
[1896-12-23 20:01:39] Home | I saw James answer angrily. "I heard, 'What, you don't want him to go to the opera now? How absurd, you yourself said time and again that going to the opera is good for him.'"
[1896-12-23 20:01:44] Home | I knew that Paul had altered James's intention regarding another matter that was crucial to Steven.
[1896-12-23 20:02:04] Home | I knew that James had always hoped Steven would become a diplomat, but Steven found it hard to accept.
[1896-12-23 20:02:24] Home | I thought that even if Steven stayed for a while in the Ministry, one day he would be sent to some country as an ambassador, and Michael wouldn't be living there.
[1896-12-23 20:02:29] Home | I thought of Steven's willingness to resume the literary plans he had conceived earlier when walking at the Fairhaven' house, which he had later abandoned.
[1896-12-23 20:02:34] Home | I know that James always opposed Steven's pursuit of literature, considering it far more inferior to diplomacy. He even could not call it a profession.
[1896-12-23 20:02:54] Home | I know, but one day, Paul, who usually looked down on the new generation of diplomats, said to James that being a writer was just as respected as being an ambassador, had the same influence, and offered even greater independence.
[1896-12-23 20:03:14] Home | I heard James say to Steven, "Well! I never expected Paul to have no objection to your pursuing literature."
[1896-12-23 20:03:19] Home | I thought that my father was a person of considerable influence, and therefore believed that any problem could be resolved through conversation with an important person, and resolved satisfactorily.
[1896-12-24 10:27:26] Home | I heard him say, "In a few days, after the meeting, Steven will bring him to dinner. You can talk to him, show off a bit. Write something good for him to see. He's very close to the editor-in-chief of the Revue des Deux Mondes. He'll get you in, he'll arrange it. He's a shrewd old man, indeed, he seems to think that in today's world..."

[1896-12-24 10:27:31] Room | I thought of the happiness of not being separated from Michael, which made Steven desire to write a good article for Paul--not out of ability.
[1896-12-24 10:27:36] Room | I grew tired as I saw Steven start to write a few pages; the pen fell from Steven's hand, and Steven burst into tears in anger.
[1896-12-24 10:27:46] Room | I thought of Steven, thinking that he would always be mediocre, that he had no talent, that he lacked the ability even to make use of the rare opportunity Paul was offering him to never leave Willowbrook.
[1896-12-24 10:27:51] Room | I thought that when Steven was able to go and see Arthur's play, his sorrow was somewhat relieved.
[1896-12-24 10:27:56] Room | I thought of the scenery that Steven loved best—the stormy seashore, because it was the most violent—and in a similar way, Steven's favorite actress was the one who played traditional roles, since Matthew had once told Steven that her art in portraying these roles was truly masterful.
[1896-12-24 10:28:01] Room | I thought that when Stevenes wished to receive some natural or artistic impression in order to gain a valuable discovery, they certainly did not want their minds to be subjected to inferior impressions that might lead them astray in judging the true value of beauty.
[1896-12-24 10:28:06] Room | I thought of Arthur performing Andromaque, Marianne the Fickle, and Hypermnestra—the magnificent scenes that Steven's imagination had longed for.
[1896-12-24 10:28:11] Room | I thought that if Steven could hear Arthur reciting these lines: "They say you are about to leave Steven and his friends, sir...," Steven would be completely entranced.
[1896-12-24 10:28:16] Room | I thought of it as if I were taking a boat to the Church of Frari in Oakdale to see Titian's Virgin or to watch the series of paintings by Carpaccio, "Saint George of Schiavoni."
[1896-12-24 10:28:21] Room | When I thought of Steven, my heart would beat violently. I thought of these verses, which Steven had already read in the simple reproduction of black ink on white paper, but Steven would see them appear in the air and sunlight brought by the golden voice, as if realizing the dream of a journey.
[1896-12-24 10:28:26] Room | I thought of Capaccio's Oakdale, Arthur in "Phedra," masterpieces of painting and theater art, whose charm gave them life in Steven, making Steven feel that Capaccio and Oakdale, Arthur and "Phedra" were one and the same.
[1896-12-24 10:28:31] Room | I thought that, if Steven were to look at a painting by Capacio in the Valleyview gallery, or hear Arthur recite a play that Steven had never heard of, Steven would no longer feel that wonderful astonishment, no longer feel that he had finally seen the extraordinary, unparalleled masterpiece that had long haunted his dreams.
[1896-12-24 10:28:36] Room | I thought that, since Steven expected to gain some insight into the nobility and suffering of Arthur's performance, it would be even more remarkable and authentic if the actress performed a valuable work with her outstanding and genuine artistry, rather than adding a bit of truth and beauty to an ordinary and vulgar plot.
[1896-12-24 10:28:41] Room | I thought that in any case, if Arthur was performing a new play, Steven would find it difficult to judge her acting and recitation.
[1896-12-24 10:28:46] Room | I thought that because Steven couldn't distinguish the lines he didn't know in advance from the meaning imparted by her tone and gestures, he would feel they were inseparable from the script itself.
[1896-12-24 10:28:51] Room | I thought the opposite: the old play that Steven could recite by heart seemed like a vast, specific space prepared in advance, in which Steven could freely judge how Arthur applied her fresh and original creativity to it as if it were a mural.
[1896-12-24 10:28:56] Room | I knew that it was a pity she had left the big stage several years ago and become a star in a popular theater company, where she had made great contributions. She no longer performed classical dramas.
[1896-12-24 10:29:16] Room | I saw Steven often looking through the advertisements. I knew, but what I always saw was a new play specially concocted for her by some fashionable writer.
[1896-12-24 10:29:26] Room | One day, I saw Steven searching in the playbill for the matinee performances of the week of New Year's, and it was the first time he saw Arthur perform two acts from "Phedre." I saw them in the closing act, because the opening piece was meaningless, its name obscure, containing all sorts of special plot elements unfamiliar to Steven.
[1896-12-24 10:29:36] Room | I saw Steven, and also the "Half-Upper-Class Society" and "Fickle Marianne" for the next day and the day after.
[1896-12-24 10:29:51] Room | I saw these names, like the name of "Hedyle," clearly and brightly before Steven's eyes (since Steven was familiar with them), shining with an artistic smile.
[1896-12-24 10:30:06] Room | I saw Steven reading another report saying that Arthur had decided to personally perform the roles she had created in the past. I thought they seemed to enhance Arthur's brilliance.
[1896-12-24 10:30:11] Room | I thought that artists must know that the meaning of certain roles is not limited to their first performance, to surprise the audience, or to be successfully performed again.

[1897-02-08 22:24:51] The dining room at Swann's house | I knew Edward replied, "Steven completely agrees with your opinion. She was a little timid just now, but she will be likable in the future."
[1897-02-08 22:25:11] The dining room of Swann's house | I thought about the ability to talk honestly and sincerely about such matters, an ability Matthew had learned from Edward and still maintained, using it now on the guests he received himself.
[1897-02-08 22:25:16] The dining room of Swann's house | I thought about how he tried to recognize these qualities in them, and how everyone possesses these qualities when the Stevenes observe people with a well-meaning bias rather than a critical sense of aversion.
[1897-02-08 22:25:21] The dining room of Swann's house | I thought that whenever Steven and others, in another period of their lives, associated with (or re-established contact with) a certain social class and felt deeply loved, they naturally clung to that class and took root among those people.
[1897-02-08 22:25:26] Home | I thought that, since Matthew kept mentioning Madame Bontemps, Steven figured he wouldn't mind Steven telling his parents about Madame Bontemps' visit to John.
[1897-02-09 22:17:35] Home | I saw how John was gradually getting to know someone, and my parents were quite interested in him, but without any admiration.
[1897-02-09 22:17:45] Home | I heard Robert say when she heard the name of the Trémouille woman: "Ah! She's a new member, she'll take others with her."

[1897-02-09 22:17:55] Home | I once saw her meet John on the street, and when she got home, she told Steven about it. I heard "John is in a state of war. She's probably launching a victorious campaign against the Massachusettes, the Sinhalese, and the Tornbians."
[1897-02-09 22:18:00] Home | I saw Steven telling her which newcomers he had seen in that artificial, contrived setting, and Robert immediately guessed where they were from, as if it were a costly trophy she had purchased. I heard, "This is a spoil taken from the home of someone or other."
[1897-02-09 22:18:05] Home | I heard James say, "Of course, the professor is a person of standing, but Steven still doesn't understand how she thinks." [1897-02-09 22:18:10] Home | I thought, but Robert understood perfectly. [1897-02-09 22:18:15] Home | I thought that to accomplish this, it was necessary for a witness to be introduced into the new, pleasant circle, like a buzzing, fickle insect diving into a flowerbed. Then, after each visit, the witness would spread rumors, quietly sowing seeds of envy and admiration.

[1897-02-09 22:19:00] Home | I know that when Steven was young, everything belonging to the conservative society became a social fashion, so an esteemed salon would never receive Republicans.
[1897-02-09 22:19:20] Home | I know, but society is like a kaleidoscope; it sometimes turns, rearranging factors once thought unchangeable into new patterns, thus forming new images.
[1897-02-09 22:19:40] Home | I knew that later, not long after Steven began visiting John's house, the Affair took on a new standard, and the kaleidoscope once again turned over its colored diamond-shaped pieces.
[1897-02-09 22:20:00] Home | I knew that everything belonging to the Jews ended up at the bottom of the kaleidoscope, not even the refined ladies were exempt, and in their place came the nameless anti-revisionists.

[1897-02-09 22:21:25] Home | I knew that Mrs. Ruphus Israel was different from everyone else; she clearly understood who it was that Matthew was generously associating with, and she was very envious. She used her influence to dissuade the people she knew from receiving John.

[1897-02-10 23:08:21] Home | I knew that although he continued to associate with respectable people (at least for his own sake), he did not want them to hold any important place in the conversations at his wife's salon. [1897-02-10 23:08:41] Home | I heard someone ask her about the Goulmont family, and she replied, "They're from the Aisne department."

[1897-02-11 05:34:34] Swann's house | When Matthew himself said a refined or even profound remark, John was often uninterested, distracted, impatient, and sometimes even responded sharply.

[1897-02-11 05:34:49] Swann's house | I thought that, in reverse, there are also many outstanding women who are deceived by foolish men who criticize their intelligence, and swayed by an excessive love that makes them admire the vulgar jokes of these fools.
[1897-02-11 05:34:54] Swann's house | I know that regarding the reasons which prevented John from entering the German quarter at that time, it should be noted that the recent shift in the kaleidoscope of society had been caused by a series of scandals.

[1897-02-11 05:35:39] Swann's house | I thought that John was too similar to that scapegoat of the social world. In fact, people in high society are severely nearsighted.
[1897-02-11 05:35:44] Swann's house | I knew they had cut off contact with the Jewish lady they had previously known, and were considering how to fill the void, when they saw a new woman who seemed to have been blown in by a single night's storm, and she was also Jewish. [1897-02-11 05:35:49] Swann's house | I knew she did not demand that people venerate their God. People therefore accepted her. [1897-02-11 05:35:54] Swann's house | I noticed that when he spoke of whom he had just visited, Steven observed that among his old friends, he was selective, and his criteria were still the semi-artistic, semi-historical taste of a collector. [1897-02-11 05:36:29] Swann's house | I thought of these interesting (or, as Matthew considered them, interesting) social experiments that did not produce the same reaction— at least not often— on each of his wife's girlfriends.

[1897-03-08 00:41:57] Bois de Boulogne | I saw that sometimes the lady of high society would stop and greet John happily, an action that would lead to no consequences. She was dressed in a dark coat, wearing a small hat with two ribbons tied under her chin, resembling the figures in a Winterhalter portrait.
[1897-03-08 00:42:17] Near the Zoo | I heard her speak to Matthew in a slightly annoyed, deep voice, as if she were an intimate friend: "Please, put on your hat."
[1897-03-08 00:42:22] Near the Zoo | I saw John say to Steven, "Come on, Steven, let me introduce you to Her Royal Highness."

[1897-03-08 00:42:32] Near the Zoo | I saw that he then said something to the princess. I heard "That day Steven met Taine, and he said the princess had quarreled with him."
[1897-03-08 00:42:37] Near the Zoo | I saw her speaking in a loud voice. I heard that "his behavior was like that of a pig, ever since he wrote that article about the emperor," Steven left him a calling card with "Come to say goodbye." I knew (in her mouth, the word "pig" was pronounced like the name of a bishop from the time of Joan of Arc)

[1897-03-08 00:43:17] Near the Zoo | I saw John, completely unaware of the impatient expression she was making toward her husband. I heard, "It's said that Prince Louis has joined the Russian army; he's not by the princess's side, and she'll feel lonely."

[1897-03-13 02:23:23] Paris Exhibition | I saw in the hall that the early spring and the scorching sunlight caused the pink Alpilles to shimmer with a pale purple sheen, and made the Grand Canal gleam with a clear, deep green. I thought of those days when the cold had not yet left, and the exhibition hall rekindled Steven's old desire to go south to Oakdale.
[1897-03-13 02:23:28] Tea Room | I saw that if the weather was bad, the Stevenes went to the concert hall or theater, and then to a "tea room" for pastries. I heard that whenever John wanted to tell Steven something but didn't want the person sitting next to him or the servants attending to Steven to understand, she would speak English to Steven, as if only the two of them understood it.
[1897-03-17 04:50:55] Tea Room | I saw Steven have to remind John not to talk about the people drinking tea or the ones serving it, because her remarks reached the ears of those she was talking about, word for word. I knew that everyone actually spoke English, except Steven, who had not yet learned it. I thought that although Steven didn't understand a single word, he guessed it was certainly not a compliment.
[1897-03-17 04:51:00] Swann's house | I know that once, Michael's attitude regarding the matinee performance surprised Steven. That day happened to be the anniversary of her grandfather's death, the day she had mentioned before. She and Steven had originally planned to go to a concert of opera excerpts with her governess.
[1897-03-17 04:51:20] Swann's house | I saw her already dressed and ready to go to the concert. I heard her adopt an indifferent attitude (no matter what the Stevenes wanted to do, she always remained cold-hearted; she said it didn't matter to her what she did, as long as Steven was happy and as long as her parents were happy).
[1897-03-17 04:51:25] Swann's house | I saw Michael remain unmoved, but she could not hide her anger; her face turned pale, and she said nothing. I heard that before lunch, she Robert took Steven aside and told him that going to the concert on this day would make James unhappy. I thought Steven found the words reasonable.
[1897-03-18 05:27:58] Swann's house | When I saw my husband return, John called him to the other end of the living room for a hushed conversation. Then he asked Michael to go with him to the next room alone. I saw Stevens hearing the gurgling sounds.
[1897-03-19 06:04:46] Swann's house | I heard him finally come out and say to her, "Steven just told you. It's up to you now." I thought of Steven, who couldn't believe that Michael, who had always been obedient, gentle, and quiet, would actually have a confrontation with James over such a trivial matter on such a day.
[1897-03-19 06:04:51] Swann's Gilberte's Room | I saw that Michael remained stiff-faced at the dinner table. After dinner, Steven and the others went to her room, and suddenly, without the slightest hesitation (as if she hadn't hesitated for a single moment), she exclaimed. I heard her say, "It's already two o'clock! You know, the concert starts at half past two." She urged the tutor to hurry up.
[1897-03-19 06:04:56] Swann's Gilberte's room | "I heard 'But,' Steven said to her, 'won't your James be upset?' 'Not at all.' "
[1897-03-19 06:05:01] Swann's Gilberte's Room | "I heard, 'But he probably thinks this day isn't very suitable.' 'What do other people think have to do with Steven? It's absurd to meddle in matters of feeling. The Stevenes feel for themselves, not for others. The girl has few chances for entertainment, and she's delighted to go to the concert. Steven shouldn't make her unhappy just to please someone else."
[1897-03-19 06:05:06] Swann's Gilberte's room | I saw her take up her hat. "But Michael," Steven grabbed her arm and said, "it's not for others' pleasure, it's for your James's." "I hope you won't come to lecture Steven," she said sharply, struggling free from Steven's grip.
[1897-03-21 07:18:32] Swann's house | I thought that the Matthews, in addition to taking Steven to the zoo or the concert hall, had given him something even more precious: they did not exclude him from their friendship with Christopher, a friendship that had once made them magical in Steven's eyes.
[1897-03-21 07:18:37] Swann's house | I thought that Steven had already believed, even before meeting Michael, that her close relationship with this holy elder would make her Steven's most beloved girlfriend, provided that her disdain for Steven did not ruin Steven's hope—that one day she would take Steven and Christopher to visit the city he loved.
[1897-03-21 07:18:42] The foyer of Swann's house | One day, I saw John invite Steven to a grand banquet. When Steven arrived, something he encountered in the foyer made him feel timid and confused. I knew that Steven didn't know who the guest sitting next to him was.
[1897-03-25 09:46:09] The vestibule of Swann's house | I knew that John always adopted the manners that were considered the most fashionable in the season, but which soon became outdated and were discarded (for example, she had once had a hansom cab, or she had once printed on her dinner invitations that it was an audience with some great and famous person).
[1897-03-25 09:46:29] The vestibule of Swann's house | I knew these etiquettes were not mysterious and required no instruction to master. John adopted a small invention imported from England, having her husband have some business cards printed with the title "Mr." before Matthew's name.
[1897-03-25 09:46:49] The hall of Swann's house | After Steven's first visit to John, she came to Steven's house and left what she called a "note," and in her excitement, Steven spent all his money to buy a very beautiful tea-flower basket for John. [1897-03-25 09:46:54] The vestibule of Swann's house | I saw Steven beg James to leave her a business card, and first of all to have the word "Mr." printed before her name, but James ignored both requests. I thought Steven would be very disappointed, but a few days later, Steven reflected that perhaps he had done the right thing.
[1897-03-25 09:46:59] The vestibule of Swann's house | I saw Steven about to enter the drawing room when the steward handed him a long envelope addressed to Steven. I thought about the "Mr" which, though merely a formality, had an obvious meaning, but the other etiquette that Steven encountered on the day of the meal was perplexing.
[1897-03-25 09:47:04] The vestibule of Swann's house | I saw Steven, in astonishment, thanking him, then looking at the envelope, unsure what to do with it, like a foreigner facing those little tools handed out at a Chinese banquet, completely unsure how to handle them.
[1897-03-25 09:47:09] The vestibule of Swann's house | I saw him, and Steven, with an expression of understanding, slipped it into his pocket. I thought the envelope was sealed, and it would be impolite to open it right away.
[1897-03-25 11:35:58] Swann's living room | I knew that several days earlier, John had written to Steven inviting him to dinner at her house with "a few acquaintances." That day there were as many as sixteen guests, and Steven had no idea that Christopher was among them.
