[1897-03-25 11:36:28] Swann's living room | I saw "Christopher" as a bullet shot at Steven, shocking him, but in order to appear composed, Steven instinctively bowed to him.
[1897-03-25 11:36:33] Swann's living room | I saw a young-looking man, not tall, bowing to Steven. I saw him, sturdy in build, nearsighted, with a red nose that curled upward like a snail's shell, and a black goatee.
[1897-03-25 11:36:43] The living room of Swann's house | I saw him standing in front of Steven, as if he were a magician. I thought of him in his formal attire, unharmed in the smoke of the shooting, while a dove flew out of the gun's muzzle.
[1897-03-25 11:36:48] The living room of Swann's house | I thought of Steven in the depths of despair, because what had been reduced to dust was not only that frail old man (who was now completely gone), but also the beauty contained in those great works, which Steven had once sheltered within a weak and sacred body he had specially created for it, like a temple.
locations: The living room of Swann's house

text:
[1897-03-25 11:36:53] Swann's living room | I thought of the short man with the upturned nose and thick mustache standing before Steven, whose sturdy body (full of blood vessels, bones, and nerve clusters) could possibly harbor any place for beauty?
[1897-03-25 11:36:58] Swann's living room | I thought of how Steven had once shaped Christopher using the transparent beauty found in Christopher's own works, slowly, carefully, like a stalactite dripping drop by drop, but in an instant, this Christopher became meaningless.
[1897-03-25 11:37:03] Swann's Living Room | I thought that because Steven had to keep his upturned nose and black beard, it was like how Stevens solve problems without looking at all the data, without considering what the total should be, but just seeking the answer—it was meaningless.
[1897-03-25 11:37:08] Swann's living room | I thought about the nose and mustache, which were unavoidable factors that put Steven in a difficult position, forcing him to reshape the figure of Christopher.
[1897-03-25 11:37:13] Swann's living room | I thought that they seemed to mean, to produce, to constantly secrete some worldly and self-satisfied spirit, which was discordant, since it had nothing in common with the temperament of the works that Steven was familiar with, which were filled with peaceful and sacred wisdom.
[1897-03-25 11:37:18] The living room of Swann's house | I thought that from the work itself, Steven would never reach that upturned nose. And yet, from this seemingly indifferent, self-assured, and whimsical nose, Steven took a path completely opposite to Christopher's work.
[1897-03-25 11:37:23] Swann's living room | I thought of Steven's mental state as resembling that of a hurried engineer—when people greeted him, he would answer without waiting for them to say "how are you?" as if it were perfectly natural: "Thank you, and you?"
[1897-03-25 11:37:28] Swann's Living Room | I thought that if someone said they were pleased to meet him, he would use the concise, clever, and fashionable sentence he considered effective: "The same to you," in order to avoid wasting valuable time on meaningless small talk.
[1897-03-25 11:37:33] Swann's living room | I thought the name was obviously the work of an impulsive painter, who sketched people and places with whimsical imagination. Therefore, when the Stevenes encountered not an imagined world but the visible one, they were often greatly surprised.
[1897-03-25 11:37:38] The living room of Swann's house | I thought that for Christopher, what made Steven more embarrassed was not Steven's preconceptions about his name, but Steven's knowledge of his work. Steven had to tie the man with the goat beard to these works, as if fastening him to a balloon, anxiously fearing that the balloon would not take off.
[1897-03-25 11:37:43] Swann's living room | I saw that, however, the books that Steven loved were indeed his own works. I thought about how, when John, according to custom, told him that Steven admired his work, he took the compliment—given specifically for him and not for any other guest—completely calmly, as if he didn't even consider it a misunderstanding.
[1897-03-25 11:37:48] The living room of Swann's house | I saw him smile slightly when the Stevenes mentioned his work. I thought of him dressed in his formal attire for these guests, beneath which was the body that greedily awaited the meal, its attention fixed on some more important reality.
[1897-03-25 11:37:53] The living room of Swann's house | I thought of them as nothing more than fragments of his old life, as if what the Stevenes mentioned was nothing but that trivial matter of him once dressing up as Samuel at a masquerade ball.
[1897-03-25 11:37:58] Swann's living room | I thought that in this smile, the value of his work plummeted before Steven's eyes (and extended to the entire value of beauty, the universe, and life), becoming nothing more than a clumsy pastime for the man with the goat's beard.
[1897-03-25 11:38:03] Swann's living room | I thought of Steven, who had once worked diligently at his writing. In fact, if he had lived on an island that produced mother-of-pearl, he would not have written, but would have dealt in pearls. His creation was no longer as inevitable as it had been before.
[1897-03-25 11:38:08] Swann's living room | I thought, so Steven began to wonder whether the uniqueness of a great writer truly proved that he was a god in his own particular kingdom, or whether all of this was merely fiction, and the differences between his works actually came from labor, not from any fundamental essential difference between different personalities.
[1897-03-25 16:38:13] Swann's Restaurant | I saw Steven and his friends taking their seats. Next to Steven's plate was a carnation wrapped in silver paper at its stem. I thought about it, and it was nothing like the envelope I had just received in the antechamber (and Steven had already forgotten about it completely), which had so confused Steven.
[1897-03-25 16:38:23] Swann's Restaurant | I saw Steven taking the same carnations from the table and inserting them into the buttonholes of his coat. Steven did the same, looking perfectly natural. I thought that although this etiquette was new to Steven, it seemed easy enough to understand, like an atheist entering a church and not knowing what the mass was about, but standing up when everyone else stood and kneeling when everyone else knelt.
[1897-03-25 16:38:28] Swann's Restaurant | I saw another unfamiliar but fleeting formality that made Steven very unhappy. I saw on the other side of Steven's plate a smaller dish containing something dark and sticky (Steven didn't know it was caviar at the time).
[1897-03-25 16:38:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought Steven didn't know what to do with it, but Steven was determined not to touch it.
[1897-03-25 16:38:43] Swann's Restaurant | I saw Christopher sitting not far from Steven, and the words he spoke were clearly heard by Steven, who suddenly understood why Paul had formed that impression of him. I thought he really did have a strange organ.
[1897-03-25 16:38:48] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that nothing more than the ideas contained within could alter the quality of a voice. Ideas affect the intensity of diphthongs, the strength of labial sounds, and the pitch of tone.
[1897-03-25 16:38:53] Swann's Restaurant | I thought his way of speaking was completely different from his writing style, and even the content he spoke about was entirely different from what he wrote.
[1897-03-25 16:38:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought his voice came from a mask, yet it did not allow Stevens to immediately recognize the face behind the mask that they had personally seen in his writing.
[1897-03-25 16:39:03] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that long after, Steven would realize that certain fragments of his conversation corresponded exactly to certain parts of his work, and that the forms in his work had become so poetic, so musical.
[1897-03-25 16:39:08] Swann's Restaurant | I saw that he considered his words to have a sculptural beauty unrelated to their meaning. I thought that since human language is connected to the mind but does not express it as clearly as style does, Christopher's words seemed incoherent.
[1897-03-25 16:39:13] Swann's Restaurant | I saw him dragging out certain words, and if he was pursuing a single image, he would string the words together into a monotonous, tedious flow of sound.
[1897-03-25 16:39:18] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that therefore, an overbearing, exaggerated, and monotonous way of speaking was precisely the hallmark of his aesthetic style of speech, the form in which his ability to create a series of harmonious images in his work found expression.
[1897-03-25 16:39:23] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that Steven had to go to such lengths to realize this because what he had said at the time, precisely because it came from Christopher himself, didn't seem like something Christopher would say.
[1897-03-25 16:39:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of these rich and precise ideas, which were lacking in the "Christopher style" that so many columnists prided themselves on.
[1897-03-25 16:39:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought this dissimilarity might stem from another side of the truth—something barely visible in conversation, like looking at a painting through tinted glasses, that is, when you read a page of Christopher's work, you feel it is something no mediocre imitator could have written at any time.
[1897-03-25 16:39:38] Swann's Restaurant | I realized that the difference in style lay in the "Christopher style," which was first and foremost about excavation. This great writer, with his genius, unearthed the precious and true elements hidden within every thing, excavating— not the "Christopher style"—was the gentle singer's true purpose in creation.
[1897-03-25 16:39:43] Swann's Restaurant | I realized that, in fact, since he was Christopher, he was, whether he wanted to or not, practicing this style. In that sense, every new beauty in his work was simply every bit of Christopher he had managed to extract from things.
[1897-03-25 16:39:48] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, if each point of beauty is related to other beauties and easily recognizable, it remains unique, and the exploration of it is also unique.
[1897-03-25 16:39:53] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that since beauty was new, it would differ from what people called the Christopher style, which was in fact nothing more than a superficial synthesis of all the various Christophers that Christopher had already discovered and written about. It could certainly not help the mediocre to anticipate what might be found elsewhere.
[1897-03-25 16:39:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that for all great writers, the beauty of their words is like the beauty of a woman one has not yet met—it is unpredictable.
[1897-03-25 16:40:03] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of this beauty, which is attached to some external object that they think of—not themselves—but which has not yet been expressed.
[1897-03-25 16:40:08] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that true diversity lies in the rich, real, and unexpected factors, in the sudden emergence of blue flower branches from the fences already covered with spring blossoms. A mere formal imitation of diversity is nothing but empty and lifeless.
[1897-03-25 16:40:13] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that only those who failed to understand the diversity of a master's work would have an illusion or memory of diversity in imitators.
[1897-03-25 16:40:18] Swann's restaurant | I thought of Christopher's words, which might have been captivating if they were not so closely tied to his active, functioning mind.
locations: The living room of Swann's house

text:
[1897-03-25 16:40:23] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, on the contrary, it was precisely because Christopher applied his thoughts with precision to the reality he loved that his language had something tangible and overly nourishing.
[1897-03-25 16:40:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the eternal and novel qualities in his work, which in conversation transformed into a very subtle way of observing things.
[1897-03-25 16:40:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about how he ignored all the known aspects, as if looking at things from trivial details, falling into errors and contradicting himself, so his thoughts appeared extremely disordered. In fact, the clear-minded thoughts that Steven and others spoke of were simply thoughts that were equally confused, but to Steven's way of thinking they seemed clear.
[1897-03-25 16:40:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that novelty has a prerequisite, which is to exclude the clichés that Steven and others were used to and considered as the very embodiment of reality. Therefore, any novel conversation, like all original paintings or music, initially appears overly contrived and tedious.
[1897-03-25 16:40:43] Swann's Restaurant | I heard when Christopher said that Professor Goard was a float, seeking balance (this metaphor seems simple today), and when he said that Brichot "had taken more care with his hairstyle than John, because he had two considerations: appearance and reputation; his hairstyle had to make him look both like a lion and a philosopher." I thought that the listeners would soon become bored, and they longed for something more concrete, which was really just something more common.
[1897-03-25 16:40:48] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the incoherent words that mask was uttering before Steven, which certainly belonged to a writer whom Steven admired, and it had a different nature, requiring transformation.
[1897-03-25 16:40:53] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that one day, when Steven, talking to himself, repeated the phrases of Christopher that he had heard, Steven suddenly realized that they had a structure similar to his own style. In this oral language that Steven had originally thought was entirely different, he recognized and clearly saw the various elements of his own style.
[1897-03-25 16:40:58] Swann's Restaurant | From a secondary perspective, I noticed that when he spoke, he often used certain words, certain adjectives, and always emphasized them.
[1897-03-25 16:41:03] Swann's Restaurant | I saw him pronouncing these sounds in a special, overly refined and intense way (emphasizing every syllable, prolonging the last one, for instance always using "visage" instead of "figure," and adding numerous v's, s's, and g's to "visage," as if they exploded from his outstretched hands at that very moment). I thought of this way of pronouncing, which was entirely in keeping with the prominent place he gave to these words he loved so much in his writing.
[1897-03-25 16:41:08] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about the blank space before these words, about how the words were arranged according to the rhythm of the sentences, so that one had to fully exploit their "length," otherwise the rhythm would be disturbed.
[1897-03-25 16:41:13] Swann's Restaurant | I thought, but in Christopher's language there was no such light that often changes the shape of words, as found in his or other writers' works. This was probably because his language came from the deepest level, and its light did not reach Steven's words.
[1897-03-25 16:41:18] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that when Stevenes opened their hearts to others in conversation, in a way they were closing themselves off.
[1897-03-25 16:41:23] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, in this respect, his work had more tonal variations and more nuances than words.
[1897-03-25 16:41:28] Swann's restaurant | I thought of this tone as something independent of stylistic beauty, closely tied to the author's deepest personality, so he himself might not even be aware of it.
[1897-03-25 16:41:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of how, when Christopher spoke freely in his writings, it was precisely this tone that gave rhythm to the words he wrote, which at the time were often insignificant.
[1897-03-25 16:41:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about these tones, which were not indicated in the work, nor were there any marks, yet they automatically attached themselves to the phrases (phrases could only be read in this way), and they were the most fleeting yet most profound aspect of the author.
[1897-03-25 16:41:43] Swann's Restaurant | I knew that certain delicate characteristics revealed in Christopher's conversation were not unique to him. Later, Steven met his brothers and sisters and found these traits even more pronounced in them.
[1897-03-25 16:42:03] Swann's Restaurant | I noticed that in lively sentences, the last few words always carried some sudden, rasping sound, while sad sentences always ended with a weak, dying tone.
[1897-03-25 16:42:13] Swann's Restaurant | I knew that Matthew had known the master when he was young, so he told Steven that he often heard Christopher and his brothers and sisters using this kind of hereditary tone, sometimes a loud cry of intense joy, sometimes a slow, melancholy whisper.
[1897-03-25 16:42:33] Swann's Restaurant | I knew it, and when they played together in the hall, in that chorus which was sometimes deafening and sometimes feeble, Christopher's part was sung the best.
[1897-03-25 16:42:53] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about the voices people utter without thinking, however unique, which are fleeting and disappear with the person, but Christopher's family pronunciation was not like that.
[1897-03-25 16:42:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of Christopher, who was remarkable because he had managed to transcri be the way he dragged out his words into writing, either as repeated cries of joy or as slow, sorrowful sighs.
[1897-03-25 16:43:03] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the resounding final phrases in his writings, which kept repeating and lingering, like the last notes of an opera overture that refuse to end, forcing a repetition again and again until the conductor finally sets down his baton.
[1897-03-25 16:43:08] Swann's Restaurant | I later realized that Steven found this ending to be in harmony with the brass-like sound of the Christopher family.
[1897-03-25 16:43:13] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, for Christopher, ever since he had incorporated the sound of brass instruments into his work, he had gradually stopped using that expression in conversation. From the day he had begun to write--let alone when Steven first met him--the sound of brass had been forever lost from his voice.
[1897-03-25 16:43:18] Swann's Restaurant | I know these young Christophers--the future writers and their siblings--are no more refined or talented than other young people.
[1897-03-25 16:43:38] Swann's Restaurant | I knew that to the latter's eyes, the Christophers were noisy and vulgar, their unpleasant jokes marking their "style"—a pretentious and foolishly amusing one.
[1897-03-25 16:43:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, however, genius, even the greatest genius, mainly does not come from superior intellectual factors and social refinement compared to others, but from the ability to transform and rework them.
[1897-03-25 16:44:03] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that if we were to heat the liquid with an electric bulb, the Stevenes didn't need the strongest bulb, but rather one that no longer illuminated, one that could convert electrical energy into heat instead of light.
[1897-03-25 16:44:08] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that for floating in the air, Stevenes didn't need the strongest engine, but another kind of engine that could convert horizontal speed into lift (instead of running on the ground, it would replace the former horizontal line with a vertical one).
[1897-03-25 16:44:13] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of something similar: the creators of genius works are not people with remarkable speech, extensive knowledge, or those living in the most refined atmosphere, but rather those who suddenly stop living for themselves and transform their own personality into a mirror.
[1897-03-25 16:44:18] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the mirror reflecting their lives, although from a social standpoint, and even in a certain sense from a mental one, this life was commonplace and unremarkable. Yet genius lies in the power of reflection, not in the nature of what is reflected.
[1897-03-25 16:44:23] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the young Christopher, who was able to show his readership the unremarkable salons where he had lived as a child, and the dull conversations he had with his brothers.
[1897-03-25 16:44:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that at this moment, he had risen higher than his friends from his own home, although these people were more clever and more refined. They could get into beautiful Rolls-Royce cars and go home, sneering at the vulgar taste of the Christophers, while he, his simple engine finally "taking off," was looking down on them from above.
[1897-03-25 16:44:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of other characteristics of his speech, which he shared with certain writers of his time (not with his family members).
[1897-03-25 16:44:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of certain younger writers who began to deny him, claiming they had no intellectual common ground with him, yet in their own unconscious way they revealed this very commonality, since they used the adverbs and prepositions he had repeatedly employed, adopted the same sentence structures as him, and spoke with the same attenuated and slowed tone (a reaction against the loquacious language of the previous generation).
[1897-03-25 16:44:43] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that perhaps these young people did not know Christopher, but his ideas had already been instilled in them, and there they caused changes in syntax and intonation, changes that necessarily correlated with originality of thought.
[1897-03-25 16:44:48] Swann's Restaurant | I know that if Christopher had not imitated anyone in terms of style, he certainly imitated a former classmate in conversation, a man who was an excellent talker and had a great influence on Christopher.
[1897-03-25 16:45:08] Swann's Restaurant | I knew that therefore Christopher spoke unconsciously imitating him, but this man's talent was not as great as Christopher's, and he had never written a truly excellent work.
[1897-03-25 16:45:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that if judged by his eloquence, Christopher could only be classified as a disciple, a second-rate writer, but under the influence of his friends' conversation, he was actually a writer with originality and creativity.
[1897-03-25 16:45:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of Christopher, who had always wanted to distinguish himself from the previous generation, which favored abstract ideas and clichés. So when he praised a book, he emphasized and quoted rather the image of a scene or a picture that carried no rational meaning.
[1897-03-25 16:45:38] Swann's Restaurant | "I heard, 'Ah! Very good!' 'Brilliant! A little girl with an orange-red shawl, ah! Very good!' or 'Ah! Yes, there's a passage about the legion marching through the city, ah! Yes, very good!'"
[1897-03-25 16:45:43] Swann's Restaurant | I knew that, in terms of style, he was not entirely in step with his time (and he belonged completely to his own country, because he hated Tolstoy, George Eliot, Ibsen, and Dostoevsky).
[1897-03-25 16:45:48] Swann's Restaurant | I heard him frequently use the word "mild" when praising a certain style. "Yes, Steven prefers Chateaubriand's Atala over his Les Natchez; Steven thinks the former is milder."
[1897-03-25 16:45:53] Swann's Restaurant | I saw that when he said this, he looked very much like a doctor. I heard the patient complain that the milk was upsetting his stomach, and the doctor replied, "Milk is gentle."
[1897-03-25 16:45:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that there was indeed a certain harmony in Christopher's style, one that resembled the kind of harmony ancient people praised in orators, and this sort of compliment is difficult to understand today, since Stevenes are accustomed to modern language, which no longer seeks such effects.

[1897-03-25 16:46:03] Swann's restaurant | I saw him smile shyly when people praised certain passages of his. I heard "Steven thinks it's more real, more accurate, may be a bit useful."
[1897-03-25 16:46:08] Swann's Restaurant | I heard it, but it was just modesty, just like when a woman, praised on her dress or her daughter, says, "It's comfortable," or "She has a good temper."
[1897-03-25 16:46:13] Swann's restaurant | I thought, but the architect's instinct was deeply rooted in Christopher, so he could not possibly have been unaware that only joy—the joy that the work gave to him first, and then to others—was the solid proof that his architecture was both useful and true.
[1897-03-25 16:46:18] Swann's Restaurant | I saw that, but many years later, his talent withered, and he kept producing works he wasn't satisfied with. Yet instead of naturally erasing them, he insisted on publishing them. I thought to myself: "In any case, it's quite accurate, and it won't be entirely useless for Steven's country."
[1897-03-25 16:46:23] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that earlier, when he said such things in front of his admirers, it was out of cunning humility, but later, when he said them deep within himself, it was out of the unease caused by his sense of pride.
[1897-03-25 16:46:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the very same words, which had once been Christopher's redundant justification for the value of his early works, and which later seemed to be his ineffective attempt to console himself over his final mediocre works.
[1897-03-25 16:46:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought he had a strict sense of taste, and whatever he wrote had to meet his standards: "It's gentle." Therefore, for many years, he was seen as a little productive, affected, and merely skillful artist. But this strict sense of taste was actually the secret of his strength, because habit both shapes a writer's style and a person's character.
[1897-03-25 16:46:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that if a writer repeatedly settles for a certain kind of pleasure in expressing ideas, he thereby sets a permanent limit on his talent.
[1897-03-25 16:46:43] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that, just as a person who often gives in to pleasures, laziness, fear, pain, and so on, he personally draws, on his own character, the image of his vices and the limits of his virtues— an image that can no longer be changed in the end.
[1897-03-25 16:46:48] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that later Steven would come to see many similarities between the writer and the person, but at first, in John's house, Steven didn't believe that the man standing before him was Christopher, the author of so many sacred works. Steven's disbelief wasn't entirely without reason, because Christopher himself (in the true sense of the word) also didn't "believe."
[1897-03-25 16:46:53] Swann's Restaurant | I saw that he didn't believe it, so he was especially attentive to those distant acquaintances (though he wasn't the type to affect refinement) — the literary journalists.
[1897-03-25 16:46:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought, of course, that he now learned of his own genius from others' praise, and that social status and official position were worth nothing compared to genius.
[1897-03-25 16:47:03] Swann's Restaurant | I saw him continue to show the utmost respect to mediocre writers, in order to soon become an academician of the French Academy. I thought about how he had learned he was a genius, but he didn't believe it.
[1897-03-25 16:47:08] Swann's Restaurant | I realized that the French Academy or the Saint-Germain district had nothing to do with the "eternal spirit" that produced Christopher's work, just as they had nothing to do with the concepts of causality or God.
[1897-03-25 16:47:13] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of that, and he knew it too, just like a person with a stealing compulsion who knows stealing is wrong but can't help himself.
[1897-03-25 16:47:18] Swann's Restaurant | I saw this man with a goat's beard and upturned nose employing his tricks like a gentleman stealing cutlery, in order to approach the esteemed position of an academician, and to get close to a certain Edward who controlled multiple votes; but he was careful not to let those who recognized the true purpose of his maneuvers detect his schemes.
[1897-03-25 16:47:23] Swann's Restaurant | I saw Christopher, at times the real Christopher, and at other times the selfish, ambitious Christopher, who talked at length about powerful, noble, or wealthy people in order to raise his own status. I thought about how he had only achieved half-success. Yet the real Christopher had once so perfectly depicted the clear, refreshing charm of the poor, like a spring.
[1897-03-25 16:47:28] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about the other vices Paul had mentioned, such as love bordering on incest (it was said to be mixed with financial fraud), which clearly ran counter to the tendencies of Christopher's latest novel.
[1897-03-25 16:47:33] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of these novels, which are filled with a devoted and painful pursuit of goodness. Any bit of happiness experienced by the protagonists is tinged with shadow, and even the readers feel anxious. And within this anxiety, even the most fulfilling life seems unbearable.
[1897-03-25 16:47:38] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that even so, even if Christopher's vices were indeed real, it couldn't be said that his literature was a deception, nor that his rich sensitivity was merely an act.
[1897-03-25 16:47:43] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about how, in pathology, certain phenomena appear similar on the surface but have different causes: some result from excessive blood pressure, secretion, and so on, while others result from a deficiency. Similarly, the causes of bad habits can be either excessive sensitivity or a lack of sensitivity.
[1897-03-25 16:47:48] Swann's restaurant | I thought that perhaps in the true life of depravity, the question of morality acquires an anxiety-provoking intensity, and the artist's answer to this question is not drawn from his personal life, but is rather a general, literary answer—this, for him, was truly life.
[1897-03-25 16:47:53] Swann's Restaurant | I thought of the great teachers of the Church, who often, while maintaining their own purity, came into contact with all human sins and from them derived their own personal sanctity. The great artists were no different; they often committed evil deeds while using their own vices to create a moral standard for the masses of Stevenes.
[1897-03-25 16:47:58] Swann's Restaurant | I thought about the vices in the writer's living environment—the careless, dull conversations, the daughter's repulsive flirtatious behavior, the wife's infidelity, and the writer's own mistakes—all things the writer most often condemns in his attacks. Yet they do not therefore change the ostentation of family life or the vulgar atmosphere that fills the house.
[1897-03-25 16:48:03] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that this contradiction was not as surprising in the past as it was in Christopher's time, because on one hand, the increasing moral decay of society had made moral standards more refined, and on the other hand, the public had become more interested than ever before in the private lives of writers.
[1897-03-26 16:40:20] Theater | I saw, on several evenings in the theater, people pointing at the writer whom Steven had so admired in Sunrise. I saw him sitting in the back of the compartment, and the identities of his companions were sufficient to provide a footnote to the views expressed in his recent work—either a ridiculous or sharp satire of those views, or a shameless denial of them.
[1897-03-26 16:40:25] Swann's Restaurant | I know a close friend who has presented evidence that he is cold-hearted, and yet another stranger has cited an example (touching, because Christopher clearly did not want it to become public) that shows he is very sentimental. I thought that what people or others said to Steven did not make Steven any more aware of Christopher's kindness or wickedness.
[1897-03-26 16:40:30] Swann's Restaurant | I know that although he was unfaithful to his wife, when he spent a night in a country inn, he stayed by the side of a poor woman who tried to drown herself, and when he had to leave, he left the innkeeper a good deal of money so that she would not drive away the unfortunate woman, but would take care of her.
[1897-03-26 16:40:35] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that perhaps, as the great writers and the man with the goatee rose and fell within Christopher, his personal life was increasingly submerged in the waves of various lives he imagined.
[1897-03-26 16:40:40] Swann's Restaurant | I thought he no longer had to fulfill actual obligations, because they had been replaced by the duty of imagining various lives.
[1897-03-26 16:40:45] Swann's Restaurant | I thought, since he experienced others' feelings as if they were his own, when circumstances required him to deal with an unfortunate person, his point of view was no longer his own, but that of the suffering person.
[1897-03-26 16:40:50] Swann's Restaurant | I felt a deep hatred for the language of those who care nothing for others' suffering and are only concerned with their own interests, and thus he aroused the inevitable resentment and lasting gratitude around him.
[1897-03-26 16:40:55] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that what this person truly loved deep in his heart were only certain images, only those depicted and sketched with words (like miniature paintings on the bottom of a small box).
[1897-03-26 16:41:00] Swann's Restaurant | I know that if someone gives him a small gift, which can inspire him to weave images, he will thank them again and again; but he shows no gratitude at all for an expensive present.
[1897-03-26 16:41:05] Swann's Restaurant | I thought that if he were to defend himself in court, he would not consider the effect his words might have on the judge, but would inevitably emphasize the image— the image that the judge had certainly not seen.

[1897-03-26 16:41:10] Swann's living room | I remember that on the day I first met Christopher at Michael's house, Steven told him he had recently seen Arthur in "Phèdre." I heard him tell Steven about a scene in which Arthur stood still, arms raised—exactly the moment when she received enthusiastic applause—that was a skillful reproduction of a classical masterpiece in her superb technique.
[1897-03-26 16:41:15] The living room of Swann's house | I saw that he thought she had probably never seen these masterpieces. I heard, "For example, the Hesperides on the metope of the Olympian temple, and the beautiful maiden on the ancient Erechtheion."
[1897-03-26 16:41:20] Swann's living room | I heard, "This might be intuition, but Steven thinks she definitely went to the museum. It would be meaningful to confirm that." I knew (the word "clarification" was a favorite of Christopher's; some young people, although they had never met him, also borrowed his vocabulary, imitating him in a sort of distant inspiration)
[1897-03-26 16:41:25] Swann's living room | I heard Matthew ask, "You mean the caryatid?"
[1897-03-26 16:41:30] Swann's living room | "I heard 'No, no,' Christopher said, 'Of course, when she confessed her love to Aline, her posture was very much like that of the Hecate statue on the Kallimico stele, but besides that, she represented a far older art.'"
[1897-03-26 16:41:35] Swann's living room | "I heard 'Steven mentioned the Caryatids of the ancient Erechtheion temple. Steven admitted they had nothing in common with Racine's art, but The Phaedra was so rich in content... what harm would a little more do..."
[1897-03-26 16:41:40] The living room of Swann's house | "I heard, 'Ah! Besides, the sixth-century Hyacinta was truly beautiful, her straight arms, wavy hair like a marble statue—yes, she really came up with something remarkable. Compared to many of this year's 'classical' works, this play has much more of a classical flavor.'"
[1897-03-26 16:41:45] The living room of Swann's house | I recalled that Christopher had once made a famous pilgrimage to these ancient statues, and thus what he said at that moment was perfectly clear to Steven, giving Steven even more reason to be interested in Arthur's acting.
[1897-03-26 16:41:50] Swann's living room | I saw Steven struggling to remember, to recall the image of her raising her arms as he remembered it. I thought, "This is the Hesperides of Olympus, this is a sister to the beautiful praying figure in the ancient Acropolis, this is noble art."
[1897-03-26 16:41:55] The living room of Swann's house | I thought that, in order for Arthur's posture to be elevated by these thoughts, Christopher should have provided Steven with the thoughts before the performance.
[1897-03-26 16:42:00] The living room of Swann's house | I thought that if that were the case, when the actress's posture actually appeared before Steven's eyes (that is, when the thing currently happening still retained its full reality), Steven could then extract the concept of an ancient sculpture from it.
[1897-03-26 16:42:05] Swann's living room | I thought that now, what Steven retains of Arthur in this play is nothing but an unchangeable memory, a thin image lacking the depth of the present, impossible to dig into, incapable of offering anything new to anyone.
[1897-03-26 16:42:10] The living room of Swann's house | I thought of Steven and others who would be unable to add new interpretations to this image, since such interpretations could not be verified or acknowledged by objective reality.
[1897-03-26 16:42:15] Swann's living room | I saw John trying to join the conversation, so I asked Steven whether Michael had let Steven read Christopher's article on "Phedre." I heard her say, "Steven has a very mischievous daughter." She added.
[1897-03-26 16:42:20] Swann's living room | I saw Christopher smile modestly and explain that the article wasn't worth much. "I say, this little booklet is simply wonderful! Simply wonderful!" John said.
[1897-03-26 16:42:25] The living room of Swann's house | I saw her saying that to show she was a good housewife and to make people believe she had read the book. I thought that she not only liked to flatter Christopher, but also liked to praise some of his works, which inspired him.
[1897-03-26 16:42:30] Swann's living room | I thought that she had, in ways she could not have imagined, inspired him. In any case, there was a close connection between the refined atmosphere of John's salon and a certain aspect of Christopher's work, and to the old man of today, they could illuminate each other.
[1897-03-26 16:42:35] The living room of Swann's house | I saw Steven speak casually about his impressions, and Christopher did not agree, but let Steven continue. I heard Steven tell him about the green light that rose when the Chaudron raised his arm.
[1897-03-26 16:42:40] Swann's living room | "I heard, 'Ah! The set designer will be delighted to hear that, he's a remarkable artist. Steven will tell him your opinion, he's very proud of this lighting design. As for Steven, honestly, Steven doesn't much care for this lighting—it wraps everything in a bluish haze, and little Hydra standing there looks just like coral on the bottom of an aquarium.'"
[1897-03-26 16:42:45] Swann's living room | I heard him say, "You're right, this does highlight the universality of the play. However, if the story were set in Neptune's palace, then this scenery would be even more appropriate. Yes, of course, Steven knows that there's Neptune's revenge in this play."
[1897-03-26 16:42:50] Swann's living room | "I heard 'No, Steven doesn't want people to think only of Port-Royal, but Racine isn't talking about the love of Neptune either. That said, it was Steven's friend's idea, and it had a strong effect, and in the end, quite beautiful.'"
[1897-03-26 16:42:55] Swann's living room | "I heard, 'In short, you like it, you understand it, right? The idea of the Stevens is fundamentally the same. His idea is a bit absurd, isn't it? But after all, it's original.'"
[1897-03-26 16:43:00] Swann's living room | I thought that when Christopher disagreed with Steven, he never made Steven speechless and silent the way Paul might have, but this didn't mean that Christopher was less insightful than the ambassador; on the contrary.
[1897-03-26 16:43:05] The living room of Swann's house | I thought that powerful ideas often give strength to those who oppose them. This idea itself is part of the eternal value of thought, and it clings, grafts itself onto the mind of those it refutes. In turn, these people use certain neighboring ideas to regain a bit of advantage, thereby supplementing and correcting the original idea. Thus, the final conclusion can be considered a joint work of the two disputants.
[1897-03-26 16:43:10] The drawing room of Swann's house | I thought that only those thoughts which, strictly speaking, aren't really thoughts at all—thoughts that have no foundation, find no support or connection in the opponent's mind—would leave the opponent speechless, for he would be facing pure emptiness. Paul's argument (on art) was unanswerable because it was illusory.
[1897-03-26 16:43:15] Swann's living room | I saw that since Christopher did not reject Steven's different opinion, Steven told him that Paul had once looked down on Steven. I heard him say, "He's a simple-minded old man. He pecks at you because he always thinks you're a piece of cake or a squid."
[1897-03-26 16:43:20] Swann's living room | I saw Matthew ask Steven, "Well, do you know Paul?" I heard her say, "Ah, he's as annoying as raindrops," inserting herself into the conversation. She had great confidence in Christopher's judgment, and perhaps also feared that Paul might speak ill of her in front of the Marceaux.
[1897-03-26 16:43:25] Swann's living room | I heard that "after dinner, Steven wanted to talk to him, but for some reason—whether age or digestion—he seemed very sluggish. Steven thought he should have been given a stimulant long ago!"
[1897-03-26 16:43:30] Swann's living room | I heard Christopher say to her: "Yes, that's right. He often had to remain silent, so as not to run out of his foolish remarks before the end, which would have filled up the front of his shirt and the white vest."
[1897-03-26 16:43:35] Swann's living room | I saw that Matthew said he played the reasonable man at home. "I heard that Steven was too harsh on Christopher and Steven's wife. Of course, Paul wouldn't interest you much, but from another point of view (Matthew liked to collect beauty in life), he was quite peculiar, a strange lover,"
[1897-03-26 16:43:40] Swann's living room | I waited until Michael couldn't hear me, then continued. I heard, "He was a secretary in Northgate, and at that time he had a mistress in Willowbrook. He was completely mad about her, and did everything possible to return twice a week, just to spend two hours with her."
[1897-03-26 16:43:45] The living room of Swann's house | I heard him say, "That woman was beautiful and intelligent, but now she's an old lady. In the meantime, he had many mistresses. If Steven had stayed in Northgate, and the woman Steven loved lived in Willowbrook, Steven would have gone mad."
[1897-03-26 16:43:50] Swann's living room | I heard him say, "For people with neurotic tendencies, they have to 'lower themselves' and 'love from below' (as the common people put it), because in this way, the woman they love will take practical considerations into account and compromise with them."
[1897-03-26 16:43:55] The living room of Swann's house | I felt intense dislike for Steven when I thought of how Matthew had suddenly realized that Steven could apply this maxim to his relationship with John, because even when great people seem to soar above life with you, their sense of self-respect remains narrow-minded.
[1897-03-26 16:44:00] The living room of Swann's house | I saw Matthew show only a slight aversion in his restless eyes, saying nothing aloud. It was nothing surprising. It is said—though this is a fabrication, yet one that is daily repeated in Willowbrook life—that when Racine mentioned Sgallon to Louis XVI, the most powerful king in the world said nothing to the poet that night, yet the next day Racine was out of favor.

[1897-03-29 03:18:23] Marcel's house | I saw Steven had just written a letter to Michael to vent his anger, but he had also carefully inserted a few phrases that seemed accidental, which his girlfriend could grasp as lifelines to reconcile with Steven.
[1897-03-29 03:18:28] Marcel's house | I saw it, but a moment later the wind changed. Steven wrote some tender sentences, using certain sweet yet sorrowful phrases, such as "Never again."
[1897-03-29 03:18:33] Marcel's house | I thought that the reader would find these words touching, while the woman reading the letter would find them boring, or perhaps she would think it all false, interpreting "never again" as "if you need Steven tonight." Or may be she believed it was true, and thus meant a permanent separation (it was hardly worth grieving over parting with someone like Steven, whom they didn't love).
[1897-03-29 03:18:38] Marcel's house | I thought that since the Stevenes were in love, they couldn't behave as they would when they weren't in love anymore. The Stevenes couldn't imagine the woman's true mental state, because although they knew she was cold and unfeeling, they still imagined her speaking in the language of a lover (they did this to deceive themselves with beautiful illusions, or to relieve their heavy sorrow).
[1897-03-29 03:18:43] Marcel's house | I thought of how Steven and others behaved toward the women they loved, like the earliest ancient scientists facing natural phenomena (when science had not yet been established, and unknown things had no explanations), bewildered and even worse.
[1897-03-29 03:18:48] Marcel's house | I saw that Steven could not perceive cause and effect, could not see the connection between one phenomenon and another. The world as seen by Steven was as elusive and intangible as a dream. I thought, of course, that Steven tried to overcome this confusion, tried to find the cause.
[1897-03-29 03:18:53] Marcel's house | I thought of Steven, who even tried to be "objective," seriously considering Michael's position in Steven's eyes, Steven's position in her eyes, and her position in others' eyes—all of which were so utterly different!
[1897-03-29 03:18:58] Marcel's house | I thought that if Steven couldn't perceive this disparity, he would see his girlfriend's simple acts of affection as expressions of passionate love, and he would interpret his own ridiculous and undignified behavior as a simple, elegant admiration for beauty.
[1897-03-29 03:19:03] Marcel's house | I thought, but Steven also feared going to the opposite extreme, seeing Michael's failure to arrive on time and her bad mood as an unchangeable hostility.
[1897-03-29 03:19:08] Marcel's house | I thought of Steven trying to find a third perspective that would correctly reflect things, distinct from these two equally distorted viewpoints. The various calculations Steven made in pursuit of this somewhat eased his pain.
[1897-03-29 03:19:13] Marcel's house | I saw Steven decide to go to Matthew's house the next day (perhaps as a result of these calculations, or perhaps because Steven had made the calculations express his own wishes). I thought of Steven, who was happy, like a person who had never really wanted to travel and had been troubled by it for a long time, only to finally reach the station and decide to cancel the trip, then happily return home and unpack his luggage.
[1897-03-29 03:19:18] Marcel's house | I thought that when people hesitate, the idea of taking a certain course of action (unless they take no decision at all, which would cause the idea to lose its vitality) is like a living seed, outlining the various contours of the passion that would result from completing the action. Therefore, Steven told himself that not seeing her again was merely an idea, yet he felt pain as if it were a real event—how absurd!
[1897-03-29 03:19:23] Marcel's house | I thought, if Steven would eventually return to her anyway, why make such a painful decision and promise?
[1897-03-29 03:19:28] On the way to Swann's house | I knew, however, that this renewed friendship lasted only a moment, while Steven was on his way to Matthew's house. I thought its destruction wasn't because the steward (who liked Steven) told Steven that Michael wasn't home (that evening Steven learned from someone who had met her that she really wasn't home), but because of the way he spoke.
[1897-03-29 07:52:34] At Swann's front door | I heard, "Sir, the lady is not at home. Steven assures you she is indeed not here. If you wish to be certain, Steven can go and call the lady's maid. Sir may rest assured that Steven will do everything possible to please you. If the lady were at home, Steven would immediately lead you to her."
[1897-03-29 07:52:39] At Swann's front door | The only real significance of these words lies in their spontaneity, as they provide an X-ray (at least a rough one) of the unimaginable reality hidden behind pretentious speech.
[1897-03-29 07:52:44] At Swann's front door | I thought that this showed, in the eyes of those around Michael, Steven was a persistent nuisance.
[1897-03-29 07:52:49] At Swann's front door | I thought of these words just now coming from his mouth, which stirred up hatred in Steven's heart; naturally, Steven was happy to direct his hatred toward him rather than toward Michael.
[1897-03-29 07:52:54] At Swann's front door | I thought how Steven would concentrate all his anger upon him, so that Steven's love would be freed from anger and remain by itself.
[1897-03-29 07:52:59] At Swann's front door | I thought, but this also showed that Steven shouldn't go to Michael in the near future. She would write Steven a letter to apologize.
[1897-03-29 07:53:04] At Swann's front door | I thought that, nevertheless, Steven would not go to see her right away; Steven wanted to prove to her that he could live without her.
[1897-03-29 07:53:09] At Swann's front door | I thought to myself that, once Steven received Michael's letter, he would find it easier to endure the pain of not seeing her for a while, because as long as Steven wanted to see her, he would be able to.
[1897-03-29 07:53:14] At Swann's front door | I thought that in order to endure this deliberately designed separation without suffering too much, Steven's heart had to free itself from terrible doubts, such as: what if Steven and I were to break off entirely, what if she had become engaged to someone else and was taken away.
locations: On the way to Swann's house

text:
[1897-03-29 07:53:19] Marcel's house | I knew the following days would be very similar to that New Year week, because at that time Steven had to continue living without Michael. I thought, but at that time Steven was clear that once Monday ended, she would return to the Champs-Élysées, and Steven would see her as he had before. On the other hand, as long as the New Year holiday did not end, it would be useless for Steven to go to the Champs-Élysées.
[1897-03-29 07:53:24] Marcel's house | I thought that, in that already distant and melancholy week, Steven had calmly endured his sorrow, neither fearing nor hoping. But now it was different; this latter feeling, hope, was almost as painful for Steven as fear.
[1897-03-29 07:53:29] Marcel's house | I saw that that evening Steven had not received a letter from Michael. I thought that Steven was blaming her for her negligence and busyness, and I was certain that there would definitely be a letter from her in the morning mail.
[1897-03-29 07:53:34] Marcel's house | I saw that Steven looked forward to the morning's letters every day. I thought of Steven's heart pounding violently, and when Steven received a letter from someone else instead of Michael, he became utterly dejected.
[1897-03-29 07:53:39] Marcel's house | I thought that sometimes Steven received no letter at all, which wasn't necessarily worse, because the friendliness of another woman toward Steven would make Michael's coldness even more ruthless.
[1897-03-29 15:00:00] Marcel's house | I saw that Steven then placed his hopes on the letters arriving in the afternoon.
[1897-03-29 20:42:57] Marcel's house | I saw that even outside of the hours when Steven went to the post office, she didn't go out, because she might have someone deliver the letters for her.
[1897-03-29 20:43:02] Marcel's house | I saw that it was finally late, and neither the postman nor a servant from Matthew's house would come any more, so Steven turned his calmed hopes toward the next morning. I thought that Steven did it because Steven believed that Steven's pain would not last long, and that Steven had to constantly, so to speak, renew it.
[1897-03-29 20:43:07] Marcel's house | I thought of sorrow, which remained as before, but it no longer extended the initial passion in an unchanging way as it had before. Instead, it began anew many times each day. The renewal of passion was so frequent that in the end—being a purely material and temporary state—it settled there.
[1897-03-29 20:43:12] Marcel's house | I thought that, therefore, the confusion caused by the first expectation had not yet calmed down, and the second expectation had already arrived. Steven was constantly in anxiety every moment of the day (enduring even an hour was no easy task).
[1897-03-29 20:43:17] Marcel's house | I thought about this pain, which was a hundred times more severe than the previous New Year's holiday, because this time Steven was not completely accepting the pain, but rather constantly hoping for it to end.
[1897-03-29 20:43:22] Marcel's house | I thought that in the end, Steven finally accepted the pain, Steven understood it was decisive, Steven would forever give up Michael, and this was for Steven's own love, because Steven would never want her to still look down on him in memory.
[1897-03-29 20:43:27] Marcel's house | From that moment on, when she made an appointment for Steven, he would often agree just to avoid making her think he was pouting over love. But at the last minute, Steven would write to her saying he couldn't come and repeatedly express his regret, as if he were dealing with someone he didn't want to see. I thought that Steven, by using these general expressions of apology usually reserved for casual acquaintances, would make Michael believe more in Steven's indifference than if he had pretended to be cold toward the woman he loved.
[1897-03-29 20:43:32] Marcel's house | I thought that Steven, without using words, would resort to repeated actions in order to better convey that he had no intention of meeting her; once Steven actually did this, she might once again become interested in Steven.
[1897-03-29 20:43:37] Marcel's house | I thought, it's a pity, this is just daydreaming.
[1897-03-29 20:43:42] Marcel's house | I thought that by no longer seeing her, I could rekindle her interest in seeing Steven again. But this approach was equivalent to losing her forever, because first, when that interest did awaken, Steven couldn't immediately give in to it if he wanted to keep it alive; second, by then the most severe period would already have passed, since Steven needed her most right at this very moment.
[1897-03-29 20:43:47] Marcel's house | I wanted to warn Steven that soon, the pain of separation would greatly lessen, and Steven would no longer, as he did right now, think of surrendering, of reconciliation, of meeting her again just to end the suffering.
[1897-03-29 20:43:52] Marcel's house | I thought about the future, when Michael would regain her interest in Steven, and Steven could safely express his interest to her. But this interest, which could not withstand such a long separation, would no longer exist.
[1897-03-29 20:43:57] Marcel's house | I thought that Michael would become an unnecessary person in Steven's life. Steven was perfectly aware of this, but Steven couldn't bring himself to tell her.
[1897-03-29 20:44:02] Marcel's house | I thought that if Steven told her he no longer loved her because they hadn't seen each other for a long time, she would believe that Steven's only purpose was to make her call him back quickly.
[1897-03-29 20:44:07] Swann's house | During this time, Steven always chose days when Michael was out and wouldn't come home for dinner to visit John (to Steven, she had become the woman she had been before, when Steven rarely saw her daughter, and he would take walks on the plane tree street when the girl wasn't coming to the Champs-Élysées). I thought of a way to make Michael understand that Steven wasn't avoiding her because he was busy with something else or because he was unwell, but because he didn't want to see her, even though Steven had said the opposite.
[1897-03-29 20:44:12] Swann's house | I thought of this method to help Steven more smoothly endure the separation.
[1897-03-29 20:44:17] Swann's house | I thought that since Steven could hear people talking about Michael, she must have also heard people talking about Steven, and she would understand that Steven wasn't attached to her.
[1897-03-29 20:44:22] Location: Swann's house | I thought, like all people in pain, that Steven felt his situation, though bad, was not the worst, because Steven could freely enter Michael's house (though Steven would never take advantage of this privilege).
[1897-03-29 20:44:27] Swann's house | I thought that if the pain were too intense, Steven could stop it.
[1897-03-29 20:44:32] Location: Swann's house | I thought that Steven's suffering was temporary every day, but that wasn't enough—how many times each hour (though the suffocating, anxious expectation of those first weeks of rupture had already passed, before Steven returned to Matthew's house)—Steven recited to himself the letter that Michael would one day send him or bring to him in person!
[1897-03-29 20:44:37] Swann's house | The happiness I imagined, which constantly came to mind at that time, helped Steven endure the destruction of real happiness.
[1897-03-29 20:44:42] Swann's house | I thought of the women who did not love Steven as "the missing," even though the Stevenes knew there was no more hope, they still waited, hoping for the slightest movement, the faintest sound.
[1897-03-29 20:44:47] Swann's house | I thought of how Robert, although fully aware that her son had perished in a dangerous expedition, would still imagine he would be miraculously saved and would soon walk through the door, strong and healthy.
[1897-03-29 20:44:52] Swann's house | I thought of this waiting, which, depending on the strength of memory and the resilience of the body, might either make Robert, years later, acknowledge the fact, gradually forget her son, and go on living, or else cause Robert to die.
[1897-03-29 20:44:57] Swann's house | I thought that, on the other hand, Steven's sadness was beneficial to his love, and this thought gave Steven some slight consolation.
[1897-03-29 20:45:02] Swann's house | I thought about Steven visiting John without seeing Michael, an visit that was always cruel, but Steven felt it would improve Michael's opinion of him.
[1897-03-29 20:45:07] Swann's house | Every time I went to see John, Steven always made sure first that her daughter was definitely not at home. Steven did this not only because he had resolved to cut ties with her, but also because he still hoped for reconciliation.

[1897-03-29 20:45:12] Location: Swann's house | I thought of this hope overlapping with the intention to break off (hope and intention are rarely absolute, at least not always, because the mind follows a law that is subject to sudden surges of different memories, a law of discontinuity), and it made Steven unaware of the cruelty of this intention.
[1897-03-29 20:45:17] Swann's house | I thought to myself that Steven clearly realized the hope was extremely slim.
[1897-03-29 20:45:22] Swann's house | I thought of Steven like a poor man, and if he had been eating dry bread and imagined that perhaps soon a stranger would give him all his fortune, he would not have cried so bitterly.
[1897-03-29 20:45:27] Swann's house | I thought about how, in order to make reality bearable, Stevenes often had to keep some small absurd notion within their hearts.
[1897-03-29 20:45:32] Swann's house | I thought that, had I not met Michael, Steven's hopes would have remained more intact—although at the same time, Steven's separation would have become more real.
[1897-03-29 20:45:37] Swann's house | I thought that if Steven were to meet her at her Robert's house, they might exchange a few words that could not be mended, making the rupture eternal and destroying Steven's hopes. On the other hand, the new anxiety this would create would awaken Steven's love, making it impossible for him to accept fate passively.
[1897-04-03 00:44:22] Swann's house | I heard, "You've come to see Michael, that's good, but I hope you'll sometimes come and see Steven too, just not on Steven's Choufleur day, there are so many guests it will bore you, come on another day, in the late afternoon Steven is always at home." I knew that long ago, before Steven's falling out with his daughter, John had already said these words to Steven.
[1897-04-03 00:44:27] Swann's house | I thought that, therefore, Steven's visit seemed merely the fulfillment of a wish she had expressed a long time ago.
[1897-04-03 00:44:32] Outside Swann's house | I saw Steven leave for John's house at a very late hour, when night had fallen and Steven's parents were about to have dinner. I thought that Steven knew he wouldn't meet Michael during the visit, but all Steven could think about was her.
[1897-04-03 04:43:02] Outside Swann's House | I knew that Willowbrook at that time was not as brightly lit as it is today; even the streets in the city center had no streetlights, and electric lights inside the houses were rare.
[1897-04-03 04:43:17] Outside Swann's House | I saw that in this district, which was considered remote at the time, the brightly lit drawing room on the second floor, just above the ground floor (the room where John usually received her guests), illuminated the street and made passersby look up and take notice.
[1897-04-03 04:43:22] Outside Swann's House | I thought that he naturally connected this light, the obvious yet subtle cause of which was the luxurious carriages at the entrance.
[1897-04-03 04:43:32] Outside Swann's house | I saw that when he saw a carriage starting up, it was actually just the coachman who was afraid the horses would catch cold, so he had them walk back and forth. I found this movement impressive because the rubber tires made no sound at all, making the sound of the horse's hooves seem clearer and more distinct. I thought of him and felt with some emotion that the mysterious cause had changed.
[1897-04-03 04:43:47] Outside Swann's House | I saw that in those days, on any street, if the house wasn't too high above the sidewalk, you could see the indoor "winter garden" from the street (now only visible in the halftone photographs in the Stahlberg New Year's Gift Series).
[1897-04-03 04:44:02] Outside Swann's House | I saw this garden was exactly the opposite of the current Louis XVI-style parlor decoration—few flowers, only a single rose or Japanese iris in a long-necked crystal vase, no more than one flower could fit—and it had a large number of indoor decorative plants that were popular at the time.
[1897-04-03 04:44:17] Outside Swann's house | I saw it, and it was arranged with no particular care; it did not reflect the mistress's calm use of lifeless decoration, but rather her fervent love for living plants.
[1897-04-03 04:44:22] Outside Swann's house | I know it more closely resembles the portable miniature greenhouses that were popular in aristocratic homes at the time. On the morning of January 1st, people placed these greenhouses under the lights--children lacked the patience to wait for daylight--among the New Year's gifts, and it was the most beautiful gift, since one could use it to grow plants and thus forget about the bare and bleak winter.
[1897-04-03 04:44:27] Outside Swann's house | I thought the winter garden was not only similar to this greenhouse, but also to the picture of a greenhouse in the beautifully illustrated book next to it. This picture was also a New Year's gift, but not given to the children, but to the novel's heroine, Miss Lily. It fascinated the children so much that even now, though they are old, they still believe that those fortunate years of winter were the most beautiful season.
[1897-04-03 04:44:42] Outside Swann's house | I have seen passersby, standing on tiptoe, able to see, deep within this winter garden, inside the various kinds of trees (from the street, the lit windows seemed like the glass cover of a children's flower shop — a picture or an actual one), a man in a suit, with a gardenia or a carnation pinned to his buttonhole, standing before a lady who was seated.
[1897-04-03 04:44:57] Outside Swann's house | I saw the two figures indistinctly, like two intaglios in a piece of golden jade. The drawing room was filled with the vapor from the samovar — an imported novelty at the time — and this samovar vapor still exists today, but people have grown accustomed to it and no longer pay any attention.
[1897-04-03 09:34:33] Location: Swann's house | I thought of John, who placed great importance on this "tea." She found it both novel and charming to say to a man, "You come a little later in the evening, Steven is always at home, you can come for tea." She temporarily adopted an English accent, accompanied by a gentle, sweet smile, which made the other person take it very seriously, bowing with a solemn expression as if it were of great importance, strange and extraordinary, something that deserved reverence and must not be taken lightly.
[1897-04-03 09:34:38] Swann's house | I knew that the flowers in John's living room were not merely for decoration; there was another reason, unrelated to the times, but connected solely to John's past life.
[1897-04-03 09:34:58] Swann's house | I knew she had been a mistress, spending most of her time with her lover, that is to say, in her own home, so she had to take care of her household.
[1897-04-03 09:35:18] Swann's house | I knew that the things seen in the homes of respectable women, and considered important by those women, were even more important to a courtesan. Her peak moments each day were not when she dressed to be admired by others, but when she undressed to meet men in secret.
[1897-04-03 09:35:38] Swann's house | I knew that she always had to dress with the same elegance, whether in a dressing gown or a nightgown. Other women displayed their jewelry for all to see, but she kept it hidden within her private room. Such a life required and accustomed one to a secret, almost careless kind of luxury.
[1897-04-03 09:35:58] Location: Swann's house | I saw that John's luxury extended even to flowers. Beside her armchair there was always a large crystal glass vase filled with Palma violets or daisies whose petals floated in the water.
[1897-04-03 09:36:13] Swann's house | I thought the flowerpot seemed to prove to visitors that this was her favorite pastime--just as she liked to drink tea alone,but was interrupted by an uninvited guest. This pastime was even more intimate and mysterious than drinking tea.
[1897-04-03 09:36:18] Location: Swann's house | I thought that, therefore, when the visitor saw the flowers displayed beside her, he would feel compelled to apologize to her, as if he had glanced at the title of a book John had not yet closed, a title that would reveal what she was reading, that is, what she was thinking about at that moment.
[1897-04-03 09:36:23] Swann's house | I thought that, after all, flowers have more life than books. People would come to the drawing room to visit her, and when they found she was not alone, they felt uneasy; people would go home with her, and when they saw the drawing room was not empty, they felt uneasy.

[1897-04-03 09:36:28] Location: Swann's house | I knew these flowers held a mysterious place in the drawing room, closely linked to the unknown life of the mistress of the house. They weren't meant for visitors, but seemed as if John had forgotten them there. I thought of how they had, in the past and still now, whispered secrets to John, and so people were afraid to disturb them, staring intently at the pale purple Palma violet, like diluted watercolor, in vain attempts to glimpse their mystery.
[1897-04-03 09:36:33] Swann's house | I knew that since the end of October, John made a point of coming home on time for tea, which was still called five o'clock tea, because John had heard (and liked to repeat to others) that Mme. Verdurin held her salon precisely so that people would know she was at home at that hour.
[1897-04-03 09:36:53] Swann's house | I knew John also wanted to hold a salon, of the same type as the Verdurin salon, but more free-flowing, as she put it, "senza rigore."
[1897-04-03 09:37:13] Swann's house | I knew that, so she seemed like Mademoiselle de Révilliac, who had snatched the most charming man from the group, especially Matthew, away from Madame de Fleurville, to set up her own establishment.
[1897-04-03 09:37:33] Swann's house | I knew, according to a certain account, that Matthew had followed her throughout her periods of agitation and seclusion. Yet, although she could easily make new acquaintances who were unaware of the past believe her, she herself was not convinced. I thought that when the Stevenes like certain characters, they repeatedly perform them in front of others and rehearse them secretly again and again, so what they end up thinking of are often the illusory witnesses of these characters, almost entirely forgetting the real ones.
[1897-04-03 09:37:38] Swann's house | When I saw John at home all day, she wore a crêpe de Chine dressing gown, as pure and white as fresh snow. Sometimes she wore a pleated muslin robe, sprinkled with pink and white petals.
[1897-04-03 09:37:53] Swann's house | I see that today people might think this outfit is unsuitable for winter, but that's not true. The light silk and soft colors made her (at that time, the drawing room had curtains, which made it very stuffy; the highest compliment a novelist describing salon life could give was "cozy and thickly padded") appear as delicate and chilly as the pink roses that seemed to have been revealed with the coming of spring.
[1897-04-03 09:38:08] Swann's house | I saw that the carpet muffled footsteps, and the hostess was again seated in a corner of the living room, unaware of your arrival. So when you approached her, she was still engrossed in her book, which added to the romantic atmosphere and charm—like suddenly discovering a secret, something that remained vivid in the memories of Stevens.
[1897-04-03 09:38:23] Swann's house | I knew that John's dressing gown was no longer in fashion, and probably only she still wore them, so they seemed like the kind of thing one would see only in a novel (only in Henry Grévy's novels had I ever seen such dressing gowns).
[1897-04-03 09:38:28] Swann's house | I saw that it was early winter, and the large chrysanthemums in John's living room were in full bloom, vibrant and multicolored—something Matthew had never seen in her apartment before.
[1897-04-03 09:38:43] Swann's house | I saw Steven praising them. I thought about how when Steven, in a gloomy mood, visited John, his disappointment gave Madame Michael a strongly poetic and mysterious quality, for the next day she would say to her daughter: "Your friend came to see Steven."
[1897-04-03 09:38:48] Swann's house | I saw that it might be due to the chrysanthemums, or the pale pink of the Louis XV-style chair cushions, or the snow-white silk-satin nightgown, or the copper-red teapot set; they added another layer of decoration to the living room, a decoration just as brilliant and elegant, yet alive, and one that could only last a few days.
[1897-04-03 09:39:03] Swann's house | I thought that what particularly moved Steven was that, unlike the vivid reds or deep browns radiating from the sunset in the November dusk, the color of chrysanthemums did not fade quickly; it lasted longer.
[1897-04-03 09:39:08] Swann's house | I saw Steven enter John's house. I saw Steven see the sunlight dim in the air, then notice it reappear, shifting to the flame-like hues of the chrysanthemums.
[1897-04-03 09:39:18] Swann's house | I saw those chrysanthemums as if they had been brilliantly colored by a master painter, captured from the ever-changing atmosphere and sunlight to adorn the house with their brilliance. I thought of how they urged Steven to set aside his deep melancholy and greedily enjoy the brief pleasures of November (those pleasures flickering in the familiar and mysterious glow of the chrysanthemums beside Steven).
[1897-04-03 09:39:23] Location: Swann's house | I felt sorry, for the conversation that Steven had heard did not enable Steven to reach that brilliance. I thought that the conversation had nothing in common with brilliance.
[1897-04-03 09:39:28] Swann's house | I heard that it was late, but John gently said to Madame Gauthier, "Oh no, it's not late at all. Don't look at the clock, it's not yet time. The clock isn't even accurate. What's so urgent that you need to leave?"
[1897-04-03 09:39:33] Swann's house | I saw her then also hand a small piece of pie to the professor's wife, who had not yet put down her little wallet.
[1897-04-03 09:39:43] Swann's house | "I don't think it's easy to get out of here," Madame Bontemps said to John.
[1897-04-03 09:39:48] Swann's house | I saw that this sentence expressed Madame Goebbels' thoughts, and she exclaimed aloud in surprise. "I heard 'Of course, Steven's little brain is always thinking that way.'"
[1897-04-03 09:39:53] Swann's house | I saw that her words were approved by the gentlemen of the The Union.

Goedard's caution toward John's distinguished friends, as she would say, "on the alert." (She liked to express the simplest things with elegant phrases)
[1897-04-03 09:40:08] Swann's house | "I see, you've missed three consecutive Wednesdays," John said to Madame Gaudier.
[1897-04-03 09:40:13] Swann's house | "I'm telling you, John, how many centuries, how many days have passed since the Steven's last saw each other. Isn't this a confession on Steven's part? But you know," she said in an overly shy and vague manner (even though she was the wife of a doctor, she never spoke directly about rheumatism or kidney pain), "Steven has had quite a few little troubles. Everyone has their own burdens, you know!"
[1897-04-03 09:40:18] Swann's house | I heard that there was a scandal among Steven's servants. Actually, Steven wasn't any more respectful of authority than any other woman, but he had to fire the steward as a warning, since he was also looking for a more lucrative position. His departure almost caused the entire cabinet to resign, even Steven's personal maid refused to stay. The scene was as dramatic as something from Homer. [1897-04-22 21:51:42] Swann's house | I sometimes saw on the velvet bodice a faintly outlined pattern reminiscent of Henry II's embroidery, and on the black satin gown there were slight bulges—either on the sleeves near the shoulders, recalling the "puffed sleeves" of 1830, or on the skirt, evoking the "panniers" of Louis XV.
[1897-04-22 21:51:57] Swann's house | I saw the ro be as something subtle, as if it were a costume. I thought of how it allowed the hazy memories of the past to seep into my present life, thereby giving John a kind of charm belonging to a historical figure or a character from a novel.
[1897-04-22 21:52:02] Location: Swann's house | I thought that if Steven mentioned it to her, she would say. I heard him say, "Steven doesn't play golf like many of his girlfriends do. Steven has no reason to wear a sweater like they do."

[1897-04-23 00:42:52] Swann's house | I saw Steven continue to resist, and this resistance was becoming increasingly effortless for him. [1897-04-23 00:42:57] Location: Swann's house | I thought to myself that when you say you will never see again the woman you love, if this isn't entirely true, then your claim that you would like to see her again isn't entirely truthful either.

[1897-04-23 00:43:07] Swann's house | I thought about how people gradually delay things, not because they don't want to end the unbearable anxiety caused by separation, but because they fear that their passion, which has no way out, will rise again.

[1897-04-23 00:43:17] Location: Swann's house | I thought about how people gradually mix their desires into memories, making them very sweet.
[1897-04-23 00:43:22] Location: Swann's house | I thought that since it was more pleasant than meeting, the meeting was continually postponed, because in a meeting you could no longer make the other person say what you wanted to hear; you had to endure their new coldness and unexpected brutality.

[1897-04-23 00:43:42] Swann's house | I thought that perhaps it was meaningless to win, since soon Steven would be declared cured.
[1897-04-23 00:43:47] Location: Swann's house | I thought about obedience, as a habitual way, which enables certain forces to grow infinitely. On the first night of our falling out with Michael, Steven's power to endure sorrow was very weak, but now it had become immeasurably strong.

[1897-04-23 00:43:57] Swann's house | I thought of how, when the money pouch is about to be filled, people suddenly empty it. When people have become accustomed to a certain treatment, they abruptly stop it before it has had a chance to take effect,

[1897-04-27 05:26:20] Marcel's house | I saw Steven spend his money quickly, even faster than he did when sending flowers to Michael every day.
[1897-04-27 07:40:36] The house of other women | Every time dusk fell, Steven felt a deep sorrow in his heart, unable to stay at home, so he would go to the women Steven didn't love and weep bitterly in their arms.

[1897-04-27 07:40:46] The house of other women | I thought that the day before, Steven had believed that seeing Michael again was the most beautiful thing in the world, but now Steven felt it was far from enough, because when she was not with Steven, she made him feel anxious and afraid.
[1897-04-27 07:40:51] The house of other women | I thought of a woman who, without realizing it, increased her power over Steven by bringing new suffering to the Steven, but at the same time, she also increased Steven's demands on her.
[1897-04-27 07:40:56] The house of other women | I thought about how she made Steven suffer, gradually tightening the encirclement around him and increasing his chains, but at the same time, she also added new constraints on him beyond the chains he had previously considered unbreakable.

[1897-04-27 07:41:06] The house of other women | I saw that Steven first decided not to go to his mother's house anymore. I thought of it, but Steven didn't have the ability.
[1897-04-27 07:41:11] The house of other women | I thought to myself: Steven still wanted to believe that Steven already knew Michael didn't love him, that he could go see her if he wished, or gradually forget her if he didn't.
