[1897-04-27 07:41:41] The house of other women | I thought that if the gloomy and unhappy Michael had reappeared for a minute before Steven, then in how many minutes had Steven been imagining the future, when she would find a way to make peace with him, perhaps even prompting them to get engaged!
[1897-04-27 07:41:46] The house of other women | I thought that, after all, the power of imagination directed toward the future must come from the past. As Steven's irritation at Michael's shrug gradually faded, so too would his memory of her charm, and it was precisely this memory that had made Steven long for her to return to him.
[1897-04-27 07:41:51] The house of other women | I thought that the past was far from dead. Steven still loved the woman he thought he hated. Every time people praised Steven's hairstyle or his complexion, Steven wished she were there.
[1897-04-27 07:41:56] Marcel's house | I saw that many people had offered to welcome Steven, but Steven was very upset and refused them all, which even caused arguments at home.
[1897-04-28 19:28:53] Marcel's house | I knew that Steven had refused to accompany James to a formal dinner where the Bongards and their niece Albertine—almost still a child—would be present.
[1897-04-28 19:29:13] Marcel's house | I thought about how the different periods of Steven's life overlapped like this. You disdainfully refuse to meet something that you love today, which will one day seem unnecessary; and yet, you ignore something you consider unnecessary today, which you will love tomorrow.
[1897-04-28 19:29:18] Marcel's house | I thought that if you agreed to go see it, you might come to love it sooner, and it would shorten your current suffering, of course replacing it with other kinds of pain.
[1897-04-28 19:29:23] Marcel's house | I thought about Steven's suffering, which was constantly changing. Steven was surprised to discover that in his heart, one day it was one feeling, the next day another, and these often had to do with the hopes or fears provoked by Michael.
[1897-04-28 19:29:28] Marcel's house | I thought of the Michael who belonged to Steven. Steven should have warned himself that another Michael, the real Michael, might be entirely different from this one,
[1897-04-28 19:29:33] Marcel's house | I thought she had no trace of the regret that Steven had attributed to her; she probably thought of Steven very little, not only much less than Steven was thinking of her, but also much less than Steven imagined she was thinking of him (Steven imagined Michael's secret meetings, sought to discover her true feelings for him, and fantasized about her missing him and remaining faithful to him).
[1897-04-28 19:29:38] Marcel's house | I thought that during such periods, although sorrow was gradually diminishing, it still remained—sorrow born of day and night longing for someone, and another sorrow born of certain memories, of a harsh word, of a verb in a letter.
[1897-04-28 19:29:43] Marcel's house | I thought of other various kinds of sorrow, which I would descri be in the love story that follows. Here, I only wish to state that the second kind of sorrow was far more cruel than the first.
[1897-04-28 19:29:48] Marcel's house | I thought it was because the concept of the person one loves always remained alive in Steven's heart, shining with the radiance that Steven immediately returned, making it incredibly beautiful. It was filled with the sweet hopes that constantly arose, or at the very least, with a lasting, tranquil sorrow.
[1897-04-28 19:29:53] Marcel's house | I thought (it should also be noted that the image of the person who caused Steven's suffering was in no way proportionate to the increasingly severe, ever-expanding, and difficult-to-cure love-related sorrow it provoked, just as in certain diseases, the cause is disproportionately out of line with the prolonged fever and slow recovery).
[1897-04-28 19:29:58] Marcel's house | I thought that if Steven's conception of the person he loved was often tinged with an optimistic mental glow, then the recollections of specific details, harsh words, and hostile letters (Steven had received only one such letter from Michael) were quite another matter,
[1897-04-28 19:30:03] Marcel's house | I thought that the person Steven loved was precisely living in these scattered fragments, and possessed a stronger power than in Steven's overall conception of her.
[1897-04-28 19:30:08] Marcel's house | I thought it was because the Stevenes, when reading the letters, scanned them quickly, filled with a terrible anxiety over possible misfortunes, rather than gazing at the people they loved with a calm and melancholy sorrow.
[1897-04-28 19:30:13] Marcel's house | I thought of this sorrow as formed in another way, coming from the outside, and penetrating deeply into Steven's soul along the path of the deepest pain.
[1897-04-28 19:30:18] Marcel's house | I thought that Steven's image of his lover was ancient and real, but in fact this image was constantly being renewed by Steven's, while the cruel memories came before this updated image, belonging to another period, a witness to an extremely terrible past (a rare witness).
[1897-04-28 19:30:23] Marcel's house | I thought that the past still existed, but not for the Stevenes, because the Stevenes liked to erase it and replace it with a golden age of beauty, with a paradise of reconciliation. But these memories, these letters, dragged the Stevenes back to reality, struck them in the face, and made them realize how distant from reality was the baseless hope they had waited for day and night.
[1897-04-28 19:30:28] Marcel's house | I thought that this did not mean the reality should never change (though sometimes it indeed does not). In the lives of Stevenes there have been many women, and Stevenes never wished to meet them, and they naturally answered Steven's non-hostile silence with silence.
[1897-04-28 19:30:33] Marcel's house | I thought that since the Marceaux didn't love them, it didn't matter how many years had passed since their separation; this was an exception, but when the Marceaux argued about the effects of separation, they overlooked it, just like people who believe in premonitions ignore the instances when their premonitions turn out to be wrong.
[1897-04-28 19:30:38] Marcel's house | I thought that, however, separation could still have an effect. The desire and interest to meet again would eventually rekindle in the hearts of Stevens.
[1897-04-28 19:30:43] Marcel's house | I thought about it, but it required time, and Steven's demanded time as harshly as the heart demanded change. First, time was something Steven's were extremely unwilling to give, because they were eager to end such a heavy suffering.
[1897-04-28 19:30:48] Marcel's house | I thought that, in the meantime, another heart needed time to complete its transformation, but at the same time, Steven's hearts also used time to change, so that when Steven's original goal was about to be achieved, it was no longer a goal.
[1897-04-28 19:30:53] Marcel's house | I thought that the goal was attainable, and that happiness could ultimately be obtained (when it was no longer happiness), and this thought itself contained only part of the truth.
[1897-04-28 19:30:58] Marcel's house | I thought that happiness descended upon the Stevenes when they became indifferent to it. It was precisely this indifference that made them less demanding, leading them to believe that if it had appeared in the past, it would have satisfied them (in reality, at that time they would have found it incomplete).
[1897-04-28 19:31:03] Marcel's house | I thought that people are not too demanding or discerning about things they don't care about. The attentions shown by those whom Steven no longer loves seem more than sufficient compared to Steven's coldness, but they are far from enough for Steven's love.
[1897-04-28 19:31:08] Marcel's house | I thought that sweet words and secret meetings would make Stevens think only of the pleasure they might bring, and the Stevenes had forgotten that originally they would have desired a whole series of romantic trysts. And it was precisely this greedy desire that made the secret meetings impossible.
[1897-04-28 19:31:13] Marcel's house | I thought, therefore, that when happiness arrived too late for the Stevenes to enjoy it anymore, when the Stevenes no longer loved it, was this late happiness the very happiness they had once longed for so desperately?
[1897-04-28 19:31:18] Marcel's house | I thought that only one person knew the Steven of that time, but that Steven no longer existed, and whenever it reappeared, happiness—whether the same or different—would vanish into thin air.
[1897-04-28 19:31:23] Travel/Recollections | I thought about how, two years later, when Steven set off with David to Riverside, he had already become almost indifferent to Michael.

[1897-04-28 19:31:28] Journey/Recollections | I often thought with melancholy that when Steven was about to receive the charm of a new face, and when Steven wished to experience the beauty of Italian Gothic cathedrals, palaces, and gardens with the help of another girl, the love in Steven's heart, the love for a particular girl, might not be anything real at all.
[1897-04-28 19:31:33] Journey/Recollections | I thought the reason was that although pleasant or painful dreams became entangled, they could, for a certain period, link this love to a particular woman, even making Stevenes believe that this love must have been stirred up by her.
[1897-04-28 19:31:38] Journey/Recollection | I thought that when Steven's [or "the Stevenes"] eventually became aware or unaware of freeing themselves from this obsessive emotion, this love seemed to be spontaneous, arising from within Steven himself and then being given to another woman.
[1897-04-28 19:31:43] Balbec | I thought, however, that this time, the departure for Riverside and the first days Steven spent there, his "doesn't matter" was still intermittent.
[1897-04-28 19:31:48] Balbec | I thought of (Steven's life rarely followed a chronological order; in the days that followed, so many things were inserted that did not follow a chronological order.)
[1897-04-28 19:31:53] Balbec | I thought of Steven often living in a more distant past, a time even farther back than the time when Steven had first fallen in love with Michael or even before that.
[1897-04-28 19:31:58] Balbec | At this thought, the realization that I would never see her again suddenly made Steven suffer as intensely as he had at the time the event occurred.
[1897-04-28 19:32:03] Balbec | I thought that although the Steven who had once loved her had been almost completely replaced by another Steven, the old Steven would sometimes suddenly reappear, and these moments usually came about through some small, insignificant thing rather than anything significant.
[1897-05-01 07:56:15] Balbec Sea Wall | I saw Steven meet a stranger on the seawall, and Steven heard what he said. I heard "the director of the Post Office and his family."
[1897-05-01 07:56:20] Balbec Seawall | I knew (if Steven didn't yet know what this family would mean for Steven's life) I thought Steven would probably find this statement utterly useless; but for Steven, who had already been separated from Michael for a long time, whose body and spirit were worn down, and who was suffering greatly, this statement would cause him intense pain.

text:
[1897-06-28 12:19:23] On the walk | I saw that although he scrutinized strangers—on this brief walk, he cast a couple of menacing and penetrating glances at some utterly insignificant, lowly-born passersby as a test—he never once looked at people he knew. I thought that if we took Steven's judgment into account—that was like a detective carrying out a secret mission, keeping his friend outside the scope of his professional surveillance.
[1897-06-28 12:19:28] On the walk | I saw Steven letting his grandmother, Charles, and him chat away, keeping Peter in the background. I heard "Tell Steven, did Steven not hear? Charles told your uncle that he used to be a member of the Fairhaven family."
[1897-06-28 12:19:33] On the way for a walk | I heard, "Yes, of course, he's Barbe-Belamy de Fairhaven."
[1897-06-28 12:19:38] Walking route | I heard, "There's a castle near Sunrise, whose owner claims to be a descendant of Geneviève de Brabant. Is he related to the family with the name Goulmard?"
[1897-06-28 12:19:43] On the way for a walk | "I heard him say, 'Absolutely right: Uncle Steven, no one is more knowledgeable about heraldry than he is. He would tell you that the 'shout' and 'battle cry' of the Stevenes were first 'Sunrise men,' and later became 'the King of Passa.' " He smiled. "The current owner of this castle is his brother." I thought of not wanting to appear proud of this "shout" that was a privilege, for only almost royal families and leaders of major factions had such a "shout."
[1897-06-28 12:19:48] On the way for a walk | I knew that Charles thus became closely related to the Fairhaven family.
[1897-06-28 12:20:08] On the walk | I know, but for Steven, she had remained for a long time the lady who had given Steven a box of chocolates with a duck on it when he was a child, and at that time, she was more distant from the Fairhaven side than from the Méséglise side. I thought that, in Steven's eyes, I was not as distinguished or socially prominent as the optician in Sunrise.
[1897-06-28 12:20:13] On the way for a walk | I thought that now, she had suddenly increased in value, and in parallel, other items owned by Steven had unexpectedly lost value. Whether it was an increase or a decrease, both were introducing numerous changes, just like Ovid's transformations, into various parts of Steven's childhood and the remnants of his childhood.
[1897-06-28 12:20:18] Walk on the way | I heard, "Is it true that there are all the busts of high-ranking officials from the Fairhaven family in this castle?"
[1897-06-28 12:20:23] Walking path | I saw Peter speaking sarcastically. I heard, "Yes, it's a fine view. Let's talk, don't tell anyone: Steven finds all this utterly dull."
[1897-06-28 12:20:28] On the walk | "I heard him say, 'But there's more interesting things at Fairhaven! That's the portrait of Steven's aunt by Gérard, it's very moving. As beautiful as Whistler's or Velázquez's works,' Peter added again." I thought of him, caught up in his Protestant fervor, and how he could not always accurately grasp the great measure.
[1897-06-28 12:20:33] On the way for a walk | "I heard that there's also a touching painting by Gustave Moreau. Steven's aunt is your friend, the niece of Charles, who was raised by this lady, and she married her cousin, who is also the nephew of Madame de Charles, the current Baron Samuel."
[1897-06-28 12:20:38] Walking route | I heard, "Then what is your uncle?"
[1897-06-28 12:20:43] Walk on the way | "I heard that his noble title was Monsieur de Charlus. According to the rules, when Steven's maternal uncle Barbe-Durand's father died, Steven's uncle Barbe-Durand should have inherited the title of Prince de Montmorency. Before he became Samuel of Fairhaven, his older brother had that title. In this family, changing names and identities was as easy as changing a shirt."
[1897-06-28 12:20:48] Walking path | I heard him say, "But Uncle Steven has some peculiar ideas about all these things. He thinks titles like Samuel in Italy and those Spanish honorifics are overused. Although he could choose from a half-dozen princely titles, he kept the title of Monsieur de Charlus as an act of protest, which on the surface seemed very modest, but actually contained a great deal of pride."
[1897-06-28 12:20:53] Walking route | I heard him say, "Nowadays everyone is a prince, but there has to be something to make you different. When Steven wants to go traveling under an assumed name, Steven will surely take on a princely title."
[1897-06-28 12:20:58] Walking route | I heard him say, "According to his account, there is no older title than that of M. de Charlus. The Baron de Montmorency claims to be the oldest baron in France, but that's not true, for at that time they were only barons of their fiefdom, Île-de-France."
[1897-06-28 12:21:03] Walking route | I saw Peter smile slightly and say. "I heard that 'to prove to you that M. de Charlus came before the Baron de Montmorency, Steven's uncle would gladly explain it to you for hours on end. Although he is very shrewd and capable, he still finds this a very lively topic of conversation. [1897-06-30 17:19:59] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw later that when the Stevenes were alone together talking about him, they said he must have been deeply influenced by a woman, either his Robert or, later on, his daughter, if he had any children.
[1897-06-30 17:20:04] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I thought of Steven thinking about Peter's mistress, and in Steven's eyes, she had a great influence on him. Steven thought to himself, "A mistress." This influence enabled Steven to realize how delicate a man's emotions could become when he lived with women!
[1897-06-30 17:20:09] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard that 'this Lady de Sévigné, once she's with her daughter, may very well have nothing to say to her!' " Charles replied.
[1897-06-30 17:20:14] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I heard her say, "There's definitely something to talk about, even if it's those trivial things she calls 'things only you and Steven would notice.' And anyway, Madame de Sévigné is often by her daughter's side."
[1897-06-30 17:20:19] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw M. de Charlus add, in a melancholy tone. I heard that La Bruyère told Steven, "That's enough: it's all the same whether you talk to the people you love or say nothing at all." He was right, that's the only happiness.
[1897-06-30 17:20:24] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard him say, 'This happiness is a pity, for life is arranged so poorly that it's hard to savor such happiness. In general, Madame de Sévigné was no more deserving of pity than anyone else. Most of her life was spent with the people she loved.'"
[1897-06-30 17:20:29] Madame Verdurin's drawing room | I heard, "You forgot, we're not talking about love, but about her daughter."
[1897-06-30 17:20:34] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw M. de Charlus speak on with an authoritative, unchallengeable, almost decisive tone. I heard, "But what is important in life is not the people that Stevenes love, but the Stevenes who are in love."
[1897-06-30 17:20:39] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I heard that the feelings of Madame de Sévigné for her daughter were less like the vulgar relations between young Monsieur de Sévigné and his mistresses, and more like the passion described by Racine in Andromaque or Phèdre. Similarly, loving God because of love for this mysticism.
[1897-06-30 17:20:44] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I heard someone say, "The boundaries that Steven and his kind draw around love are too narrow, and the only reason is that Stevenes are too ignorant of life."
[1897-06-30 17:20:49] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw Peter ask his uncle, his tone slightly contemptuous. "I heard, 'Do you like Andromaque and Hypermnestra very much?'"
[1897-06-30 17:20:54] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard that the truth contained in a tragedy by Racine is greater than all of Monsieur Unknown_Victor Hugo's comedies," De Charlus replied.
[1897-06-30 17:20:59] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw Peter lean over and whisper to Steven. I heard, "This upper class, whatever the case may be, is really terrifying! To prefer Racine to Hugo, whatever the case may be, is simply too much!"
[1897-06-30 17:21:04] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I thought about what his uncle had said, and it truly troubled him. Yet, by uttering "whatever the case may be" and "excessive," he found a sense of pleasure, which was a comfort to him.
[1897-06-30 17:21:09] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I knew that M. de Charlus's sentimental remarks about parting and sorrow made Steven's grandmother later tell Steven that the nephew from Charles understood certain works far better than his aunt. I thought that something in this nephew's mind made him far superior to most of the people in the nobleman's club.
[1897-06-30 17:21:14] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | From these impressions, he not only revealed a delicate sensitivity, but his voice was also different—similar to certain contraltos whose middle register had not been sufficiently trained, so that when he sang, it seemed like a duet between a young man and a woman.
[1897-06-30 17:21:19] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw that when he expressed these delicate thoughts, his voice rested on high notes, revealing an unexpected tenderness, as if it contained the harmonious chorus of his fiancée and sisters, expressing their tenderness. I thought that if, in his voice, there seemed to be a group of young girls sheltered within it, M. de Charlus would probably feel very upset.
[1897-06-30 17:21:24] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw that when he was talking, people often heard their sharp and cheerful laughter. I saw these boarding school girls or flirtatious young women attacking the men beside them with witty and humorous words, pouting their lips.
[1897-06-30 17:21:29] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I heard that "Israël is the surname of these people, but Steven always felt it was a term for classification, a racial category, rather than a proper name." I know he said there was a house that had once belonged to his family, where Marie-Antoinette had lived, and the garden had been designed by Le Nôtre. Now the house belonged to the wealthy Israël family, who had bought it.
[1897-06-30 17:21:34] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw him shouting. I heard, "I don't know why, but may be people like them don't have surnames, and are only referred to by the collective they belong to. That's fine! But it was once the Fairhaven' house, and now it belongs to the Israel family!!!"
[1897-06-30 17:21:39] Madame Verdurin's drawing room | I heard someone say, "It makes you think of a room in the Château de Blois. The tour guide who shows people around the castle arrives there and says to Steven, 'Mary Stuart used to pray here, and now Steven is putting brooms and such things here.'"
[1897-06-30 17:21:44] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard that 'naturally, Steven doesn't want to know anything about this disgraceful house and Clara de Simeon, Steven's aunt who ran away from her husband. But Steven still keeps the photos of the house when it was still intact, and also the photo of the princess, whose big eyes still only saw Steven's cousin then.'"
[1897-06-30 17:21:49] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw him say to Steven's grandmother. I heard him say, "When a photograph is no longer a copy of a real object, but shows things that no longer exist, it gains a certain authority. Since you're interested in such architecture, Steven can give you one."
[1897-06-30 17:21:54] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw that at this moment, he realized the bright floral edging of his embroidered handkerchief had slipped out of his pocket. He quickly put the handkerchief back into his pocket. I thought of the expression of terror as resembling that of a woman who was overly shy but by no means innocent, concealing certain of her charms, and because she was too concerned with propriety, she felt it indecent to reveal them.
[1897-06-30 17:21:59] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard him continue, 'You can imagine, these people first of all destroyed Renoult's garden, which was just as criminal as tearing up a Poussin painting! For that alone, these Israel family members should be put in prison.'"
[1897-06-30 17:22:04] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw him pause for a moment, then he added with a smile. "I heard him say, 'Of course there are many things they should be in prison for, that's true! Anyway, just imagine what effect a British-style garden in front of these buildings would have!'"
[1897-06-30 17:22:09] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard Charles say, 'But the house is of the same style as the Petit Trianon,' 'Marie Antoinette also had an English garden built at the Petit Trianon, wasn't there!'"
[1897-06-30 17:22:14] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard 'That English garden always spoils the beauty of Gabriel's façade!' De Charlus replied, 'Clearly, now to tear down that rustic cottage would be almost a barbaric crime!'"
[1897-06-30 17:22:19] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | "I heard, 'But no matter what the modern spirit is, a whimsical idea of Mrs. Israël could never carry the same weight as the memory of the queen, and Steven always remained doubtful about it.'"
[1897-07-01 04:42:47] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | During this time, David had already signaled to Steven to go upstairs to bed, although Peter kept insisting he stay. I thought of Peter's hint to M. de Charlus that Steven often felt sad before going to bed at night, and his uncle must have found this rather unmanly, which would have surely embarrassed Steven!
[1897-07-01 04:42:57] The drawing room of Madame Verdurin | I saw Steven linger a while longer, and then he left.

text:
[1897-07-01 12:50:28] Marcel's Room | I saw that after a while, Steven heard someone knocking at the door. Steven asked who it was. What surprised Steven was that the voice he heard was that of M. de Charlus.
[1897-07-01 12:50:33] Marcel's Room | I saw him say it dryly. "I heard, 'It's Charlus. Sir, may Steven come in?'"
[1897-07-01 12:50:38] Marcel's Room | I saw him come in, and even after closing the door, he continued speaking in the same dry manner. I heard, "Steven's nephew just said that you were feeling a bit restless before going to sleep, and also that you greatly admire Christopher's works. Steven has a book by Christopher in his trunk, which you may not have read, and so he's bringing it over to help you pass the time during this unpleasant period."
[1897-07-01 12:50:43] Marcel's Room | I saw Steven very excitedly thanking Monsieur de Charlus. I thought to myself and said to him that, on the contrary, Steven was afraid that Peter would say that Steven felt unwell when night came, making Steven appear more foolish and ridiculous in Peter's eyes than he actually was.
[1897-07-01 12:50:48] Marcel's Room | I saw him answer, his tone somewhat gentler. "I heard, 'It's not true. You probably have no personal talents, Steven knows nothing about it. But talented people are so rare! Still, for a time at least, you have youth, which is always an extremely tempting thing."
[1897-07-01 12:50:53] Marcel's Room | "I heard him say, 'Besides, the greatest folly is to think that any emotion you yourself haven't felt is either ridiculous or deserving of condemnation. Steven likes the night, yet you tell Steven that you're afraid of the night. Steven likes the fragrance of roses, yet Steven has a friend whose body temperature rises at the scent of roses. Do you really think Steven therefore considers him less than Steven?"
[1897-07-01 12:50:58] Marcel's Room | "I heard 'Steven tries to understand everything, Steven avoids blaming anything. In short, don't complain too much. Steven isn't saying that feeling of melancholy isn't uncomfortable; Steven knows that people can be very painful about certain things, and others don't understand.'"
[1897-07-01 12:51:03] Marcel's Room | I heard him say, "But at least you've directed your love toward your David, and you see her often. And it's a tenderness that has been promised by someone else—Steven means a tenderness that is returned. There are many people who haven't even reached that point yet!"
[1897-07-02 00:40:42] Marcel's Room | I saw him pacing back and forth in the room, examining this object, lifting up that one. I thought of Steven, and it seemed he had something to announce to Steven, but he couldn't find the right words.
[1897-07-02 00:40:47] Marcel's Room | I saw he had added a line, so I rang the bell. I heard, "Steven has another book by Christopher here; Steven had someone bring it to you."
[1897-07-02 00:40:52] Marcel's Room | I saw that after a while, a young waiter came.
[1897-07-02 00:40:57] Marcel's Room | I saw M. de Charlus speaking with pride. I heard, "Go get your head waiter and bring him to Steven! Only he knows how to handle things properly."
[1897-07-02 00:41:02] Marcel's Room | I saw the waiter ask. I heard, "Sir, do you mean Monsieur Émer?"
[1897-07-02 00:41:07] Marcel's Room | I heard, "Steven doesn't know his name. Oh yes, Steven remembers, Steven heard people call him Hame. Go quickly, Steven has an urgent matter."
[1897-07-02 00:41:12] Marcel's Room | I saw the waiter answer. I heard, "He'll be here right away, sir. Steven just saw him downstairs." I thought of pretending to be well-informed.
[1897-07-02 00:41:17] Marcel's Room | I saw that after a while, the waiter returned. I heard, "Sir, Monsieur Hémé is already in bed. Steven can take care of it for you."
[1897-07-02 00:41:22] Marcel's Room | I heard, "No, no, you just have to wake him up."
[1897-07-02 00:41:27] Marcel's Room | I heard, "Sir, Steven can't, he's not staying here tonight."
[1897-07-02 00:41:32] Marcel's Room | I heard, "Well, all right, go ahead and leave!"
[1897-07-02 00:41:37] Marcel's Room | I said when the servant had left. I heard, "Sir, you're too kind, Christopher's book, one is enough for Steven."
[1897-07-02 00:41:42] Marcel's Room | I saw M. de Charlus still pacing back and forth. I heard, "Yes, it seems that's the case."
[1897-07-02 00:41:47] Marcel's Room | I watched like that for a few minutes. Then he hesitated again, changing his mind several more times.
[1897-07-02 00:41:52] Marcel's Room | When I finally saw it, he turned on the spot, his voice once again harsh and grating as he said to Steven, "Sir, good night!" and then left.
[1897-07-02 00:41:57] Beach | I saw that in the morning, at the beach, Steven was about to go for a swim when M. de Charlus came up to him and reminded Steven that he should go find his grandmother as soon as he got out of the water, since she was waiting for him. I knew that that evening, Steven had expressed to him a variety of noble sentiments. The next day, he was leaving.
[1897-07-02 00:42:02] Beach | What I saw was something unexpected for Steven: he grabbed Steven's neck and spoke to him in a vulgar, careless, and mocking tone. I heard, "You don't really care about your old David, do you, you little rascal?"
[1897-07-02 00:42:07] Beach | I heard, "Sir, what did you say, Steven loves her very much!"
[1897-07-02 00:42:12] Beach | I saw him take a step forward and coldly say to Steven. I heard him say, "Sir, you are still young, and you should make the most of this youth by learning two things: first, you must avoid expressing too natural a feeling, so as not to let your true meaning be understood. Second, do not answer someone's words with arrogance before you understand what they really mean."
[1897-07-02 00:42:17] Beach | "I heard, 'If you had been as careful before, you wouldn't have looked like a deaf man babbling nonsense, and you wouldn't have done anything else ridiculous besides embroidering an anchor on your swimsuit.'"
[1897-07-02 00:42:22] Beach | "I heard, 'Steven has lent you a book by Christopher. Steven needs it back now. Please have that funny-named, unsuitable head waiter come over in an hour to return the book to Steven. Steven thinks, he can't possibly still be sleeping at this hour!"
[1897-07-02 00:42:27] Beach | I heard, "You made Steven feel that it was too early last night to talk about youth's allure; perhaps if Steven had pointed out the foolishness, inconsistency, and insensitivity of young people, he might have been of better help to you."
[1897-07-02 00:42:32] Beach | I heard, "Sir, Steven hopes this little cold bath will be better for you than your sea bath. But don't stand here motionless, you'll catch a chill. Goodbye, sir."
[1897-07-02 00:42:37] Hotel | I saw that after some time, Steven received a book that had been sent to him, the very same book he had lent to Steven and then had returned to him. I thought he certainly regretted those words.
[1897-07-02 00:42:42] Hotel | I saw it, but it wasn't Étienne who returned the book—he happened to be "out," and it was the elevator operator who returned it. I saw the book was a high-quality leather-bound edition, with another piece of leather inlaid on the cover, slightly raised and shaped like a forget-me-not flower.
[1897-07-02 00:42:47] The Bloch's house | As soon as M. de Charlus left, Peter and Steven were finally able to go to Richard's for dinner. I thought about this small evening gathering, and Steven understood that the stories which his companions found so amusing were actually Richard's stories; the "completely incomprehensible" person was indeed one of his friends, whom he always described in that way.
[1897-07-02 00:42:52] The Bloch's house | I thought of some people who were admired in childhood, such as James, who was wiser than other family members, or a teacher who revealed the mysteries to Steven and his friends, a person who himself benefited from those mysteries, or a companion who performed better academically than Steven (like Richard, who did better than Steven).
[1897-07-02 00:42:57] The Bloch's house | When I thought of how Steven and others liked Musset's "The Hope of God," he already looked down on the Musset who had written "The Hope of God." And when Steven and others liked the old Leconte or Claudel, he was only enchanted by the poetic lines "At Saint-Briac, like Zoukka, you are so, so at ease..."
[1897-07-02 00:43:02] The Bloch's house | I thought to add: Padua is a beautiful place, a great doctor of law...
[1897-07-02 00:43:07] The Bloch's house | I thought of the various "Night Poems" and remembered only these lines: in Havre, facing the Atlantic; in Oakdale, the terrible Lido Hotel; pale Adriatic girl; dying on the grass of a tomb.
[1897-07-02 00:43:12] The Bloch's house | I thought about how, when people truly trust and admire someone, they collect and quote certain phrases with great admiration, even though these phrases are not as good as what people themselves could create with their own talent. Yet, for the latter, people are harshly unwilling to accept them.
[1897-07-02 00:43:17] The Bloch's house | I thought of a writer in a novel who, by the excuse of reality, used certain "words," certain characters, which in the living whole became heavy, lifeless weights, the mediocre parts—this was actually how it was.
[1897-07-02 00:43:22] The Bloch's house | I thought of the portraits in Saint-Simon's work, which he himself did not appreciate but were remarkably vivid; and the charming brushstrokes that he, a man of great intelligence, found so fascinating, seemed rather ordinary or even incomprehensible to others.
[1897-07-02 00:43:27] The Bloch's house | I thought that this was because, in the state of "observation," people are far below their level when they are creating.
[1897-07-02 00:43:32] The Bloch's house | I saw that, so Steven's friend Richard was entirely cast in the same mold as his father, who was forty years older than his son. He told some incomprehensible anecdotes and burst into loud laughter.
[1897-07-02 00:43:42] The Bloch family's home | I saw the real, exposed Richard was just like that; he laughed out loud and repeated the last sentence two or three times so the audience could fully savor the flavor of the story.

[1897-07-02 00:43:52] The Bloch's house | I saw his son laughing out loud at the same time, always showing respect for James's stories at the dinner table.
[1897-07-02 00:43:57] The Bloch's house | I saw it like that, and Richard said the most wise thing, showing the wealth he had acquired from his own home.
[1897-07-02 00:44:07] The Bloch's house | I saw that he then repeated a few witty remarks for the thirtieth time. I knew this kind of witty remark was something Richard only brought out on very special occasions (along with his tailcoat), that is, when he introduced someone to show off: his teacher, a "classmate" who had won every prize, or, like that evening, Peter and Steven...
[1897-07-02 00:44:12] The Bloch family's home | I heard him say, "A remarkable military critic who presented various pieces of evidence, and for some undeniable reason, elaborated at length on the inevitability of Japan's defeat and Russia's victory in the Russo-Japanese War."
[1897-07-02 00:44:17] The Bloch's house | I heard, or rather, I said: "This man is remarkable. He is considered a great financier in politics, and a great politician in finance."
[1897-07-02 00:44:37] The Bloch House | I knew that this sort of joke could also be replaced with stories about Baron Rothschild and Sergeant Ruffus Israel. By bringing these characters onto the stage in an ambiguous way, it suggested that Mr. Richard actually knew these people personally.
[1897-07-02 00:44:42] The Bloch family's home | I thought that Steven had also been deceived. From the way Richard spoke about Christopher, Steven must have believed that Christopher was an old friend of his.
[1897-07-02 00:44:47] The Bloch's house | I thought, but in reality, all the celebrities that Richard "didn't know" were people he had seen from afar in the theater or on the street. Moreover, he imagined that his face, name, and character were not unfamiliar to them; when they saw him, they often had to restrain themselves from the faint desire to greet him.
[1897-07-02 00:44:52] The Bloch family's home | I thought about people in high society, who, because they knew talented and first-rate individuals, would entertain them to dinner, yet that did not mean they understood them any better.
[1897-07-02 00:44:57] The Bloch's house | I thought that if you spent just a few days in the upper class, the stupidity of its residents would make you long to live among the unremarkable people who are unknown to one another, and you would imagine them to be full of wisdom. Steven immediately understood this when he spoke about Christopher.
[1897-07-02 00:45:07] The Bloch's house | I saw that Richard was well-known at home, but he wasn't the only one. Steven's companions were even more so in front of his sister.
[1897-07-02 00:45:12] The Bloch's house | I saw him bury his head in the dish, asking them questions in a muffled tone, repeatedly, until they were laughing so hard they cried. I thought that they also used the same language as the brothers, speaking it fluently, as if it were truly necessary and the only language capable of being used by intelligent people.
[1897-07-02 00:45:17] The Bloch's house | When I saw the Stevenes arriving, my elder sister said to one of her sisters. I heard, "Hurry and report to James and the respected Robert, being careful with Steven."
[1897-07-02 00:45:22] The Bloch House | "I heard 'bitches,' Richard said to them, 'Steven is here to introduce you to Sir Peter, who carries a sharp spear and has come from East Cailly to spend a few days in the house with stone walls polished smooth and decorated with running horses."
[1897-07-02 00:45:27] The Bloch's house | I heard, "Hey, pull your fancy sleeveless dresses tighter. Oh, what's this affected fellow here? Anyway, it's not James!"
[1897-07-02 00:45:37] The Bloch's house | I saw the ladies of the Richard family burst into laughter, laughing so hard they were all doubled over.
[1897-07-02 00:45:42] The Bloch's house | I saw Steven say to his brother. I heard him recommend that Steven read Christopher's books, how much pleasure it gave Steven! Steven really loved Christopher's books.
[1897-07-02 00:45:47] The Bloch's house | I knew that Richard had only seen Christopher from a distance, and that his knowledge of Christopher's life was based on secondhand gossip. It seemed he had also come to know Christopher's writings through superficial literary criticism.
[1897-07-02 00:45:52] The Bloch family's home | I thought of the world he lived in, a world of "almost," where greetings were offered in emptiness and judgments were made in falsehood. In this circle, inaccuracy and incompetence did not diminish one's confidence; on the contrary, they only increased it.
[1897-07-02 00:45:57] The Bloch's house | I thought that it was a miracle of self-esteem, that only few people had the privilege of being well-connected and knowledgeable, so those who lacked both could still consider themselves important. Because from the perspective of the social ladder, people who occupied a certain position always felt that their position was the best.
[1897-07-02 00:46:02] The Bloch's house | I thought about how one could name the greatest people by their names, slander them even though one had never met them, judge them without understanding them, look down on them, considering them inferior, unfortunate, and pitiable.
[1897-07-02 00:46:07] The Bloch's house | I realized that when jealousy expresses itself through contemptuous words, one must understand "Steven wouldn't want to know him!" as "Steven couldn't be bothered to meet him" in a rational sense. But the emotional meaning was indeed "Steven wouldn't want to know him!"
[1897-07-02 00:46:12] The Bloch's house | I thought about how Steven's centralism made everyone see themselves as kings, causing them to look down on the world beneath them. Mr. Richard granted himself a luxurious pleasure: to be an unfeeling king.
[1897-07-02 08:00:00] The Bloch's house | Every morning, when I saw him drinking his cocoa, I would read an article beneath the name Christopher on the freshly opened newspaper. I would then give him a brief, contemptuous verdict, pronouncing my judgment with the comfortable pleasure of each sip of the hot drink, repeating the same sentence each time. I heard, "This Christopher's stuff is absolutely unreadable! That scoundrel really makes me sick! We can't subscri be to this paper anymore! This is really a scam! What a piece of trash he writes!"
[1897-07-03 00:15:35] The Bloch's house | I saw him speaking as he ate a slice of buttered bread.
[1897-07-03 00:15:45] The Bloch's house | I thought of Richard's kind of illusory self-awareness, which extended far beyond his own circle of feelings. First of all, his children regarded him as an extraordinary person.
[1897-07-03 00:15:50] The Bloch family's home | I thought that for a filial son, his father was always the best father, even beyond all the objective reasons to admire him. And for Mr. Richard, these objective reasons were certainly not lacking; he was educated, perceptive, and very affectionate toward his wife and children.
[1897-07-03 00:15:55] The Bloch family's home | I thought about how, among close family members, people found him very pleasant to be with, because in "high society," people judged others according to utterly absurd standards and fixed, yet mistaken, rules.
[1897-07-03 00:16:00] The Bloch House | I thought that, in this class where there was no nobility and yet it affected such an important air, people made up for the noble's pretensions with an even more bewildering kind of difference.
[1897-07-03 00:16:05] The Bloch's house | I knew that in his family, and even to distant relatives, it was said that Richard's mustache and the upper part of his nose resembled those of a certain nobleman, so people called Richard "the fake Omar Samuel."
[1897-07-03 00:16:25] The Bloch's house | I found this resemblance to be the most elusive, but one could say it was rather a title. People kept saying, "Richard? Which one? Omar Samuel?" just as they would say, "Princess Murat? Which one? The queen of Naples?"
[1897-07-03 00:16:30] The Bloch family's home | I would see certain days when he hired a Victoria-style open carriage with two horses from the livery stable and drove through the Bois de Boulogne. He lay listlessly in the carriage, his two fingers pressed against his temples, and the other two supporting his chin.

[1897-07-03 00:16:40] The Bloch's house | I knew that people who didn't know him might think he was a pretentious fellow, but the family was certain that when it came to "handsomeness," Uncle Solomon could easily outshine Garamond de Grudel. I thought of him as one of those people: because they had once dined at a restaurant on the Boulevard des Capucines in Willowbrook with the editor of L'Éclair, the newspaper's "Society Notes" section would refer to them as "faces familiar to Willowbrookians" when they died.
[1897-07-03 00:16:45] The Bloch's house | I saw Mr. Richard tell Peter and Steven that Christopher knew perfectly well why he—Mr. Richard—didn't greet Christopher, so that whenever Christopher saw him from a distance in the theater or the club, he would always avoid looking at him.
[1897-07-03 00:16:55] The Bloch's house | I saw Peter's face flushed red. I thought that perhaps because he considered the club was probably not the The Union where James had once been president. On the other hand, it might be a relatively closed circle, since Mr. Richard said that nowadays they wouldn't even receive Christopher if he tried to go there.
[1897-07-03 00:17:00] The Bloch's house | I saw Peter, full of respectful apprehension, anxiously asking whether the club was the one on King's Street. I thought that the Peter family considered that place to be "inferior," and he knew that certain Jews were received there.
[1897-07-03 00:17:05] The Bloch's house | I saw Mr. Richard answer, with an air of indifference, pride, and shame. "I heard, 'No, it's a small circle, but much more pleasant. It's called the Ganash Club. The people there are quite critical of the galleries.'"
[1897-07-03 00:17:10] The Bloch family's home | "I heard that the club's president isn't Sir Ruffus Israel?" Richard asked James. I thought of it as a way to give him an opportunity to tell a decent lie, and he had not expected that this financier did not have the same authority in Peter's eyes as he did in his own family's.

[1897-07-08 02:02:13] Hotel | I know that now, she has become the source of his constant suffering, because she hates him, and she is tormenting him.

[1897-07-10 09:16:38] Hotel | I thought to myself whether Steven might have misjudged his grandmother, whether he had perhaps overestimated her, whether she was not as indifferent as he had always believed to matters concerning her own appearance, whether she too might have some coquetry, something utterly alien to what he had always thought of her.
[1897-07-10 09:16:43] Hotel | I thought about taking a photograph, especially because Steven's grandmother seemed so satisfied with it, which caused Steven to feel annoyed.

[1897-07-11 15:34:25] Hotel | I thought of Steven, the ideal figure in every way, and of Robert and David, who often laughed at Françoise's allergies, and Steven was certain that he wasn't mocking her by doing so.

[1897-07-12 21:52:07] Hotel | I saw that, although Steven had to look at David's incredibly beautiful hat, at least Steven had caused the delighted expression to fade from her face.

[1897-07-13 14:59:50] Hotel | I knew Steven was in a bad mood, mainly because that week David seemed to be avoiding him.
[1897-07-13 14:59:55] Hotel | I knew that whether by day or by night, Steven never had even a moment alone with her.

[1897-07-14 04:10:04] Hotel | I saw that either she was shutting herself in with Françoise for a long whispered conversation, not allowing Steven to disturb them.
[1897-07-14 06:23:45] Hotel room | I thought about the evening spent with Peter outside, and on the way back, Steven was already imagining the moment when he would see his David again and kiss her.
[1897-07-14 06:23:50] Hotel room | I saw Steven waiting, expecting her to tap lightly on the wall next door to call him over and say goodnight. But Steven's efforts were in vain; he heard not a single sound.
[1897-07-14 06:24:00] Hotel room | I saw Steven go to bed at last. I felt a little resentful of her, for she had carelessly taken away from Steven the happiness he valued so much, and this indifference was a recent development.
[1897-07-14 06:24:05] Hotel Room | I saw Steven listening intently to the sounds coming from the wall. The wall remained silent, and Steven fell asleep with tears in his eyes. I thought of Steven still having his heart race as it did in childhood.

[1897-07-14 06:24:15] Near the beach | I saw Steven seeing some young women who were getting down from the carriage; some entered the ballroom of the amusement hall, and others went into the cold drink shop. I thought that from a distance, they were intoxicating.
[1897-07-14 06:24:20] Near the beach | I thought of Steven, who was in that stage of youth when he had not yet fallen for a specific person, and his heart was still empty.

[1897-07-14 06:24:25] Near the beach | I thought that, at such a stage, just like a man in love longs for and seeks the woman he is devoted to, young people long for, seek, and see beauties everywhere.
[1897-07-14 06:24:30] Near the beach | I thought that as long as there was a single real detail—a woman seen from afar, or just the back of a woman, even if only a little of her appearance could be made out—it would be enough for Steven and his kind to imagine what beauty lay before them. Steven would imagine he had recognized her, his heart would beat wildly, and his steps would quicken.
[1897-07-14 06:24:35] Near the beach | I thought that once the woman disappeared, the Stevenes would always doubt whether she was really her; only when they caught up with her would they realize they had been completely wrong.
[1897-07-14 06:24:40] Near the beach | I thought of saying something, but Steven's growing discomfort made him even more susceptible to the temptation of exaggerating the simplest pleasures, since Steven had little access to women.
[1897-07-14 06:24:45] Near the beach | I thought of the refined and charming girls, and because Steven could not approach them anywhere, they seemed to be everywhere.
[1897-07-14 06:24:50] Near the beach | I thought that if it were at the beach, it would be because Steven was too weak. If it were at the fairground or a candy store, it would be because Steven was too shy.
[1897-07-14 06:24:55] Near the beach | I thought, but if Steven were to die soon, Steven would really like to know how the most beautiful girl life could offer was actually made in real life.
[1897-07-14 06:25:00] Near the beach | I thought that, in any case, it would be someone other than Steven, or perhaps no one at all would be able to enjoy this provision (in fact, Steven was unaware that, at the very root of his curiosity, there lay a desire for possession).
[1897-07-14 06:25:05] In front of the big hotel | I saw that Steven was alone. Steven had no choice but to stand motionless at the entrance of the big hotel, waiting for the moment when he would meet his grandmother. I thought that if Peter were with Steven, may be Steven would dare to enter the ballroom.
[1897-07-14 15:20:48] Dike | I saw that at that moment, almost at the end of the dike, Steven saw five or six little girls coming forward. I saw them leaving a strange, moving imprint on the embankment.
[1897-07-14 15:20:58] Dike | I thought that, in both appearance and behavior, they were different from all the girls one usually saw in Riverside.
[1897-07-14 16:27:56] Beach | I saw a group of gulls, coming from nowhere, strolling leisurely along the beach, while those who arrived late flew here and there, chasing the other gulls.
[1897-07-14 16:28:06] Beach | I saw birds flying back and forth, their destinations as unclear as those of the people bathing in the sea. I thought that the birds seemed not to see the people bathing in the sea, and for their bird minds, this destination was clearly defined.
[1897-07-14 16:28:11] Beach | I thought that only the seagulls were probably used to these birds.
[1897-07-14 18:08:38] The Embankment | I saw one of the unfamiliar girls pushing her bicycle, and two others holding golf "club" shirts in their hands.
[1897-07-14 18:08:48] Dike | I saw that their short outfits were completely different from those of the other girls in Riverside. I thought that among other girls there were indeed a few who took part in sports, but they did not therefore adopt special attire.
[1897-07-14 18:08:53] Dike | I saw that this was precisely the moment when all the gentlemen and ladies came to the embankment for a stroll, exposed to the merciless fire of hand-held long-handled spectacles that scrutinized them intently. [1897-07-14 18:08:58] Dike | I saw the chief judge's wife proudly seated in the middle of the formidable row of chairs in front of the music pavilion. [1897-07-14 18:09:03] Dike | I saw all these people walking along the seawall, pretending not to see anything in order to convince others that they didn't care about these girls at all, when in reality they were secretly watching them, making sure not to meet their eyes. I thought that the sea wall seemed to wobble like the deck of a ship (because they don't lift one leg while swaying their arms, turning their eyes, leveling their shoulders, and moving in the opposite direction to balance the movement they had just made on the other side, and to make their face flush with blood).
[1897-07-14 18:09:08] The Embankment | I saw people walking beside them or coming from the opposite direction, but instead of avoiding them, they bumped into them and kept chasing after them. I thought that because they were both the objects of each other's secret attention, even though both masked this attention with the same contempt.
[1897-07-14 18:09:13] Dike | I thought about the love of crowds--and thus also the fear of crowds--which is one of the strongest motives in every person's heart. Either to try desperately to be liked by others, or to astonish them, or to show them how much one despises them.
[1897-07-14 18:09:18] Dike | I thought about how, in the mind of a recluse, absolute imprisonment—even until the end of life—often stems from an abnormal fascination with people. [1897-07-14 18:09:23] Dike | I saw that among these people, a few were following some line of thought, but their hurried gestures and distracted eyes did not harmonize with the thoughtful, swaying steps of their neighbors, thus revealing their inner preoccupations.
[1897-07-14 18:09:33] Dike | I saw the few girls that Steven had seen from afar, and among all these people, they moved forward directly, their bodies completely relaxed. [1897-07-14 18:09:38] The Embankment | I thought of the waltz dancers like that, and it was very impressive. Although each of them was a type, different from others, none of these women failed to be beautiful.
[1897-07-14 18:09:43] Dike | I thought, but honestly, Steven had only seen them for a short while, and hadn't even dared to look at them closely; Steven had not yet grasped the personality of any one of them.
[1897-07-14 18:09:48] Dike | I saw one exception: her straight nose, brown skin stood out in sharp contrast to others, resembling the complexion of the Arab-looking figure among the Three Kings who came to worship the newborn Jesus in a Renaissance painting.
[1897-07-14 18:10:03] Dike | I saw how Steven knew them—one simply through those rather stiff, stubborn, yet smiling eyes; the other simply through her pink cheeks. I thought of the pinkish hue with a coppery tint, which inevitably brought to mind hydrangeas.

As the musical phrases passed by, Steven could not separate them, could not recognize each one. As soon as he recognized them, he immediately forgot them. In accordance with the order in which this whole proceeded).
[1897-07-14 18:10:13] Dike | I saw Steven see a white oval, and then black eyes and green eyes appeared in succession. [1897-07-14 18:10:18] Dike | I saw, through this group of women, a harmonious fluidity spreading out, a continuous transfer of liquid beauty, collective beauty, and dynamic beauty. text:
[1897-07-14 18:10:28] The Embankment | I thought that these girls, whose behavior revealed a bold, frivolous, and cruel nature, were extremely sensitive to anything ridiculous or ugly, and could not be attracted by anything noble or intelligent; thus, naturally, they gathered among their own peers.
[1897-07-14 18:10:33] Dike | I thought of all the girl companions who revealed a contemplative or sensitive nature through their shyness, restraint, awkwardness, and the type of people they probably called "annoying," and how they felt repelled by and ignored them.
[1897-07-14 18:10:38] The Embankment | I thought of something else—refined, flexible, and graceful, a kind of mixture that would draw them toward other people, with whom they would form friendships. The seductive directness of their nature and the promise of happy times spent with them could only be expressed in this single way.
[1897-07-14 18:10:43] Dike | I thought about what class they belonged to, and Steven could not accurately determine it. Perhaps this class was at a certain stage of development, or perhaps it was due to wealth and leisure, or to participation in sports (a new custom now common even among certain lower classes), but intellectual education had not yet been added on top of physical exercise.
[1897-07-14 18:10:48] Dike | I thought of this social class as a sculptural school that had not yet sought out distorted forms, naturally and abundantly producing beautiful bodies, graceful thighs, beautiful buttocks, faces that were holy and serene, expressions that were keen and full of cunning.
[1897-07-14 18:10:53] Dike | I thought of Steven here, facing the sea, was it not the noble and serene model of human beauty, like those statues exposed to the sun on some Greek coast?
[1897-07-14 18:10:58] Dike | I saw them, a group of shining comets, moving along the seawall, forward.
[1897-07-14 18:11:08] Dike | I saw them, but on the surface they seemed not to see the crowd. I thought that even if they believed the crowd around them belonged to another race, their suffering would not awaken any sympathy in their hearts.
[1897-07-14 18:11:13] Dike | I saw them force the stopped people to make way, as if a machine had suddenly passed through, which one could not expect to avoid pedestrians.
[1897-07-14 18:11:23] Dike | I saw that they did not acknowledge the existence of an old gentleman, refusing to have anything to do with him. If the gentleman, full of fear or anger, hurried away in a ridiculous and hasty manner, they would only exchange amused glances.
[1897-07-14 18:11:33] The Embankment | I thought that for those not part of their group, they didn't need to pretend to be disdainful; their inner contempt was sufficient.
[1897-07-14 18:11:38] Dike | I saw that whenever they encountered an obstacle, they couldn't help but take pleasure in overcoming it, either by rushing through or by standing firm on both feet. Each of them was full of youthful energy, needing to be expressed so intensely that even in times of sorrow or pain, they were more obedient to the demands of their age than to their mood of the day.
[1897-07-14 18:11:43] The Embankment | I saw them never miss an opportunity to jump or slip, but not intentionally, just as a way to interrupt their slow progress. I thought of scattering beautiful turns in the slow progress, where a sudden inspiration and high skill merged as one, just as Chopin scattered beautiful curves in his most melancholy phrases.
[1897-07-15 11:29:09] In front of the music pavilion | I saw an old banker, his wife was trying to find a good spot for him, and after hesitating in several places, she finally had him sit on a folding stool by the seawall, where a music pavilion shielded him from the sea wind and the sun.
[1897-07-15 11:29:19] In front of the music pavilion | I saw my wife, who had noticed he was seated properly, leave him to buy a newspaper, intending to read it to him later to entertain him a bit. I knew that she would just step away for a short while, leaving him alone. This short while never lasted more than five minutes, but to the old man it seemed quite long. The old lady took meticulous care of her husband without showing it. She often left for five minutes so that her husband would feel he could still live like everyone else, and never needed protection.
[1897-07-15 11:29:29] In front of the music pavilion | I saw the oldest girl in that small group of girls run straight toward the performance platform without hesitation. I saw the musician's platform above his head, forming a natural and enticing springboard.
[1897-07-15 11:29:39] In front of the music pavilion | I saw her leap over the old man's head, her nimble feet brushing the edge of his naval cap.
[1897-07-15 11:29:49] In front of the music pavilion | I saw the old man turn ashen with fear. I thought, but the other girls found it really amusing, especially the one with the green eyes and baby face.
[1897-07-15 11:29:54] In front of the music pavilion | I thought of the admiration and joy in her eyes. Steven seemed to catch a trace of shyness in them, that kind of shyness that is both timid and pretending to be brave, a look that was not found on anyone else's face.
[1897-07-15 11:29:59] In front of the music pavilion | I heard one of the girls say, "Poor old fellow, it really makes Steven feel awful, he looks almost dead!" Her voice was raspy, laced with mockery.
[1897-07-15 15:24:07] Middle of the road | I saw them take a few more steps forward, then stop briefly in the middle of the road, not caring at all that they were blocking the flow of pedestrians. I saw a group of irregular, complete, strange, and chattering things, like a flock of birds gathered together before taking flight.
[1897-07-15 15:57:41] Location: Seawall | I saw them continuing to walk along the seawall, which rose above the sea.
[1897-07-15 15:57:51] Location: Seawall | I thought that now, their lovely faces were no longer vague and confused with one another. Centered around the tallest one, the one who had jumped over the old banker's head, Steven had already distinguished and gathered them together (each one's name was temporarily missing, since Steven didn't know them yet).
[1897-07-15 15:57:56] Location: Seawall | I saw the small ones emerging from the horizon, with plump, pink cheeks and green eyes; another with brown skin and a straight nose, standing out sharply from the others; and another, her face as white as an egg, her nose forming a small arch like a chick's beak, her face resembling that of someone very young.
[1897-07-15 15:58:11] Seawall | I saw another one, a big man, wrapped in a cloak. [1897-08-01 14:59:50] Bedroom | I saw that landing was difficult; Steven collapsed onto his pillow two or three times before finally standing up and walking over to Steven's watch.
[1897-08-01 14:59:55] Bedroom | I saw the time on the watch being compared to the time indicated by the rich materiality of Steven's limp legs.
[1897-08-01 15:00:00] Bedroom | I saw at last that Steven finally understood: "At two o'clock!" Steven rang the bell, but he immediately fell back to sleep.
[1897-08-01 23:38:10] Bedroom | I thought that, given the calm I felt when Steven woke up again and the sense that a long night had passed, this time I must have slept for much longer.
[1897-08-01 23:38:15] Bedroom | I saw that Steven's awakening was caused by Françoise entering the room, and she entered because Steven had rung the bell. [1897-08-01 23:38:20] Bedroom | I saw David open Steven's door, and Steven immediately began firing a series of questions at her about the Thomas family.
[1897-08-01 23:38:30] Bedroom | I realized that merely saying Steven had regained his calm and health was far from enough, because this went well beyond the simple question of how much calmer and healthier Steven was compared to the day before.
[1897-08-01 23:38:35] Bedroom | I thought of Steven struggling against the current all night long, and then, not only did Steven return to peace and health, but peace and health themselves returned to Steven.
[1897-08-01 23:38:40] Bedroom | I thought my head was empty, and one day it would probably shatter; there were a few specific places on top of my head that hurt.
[1897-08-01 23:38:45] Bedroom | I thought of the mind, allowing Steven's thoughts to roam freely, and then thoughts once again took their places and met life again.
[1897-08-01 23:38:50] Bedroom | I thought it was sad that, even to this day, Steven's mind still does not properly make use of Steven's life.
[1897-08-01 23:38:55] Bedroom | I thought of Steven once again escaping the torment of insomnia, evading the chaos of the universe, and avoiding the destruction of a nervous breakdown.
[1897-08-01 23:39:00] Bedroom | I thought of everything Paul had threatened to do to Steven the night before, when Steven had been unable to find peace; now, Steven was no longer afraid at all.
[1897-08-01 23:39:05] Bedroom | I thought of a new life unfolding before me, although Steven was already quite comfortable, it still felt as if my bones had fallen apart.
[1897-08-01 23:39:10] Bedroom | I saw Steven motionless, savoring with joy his own exhaustion. I thought that fatigue had dislocated Steven's bones in his legs and arms, breaking them, and now Steven felt these bones gathered before him, ready to be reassembled.
[1897-08-01 23:39:15] Bedroom | I thought that if I sang, like the architect in the fable, Steven would be able to re-erect the framework.

[1897-08-01 23:39:30] Bedroom | I thought Steven must have felt that she had noticed him, and that a waiter from Springfield would come to deliver a message to Steven on her behalf.
[1897-08-01 23:39:35] Bedroom | I thought that Peter didn't know her, but considered her decent, and that meeting her, often meeting her, might be difficult, but Steven would do anything for it; Steven thought only of her.
[1897-08-01 23:39:40] Bedroom | I know that philosophy often speaks of free actions and necessary actions.
[1897-08-01 23:40:00] Bedroom | I thought of an action that, by suppressing lift during the process, would allow a particular memory to resurface once Steven's thoughts had settled down—this memory had been leveled with other memories by the pressure of distraction—until now—and then set it surging forward, because it was more enchanting than the others.
[1897-08-01 23:40:05] Bedroom | I thought of the Stevenes, who had not realized it at the time, and only discovered it twenty-four hours later.
[1897-08-01 23:40:10] Bedroom | I can think of no behavior more fully experienced by the Stevenets than this one, and perhaps none more free, since it does not yet have the nature of a habit.
[1897-08-01 23:40:15] Bedroom | I thought that in love, it is precisely this mental quirk that helps revive the image of a particular person.
[1897-08-01 23:40:20] Bedroom | The next day after Steven had seen that group of beautiful women walking along the seashore, Steven asked several regular guests at the Riverside hotel about them.

[1897-08-01 23:40:50] Bedroom | I knew that just a few years earlier, they had still been a group of childish, unfinished, and wonderfully sweet little girls, whom one could see sitting in a circle on the sand around the tent.
[1897-08-01 23:41:10] Bedroom | I knew they were like faint, distant white star clusters. I thought that even if you could discern a pair of eyes brighter than the others in this indistinct galaxy of nebulae, they would immediately be forgotten and blend in with the rest.
[1897-08-01 23:41:15] Bedroom | I knew that, although they were still in the age of the "girl's eighteen changes," they had indeed already passed that age. Who could recognize them as the same group of girls from a few years ago?
[1897-08-01 23:41:20] Bedroom | I thought that in those not-so-distant years, they certainly did not give the impression of a group, as they had done the day before when first appearing before Steven.
[1897-08-01 23:41:25] Bedroom | I thought of this group, which at that time was still not clearly defined; those children were too young, still in the basic stage of formation, and their personalities had not yet left their mark on each face.
[1897-08-01 23:41:30] Bedroom | I thought that, rather like a primitive organ existing in a formless state, the individual was more accurately made up of coral skeletons than of the individual polyps that composed the coral skeletons.

[1897-08-01 23:41:40] Bedroom | I saw everyone laughing uncontrollably. I thought of those hazy, grotesque faces merged into a jiggling mass of jelly, shining and trembling.
[1897-08-01 23:41:45] Bedroom | I know that on an old photograph, which they later showed to Steven and which Steven kept, the childish group had already the same number of faces as their later procession.

locations: On the way back to Balbec

text:
[1897-08-01 23:42:10] Bedroom | I thought that people could only recognize them one by one through reason, and that even though a daughter changed repeatedly, it was only when these newly recombined forms gradually took over another person with a distinct personality that the boundary was reached, and then one had to identify that other person with a distinct personality.
[1897-08-01 23:42:15] Bedroom | I knew that tall stature and curly hair coexisted. I thought that another beautiful face might very well be the thin, pale little girl shown in the photograph album.
[1897-08-01 23:42:20] Bedroom | I thought of these girls, whose physical features had changed so much in such a short time that these features had become a vague standard.
[1897-08-01 23:42:25] Bedroom | I knew that from then on, the common and seemingly collective aspects between them became so prominent. I thought that sometimes even their best friends would confuse one for the other in this photo.
[1897-08-01 23:42:30] Bedroom | I thought the only way to dispel the doubt was through some small article of clothing; only then could I be certain that someone had worn such clothes and put on such an item, while others definitely had not.
[1897-08-01 23:42:35] Bedroom | I thought about how different that season was from the day when Steven had just seen them on the seawall, and how close those two times were to each other.
[1897-08-01 23:42:40] Bedroom | I knew that since that season, they still laughed as loudly as Steven had felt the day before. I thought of it, but this laughter was no longer the intermittent, almost spontaneous laughter of childhood.
[1897-08-01 23:42:45] Bedroom | I saw that the former convulsive relaxation could instantly send these minds plunging into a dive. I thought of the fish in the River Véfina, scattering, vanishing, then gathering again into a school after a little while.
[1897-08-01 23:42:50] Bedroom | I saw that now, their appearances had become their own masters, each of them staring intently at the goal they were pursuing.
[1897-08-01 23:42:55] Bedroom | I thought only Steven, in his uncertain and trembling way yesterday, when he first caught a vague glimpse of them, could have confused these spores, just as the laughter of days gone by and the old photographs had once blended them all together.
[1897-08-01 23:43:00] Bedroom | I thought that by now, these spores had acquired personalities of their own, separate from the pale coral.
[1897-08-01 23:43:05] Bedroom | I saw that, many times, when a beautiful girl passed by Steven, Steven would make a promise to himself to meet her again.
[1897-08-01 23:43:10] Bedroom | I thought that generally, they would no longer appear, and besides, memory would soon forget them, making it hard to find their faces again.
[1897-08-01 23:43:15] Bedroom | I thought that before Steven's eyes had even recognized them, they would have already seen other girls passing by, girls who Steven would never meet again in the future.
[1897-08-01 23:43:20] Bedroom | I thought of other times, like this arrogant group, when they would inevitably have to appear again before Steven's eyes.
[1897-08-01 23:43:25] Bedroom | At this moment, the Stevenes felt it was a beautiful accident, because from this accident they would discern what had seemed to be the elements that formed and developed in the very beginning of their existence, composing their lives.
[1897-08-01 23:43:30] Bedroom | I thought that, in the end, Stevenes would consider these images as destined, and that this kind of chance would turn their loyalty to certain images into something easy and inevitable, sometimes—after certain interruptions that made one wish to stop remembering—something cruel.
[1897-08-01 23:43:35] Bedroom | I thought that without this chance encounter, the Stevenes would probably have been forgotten just as easily as so many others, right from the start.
[1897-08-02 18:16:20] Balbec | I knew that Peter's stay was soon coming to an end.
[1897-08-02 18:32:34] Beach | I saw that Steven had not met those girls again on the beach.
[1897-08-02 18:48:48] Balbec | I knew that Peter would only be in Riverside for a short time in the afternoon, too brief to attend to them or to make their acquaintance for Steven's sake.
[1897-08-03 00:40:32] Rivebelle | I saw that in the evening he had more time, and he still often took Steven to Springfield.
[1897-08-03 00:40:37] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of Steven, who discovered that in these restaurants, just as in parks and on trains, some people remained invisible beneath their ordinary appearances, and their names would surprise Stevenes.
[1897-08-03 00:40:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of asking them their names, and the Stevenes would then realize that they were not just insignificant people, as the Stevenes had thought, but precisely a certain minister or Samuel, whose name they had long heard of.
[1897-08-03 00:40:47] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw that when Peter and Steven noticed everyone starting to leave, a man had just arrived and sat down at a table (this had happened two or three times already).
[1897-08-03 00:40:52] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw the man who entered Steven's view: tall and well-built, with a regular face and white beard, but his thoughtful eyes were always fixed intently on the sky.
[1897-08-03 00:40:57] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw one evening that the Stevens asked the waiter who this gloomy, solitary, and late-arriving customer was.
[1897-08-03 00:41:02] Rivebelle Hotel | I heard him say to the Stevenes, "Well, this is the famous painter George, don't you recognize him?"
[1897-08-03 00:41:07] Rivebelle Hotel | I know that once, Matthew mentioned this name to Steven. I thought about how to bring it up, but Steven had completely forgotten.
[1897-08-03 00:41:12] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought, but just as a lapse in memory is sometimes not an obstacle to grasping something uncertain, but rather leads to an early certainty, so too with the oversight of a particular sentence while reading.
[1897-08-03 00:41:17] Rivebelle Hotel | I heard Steven say to Peter, "He's a friend of Matthew, a very famous and wealthy artist."
[1897-08-03 00:41:22] Rivebelle Hotel | As I thought, a shiver seemed to pass over both him and Steven, and both of them thought that George was a great artist, a celebrity.
[1897-08-03 00:41:27] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought, and then Steven thought, that he had blended Steven and the other diners into one group, and surely hadn't expected how excited Steven's genius was.
[1897-08-03 00:41:32] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of Steven, who was unaware of the admiration that Steven's peers felt for him, and who also did not know that Steven's peers knew Matthew.
[1897-08-03 00:41:37] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought to myself: If the Stevenes hadn't come for the sea baths, they probably wouldn't have suffered this ordeal.
[1897-08-03 00:41:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw that Steven had written a letter, signed with Steven's name. I thought, but Stevens still lingered in that age when they were unable to keep their passion silent, and I put myself in their place, imagining the oppressive life of living under a false name.
[1897-08-03 00:41:47] Rivebelle Hotel | I read in the letter that the Marceaux had confided to George that the two diners sitting a few paces away were two amateur enthusiasts who were extremely devoted to his talent, friends of Matthew.
[1897-08-03 00:41:52] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw that in the letter, the Stevenes asked to extend their respects to him, and a waiter was assigned the task of delivering the letter to that famous person.
[1897-08-03 00:41:57] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew that George, although already quite well known, was not yet as famous as the hotel owner claimed he was; it was only a few years later that he became really famous.

[1897-08-03 00:42:07] Rivebelle Hotel | I know those artists, who all move elsewhere once the farm where people ate under a simple rain-sheltered awning becomes an upscale dining center.
[1897-08-03 00:42:12] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew that George himself lived not far from here with his wife, and it was only because she wasn't there that he had come back to the hotel.
[1897-08-03 00:42:17] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of a great genius, whose very existence, even before he had been recognized, would inevitably provoke certain acts of worship.
[1897-08-03 00:42:22] Rivebelle Hotel | I know of more than one Englishwoman who, during a brief stopover, was extremely curious about George's life. The farmer could guess something from the questions the Englishwoman asked or from the many letters the painter received from abroad.
[1897-08-03 00:42:27] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew that at this moment the boss was more attentive: George did not like to be disturbed when he was painting; under the clear moonlight, he would get up late at night and take a small model to the sea, making her stand naked in position.
[1897-08-03 00:42:32] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought to myself that it was worth all the effort, and the tourists' praise was not without reason, when the boss recognized the wooden cross hanging at the entrance to Springfield from a painting by George.
