[1897-08-03 00:42:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew, but whether the small painting of "Sunrise at Sea" that George had given him was worth a fortune, he didn't know.
[1897-08-03 00:42:47] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw Steven and the others see George read their letter, put it in his pocket, continue eating, then ask for his coat, stand up, and leave.
[1897-08-03 00:42:52] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought for certain that Steven's behavior was annoying him, and now Steven really wanted (and also feared) to slip away before he noticed Steven.
[1897-08-03 00:42:57] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of one thing that Steven and his friends never considered, yet in their eyes it was the most important thing: the passion that Steven and his friends felt for George, a passion they would not allow anyone to question or doubt.
[1897-08-03 00:43:02] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that the Stevenes could indeed prove, with the anxious heart they carried during the wait, their willingness to risk everything for this great man, but this enthusiasm was not, as the Stevenes themselves imagined, a sign of admiration, since they had never actually seen any of George's works.
[1897-08-03 00:43:07] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that the object of Steven's emotions was probably the empty concept of a "great artist," rather than a work that Steven had never seen.
[1897-08-03 00:43:12] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that, at best, it was a hollow admiration, an empty framework of admiration, a skeletal structure of feeling—something connected to childhood, just like certain organs that no longer exist in adults, and so the Stevenes were still children.
[1897-08-03 00:43:22] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw that George was about to reach the door when he suddenly turned and came toward us.
[1897-08-03 00:43:27] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of Steven, both surprised and delighted, overwhelmed with tension.
[1897-08-03 00:43:32] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that, several years later, Steven would no longer feel this way, because as people grow older, their abilities decline, and becoming accustomed to social occasions makes one never again think of seizing such an unusual opportunity or feeling such excitement.
[1897-08-03 00:43:37] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw George sitting at the table with Steven and speaking a few words to them. I heard Steven mention Matthew to him several times, but he never answered Steven.
[1897-08-03 00:43:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw him, and he didn't stop inviting Steven to come visit him in his studio at Riverside. I thought that Steven had initially believed he didn't know Matthew.
[1897-08-03 00:44:02] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew this invitation had not been extended to Peter, because Steven had said a few words that made him believe Steven was fond of art and thus earned the invitation.
[1897-08-03 00:44:07] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that even if George and Matthew were close friends, Matthew's recommendation probably wouldn't have had such an effect (because in life, the proportion of emotions that are free from self-interest is greater than people think).

[1897-08-03 00:44:17] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that compared to the kindness of a great artist, the kindness of a nobleman, no matter how touching, always had an air of acting and affectation.
[1897-08-03 00:44:22] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought of Peter, who went to great lengths to be liked, while George loved giving and sacrificing.
[1897-08-03 00:44:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I knew that everything he possessed—his thoughts, his works, and all the rest he considered secondary—would be gladly given to someone who understood him.
[1897-08-03 00:45:02] Rivebelle Hotel | I know, but he didn't have a social circle that he could endure on his own; he lived in solitude, with a wild element to him.
[1897-08-03 00:45:22] Rivebelle Hotel | I know that people in the upper classes call this pretentiousness, lack of refinement; those in power call it having the wrong ideas; neighbors call it insanity; and family members call it selfishness and arrogance.
[1897-08-03 00:45:27] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that, at first, even in solitude, he had happily considered that through his work he could speak to those who did not understand or had offended him, allowing them to know themselves fully.
[1897-08-03 00:45:32] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that perhaps he lived alone not out of indifference to others, but out of love for them, just as Steven had given up Michael in order to one day reappear in a more charming form.
[1897-08-03 00:45:37] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that perhaps his work was meant for certain people, like returning to them, and in this return, people would like him, admire him, and talk about him, even though they had not seen him himself.
[1897-08-03 00:45:42] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that whether they were patients, monks, artists, or heroes, when Stevenes decided to give something up with their original mindset, it was not always entirely complete at first. Later, through reaction, it finally had an effect on the Stevenes.
[1897-08-03 00:45:47] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that if he had ever wished to paint for certain people, then when he was painting, he was living for himself, away from the society he had grown indifferent to.
[1897-08-03 00:45:52] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that the practice of solitude had made him love solitude, just as Steven and others at first feared every important matter.
[1897-08-03 00:45:57] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that because the Stevenes knew that such a major matter was incompatible with smaller ones, and the Stevenes placed great importance on small matters.
[1897-08-03 00:46:02] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought that great matters did not take away Steven's small concerns, but rather set Steven free from them.
[1897-08-03 00:46:07] Rivebelle Hotel | I thought about how, before experiencing great events, Steven's entire focus was on figuring out to what extent they could reconcile their lives with some small pleasures, but once they experienced great events, those little joys no longer seemed like joy at all.
[1897-08-03 00:46:17] Rivebelle Hotel | I saw that George hadn't spoken with the Marceaux for very long, and Steven was preparing to visit his studio two or three days later.

[1897-08-04 01:45:02] Balbec | The first image I thought of, in Steven's memory, was very faint. Steven longed for it, pursued it, then forgot it, and later found it again.

[1897-10-09 07:59:50] Balbec | I heard her say to Steven, "Yes, Steven is spending the night at your hotel tonight. Steven has a cold, and even before dinner, Steven is going to bed."
[1897-10-09 07:59:55] Balbec | I heard, "You can come to Steven's bed to watch Steven have dinner, and then we'll play for a while. Whatever you want to play, we'll play it."
[1897-10-09 08:00:00] Balbec | I heard, "If you come to the station tomorrow morning, Steven would be very happy, but Steven is afraid it might seem odd. Steven didn't mean Andre, she's smart; Steven was talking about someone else going to the station."
[1897-10-09 08:00:05] Location: Balbec | I heard that someone told Steven's aunt, which would become gossip again, but Steven and his friends could spend the evening together, and Steven's aunt wouldn't know a thing.
[1897-10-09 08:00:10] Balbec | I saw her smile again and add a sentence. I heard, "Steven is going to say goodbye to André. Okay, see you soon, come early, we have plenty of time."
[1897-10-10 00:42:27] Balbec | I thought of the words I had heard, and Steven was once again in the period before he loved Michael, back to the time when Steven felt that love was not just an external whole, but something that could be realized.
[1897-10-10 00:42:32] Balbec | I thought of Michael as Steven had seen her on the Champs-Élysées, a Michael entirely different from the one who reappeared in Steven's mind when he was alone.
[1897-10-10 00:42:37] Balbec | I thought that suddenly, the imagined Albertine, the Albertine whom Steven had not yet met, the Albertine whom Steven imagined was secretly watching him on the seafront, the Albertine who looked unhappy as Steven walked away, had turned into the real Albertine, the Albertine Steven saw every day.
[1897-10-10 00:42:42] Balbec | I thought that Steven had originally believed she was full of bourgeois prejudices, and had been especially open with her aunt!
[1897-10-10 00:42:47] Balbec Hotel | I saw Steven going to have dinner with David, and I felt that there was a secret in my heart that she did not know about.
[1897-10-10 00:42:52] Balbec Hotel | I thought that, for Albertine, tomorrow when her girlfriends were with her, they would not know what had just happened among the Stevenes.
[1897-10-10 00:42:57] Balbec Hotel | I thought of how Madame Bontemps, when she kissed her niece's forehead, had no idea that between the two of them there was also a Steven. The way the girl had styled her hair was to please Steven, and this purpose was kept secret from everyone.
[1897-10-10 00:43:02] Balbec Hotel | I thought that up until then, Steven had been so envious of Madame Bongar, because her relatives were also her niece's relatives; she mourned for the same people her niece did; and wherever she visited her relatives, her niece also went to visit the same relatives.
[1897-10-10 00:43:07] Balbec Hotel | I thought that, by chance, Steven was better than her aunt herself in Albertine's eyes, and when she was with her aunt, what she would miss would be Steven.
[1897-10-10 00:43:12] Balbec Hotel | I had thought about what would happen shortly after, but Steven wasn't exactly sure. In any case, this grand hotel, this night, no longer seemed empty to Steven; they contained Steven's happiness.
[1897-10-11 00:43:22] Balbec Hotel | I saw Steven ring the bell to summon the elevator operator, so he could go up to the room Albertine had rented, which was on the side of the valley.
[1897-10-11 00:43:27] Elevator of the Balbec Hotel | I thought of any small action, such as sitting on the bench in an elevator, and Steven found them so sweet, so intimately connected to his heart.
[1897-10-11 00:43:32] Elevator of the Balbec Hotel | I thought of the elevator cables that allowed one to ascend, and the few steps one had to take after getting out of the elevator. To Steven, these were simply the materialization of his joy into gears and steps.
[1897-10-11 00:43:37] Corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I thought that if Steven took just two or three more steps down this corridor, he would reach the room, where the precious essence of that rosy body was hidden.
[1897-10-11 00:43:42] Corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I thought of that room, which, even if something sweet were to happen within it, would afterward remain the same as ever. To an outsider who knew nothing about it, the room would still be no different from any other room.
[1897-10-11 00:43:47] Corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I thought of all these rooms, where the objects had become silent witnesses, careful and cautious confidants, and inviolable keepers of happiness.
[1897-10-11 00:43:52] Corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I saw those steps from the staircase to Albertine's room, those inevitable steps that no one could stop anymore, and Steven walked them with joy and care. I thought I had plunged into a new environment, as if Steven, with every step he took, was slowly moving forward in happiness, while at the same time I felt an immense and previously unknown sensation, as though I had finally entered the inheritance that had always been meant for Steven.

[1897-10-11 00:43:57] The corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I saw Steven jumping up and down with joy. I thought of Steven, and suddenly realized that Steven should have had no suspicions. She had told Steven to come after she was in bed, which was perfectly clear.
[1897-10-11 00:44:07] Corridor of the Balbec Hotel | I saw Françoise on the road and nearly knocked her over, and Steven's eyes lit up as he ran to his girlfriend's room.
[1897-10-11 05:13:17] Albertine's room | I saw Steven looking at Albertine lying in bed. I saw before me a white blouse revealing her neck, which altered the proportions of her face.
[1897-10-11 05:13:27] Albertine's Room | I saw that perhaps it was the bed, or perhaps the cold, or may be dinner that had made her face more flushed, more radiant than a peach blossom. I thought of Steven and the look on his face that I had seen several hours earlier on the seawall, and now I was finally about to find out what this beauty tasted like.
[1897-10-11 05:13:32] Albertine's Room | I saw her two dark, curly braids, which had been completely undone to please Steven, one of them running from top to bottom across her cheek.
[1897-10-11 05:13:47] Albertine's room | I saw her smiling at Steven. I saw her beside the window, where the bright moonlight illuminated the valley.
[1897-10-11 05:13:57] Albertine's room | I thought of seeing Albertine's bare neck and her cheeks, which were more beautiful than roses, and how Steven was so enraptured (meaning that, for Steven, the real world was no longer in nature, but rather in a torrent of sensations, to the point where Steven could hardly control himself).
[1897-10-11 05:14:02] Albertine's room | I thought of this meeting as having completely shattered the balance between the vast, impregnable life within Steven and the fragile cosmic life in comparison.
[1897-10-11 05:14:07] Albertine's Room | I saw from the window, Steven faintly glimpsed the sea beside the valley, the swelling breasts of the highest cliffs at Ménival, and the night sky before the moon had reached its zenith.
[1897-10-11 05:14:22] Albertine's room | I thought that, compared to the downy hair around Steven's eyes, Steven seemed to find everything lighter.
[1897-10-11 05:14:27] Albertine's room | I thought of Steven, whose eyelashes had already begun to swell up, firm and strong, ready to lift many other heavy things upon their tender surface, the world's mountains and hills.
[1897-10-11 05:14:32] Albertine's room | I thought that the hemisphere of the horizon itself was no longer enough to fill this downy celestial body.
[1897-10-11 05:14:37] Albertine's room | I thought that compared to the deep breath that filled Steven's chest, all the life that the Creator could grant Steven seemed very faint to Steven, and the breath of the sea had become so short in his eyes.
[1897-10-11 05:14:42] Albertine's room | I saw Steven lean down toward Albertine to embrace her. I thought that at this moment, death would come to Steven, and Steven would not care at all.
[1897-10-11 05:14:47] Albertine's room | I thought, more precisely, that Steven felt it was impossible, because life was not outside Steven, but inside Steven.
[1897-10-11 05:14:52] Albertine's Room | I thought that if, at this moment, a philosopher were to explain his ideas, saying that one day, even a distant day, Steven would die; while the eternal power of nature would still continue to live, Steven would surely smile with compassion at him!
[1897-10-11 05:14:57] Albertine's room | How could that be? How could the world exist longer than Steven, since Steven was not lost in the world, but rather the world was locked within Steven's heart, and the world could never possibly fill Steven's heart.
[1897-10-11 05:15:02] Albertine's Room | I thought that Steven felt there was still room in his heart for countless other treasures, and Steven would contemptuously throw the sky, the sea, and the cliffs into a corner.
[1897-10-11 05:15:07] Albertine's room | I saw Albertine scream as Steven rushed toward her to kiss her. I heard, "Hurry up, or else Steven will ring the bell!"
[1897-10-11 05:15:12] Albertine's room | I thought, but in Steven's view, a girl sending a young man secretly to meet her, keeping it from her aunt, surely wasn't doing it for nothing; someone who knows how to seize the right moment can succeed if they have the courage.
[1897-10-11 05:15:17] Albertine's room | I saw Albertine's round face illuminated by the inner flame, as if lit by a small lamp that had burned all night. I thought of Steven in such an excited state, and to Steven she was so three-dimensional that, in his eyes, she turned as if imitating the rotation of a globe, like Michelangelo's figures carried away by a static yet dizzying whirlwind.
[1897-10-11 05:15:22] Albertine's room | I thought of this never-before-tasted pink fruit, what it would smell like, what it would taste like—I was about to find out, Steven!
[1897-10-12 06:28:02] Albertine's room | I saw Albertine had summoned all her strength to pull the bell. I saw it just then, and Steven heard a sharp, continuous, and grating sound.
[1897-10-12 07:43:46] Balbec | I thought back to how Steven had always believed that his love for Albertine was not based on the desire for physical possession.
[1897-10-12 07:43:51] Balbec | I thought, but the result of that evening's attempt was that, in Steven's eyes, such possession had become impossible.
[1897-10-12 07:43:56] Balbec | I thought back to the first day on the seawall when I saw her, and Steven had already suspected she was a loose woman. Then, through various intermediate assumptions, Steven seemed finally to have confirmed that she was absolutely pure and spotless.
[1897-10-12 07:44:01] Balbec | I heard about it a week later, after she returned from her aunt's house. She coldly said to Steven: "Steven, I have forgiven you, and I even feel sorry for having made you sad, but never, ever do that again!"
[1897-10-12 07:44:06] Balbec | It occurred to me that this was the exact opposite of what Richard had told Steven, that one could have any woman one wanted; it seemed as though Steven were not seeing a real, living girl, but rather a wax doll.
[1897-10-12 07:44:11] Balbec | I realized that from then on, Steven's desire to enter her life, to follow her to the land where she had spent her childhood, and to begin living under her guidance would gradually grow distant from her.
[1897-10-12 07:44:16] Balbec | I had never felt a more urgent desire to know what she thought about something, nor had I ever clung more firmly to the belief that Steven could kiss her.
[1897-10-12 07:44:21] Balbec | I thought that once the desire for possession stopped feeding Steven's dream, the dream would abandon her, whereas Steven had always believed this dream to be independent of the desire for possession.
[1897-10-12 07:44:26] Balbec | I thought that from now on, these fantasies would once again be free, transferring to one of Albertine's girlfriends, first and foremost to Andre--depending on the charm Steven found in a particular girlfriend on any given day, and especially on the possibilities and opportunities that Steven faintly glimpsed as being available to him through her.
[1897-10-12 07:44:31] Balbec | I thought, even if there had been no affair with Albertine, in the days that followed, Steven probably would not have grown any happier about Andre's growing attentiveness toward him.
[1897-10-12 07:44:36] Balbec | I knew about Steven's failure with Albertine, which she had never told anyone about.
[1897-10-12 07:44:56] Balbec | I thought of some pretty young girls who, once they reach adolescence, are always more beloved than women who are more beautiful and wealthier--this is true at home, among friends, and in society.
[1897-10-12 07:45:01] Balbec | I thought it was certainly because of their beautiful looks, but even more because of their mysteriously joyful and fascinating charm—the source of which probably lay in their endless vitality, and people who had not been so generously blessed by the Creator came to them to quench their thirst. Albertine was one of these people.
[1897-10-12 07:45:06] Balbec | I thought of some girls who, not yet of an age to love—and even worse, once they are—were asked to give far more than they could possibly offer, even things they couldn't possibly give. She was one of them.
[1897-10-12 07:45:11] Balbec | I knew that from childhood, Albertine had had four or five admirers around her, among them André, who was far superior to her, and André himself was fully aware of this. I thought that perhaps it was precisely the kind of unconscious attractiveness that Albertine had for people that helped her, becoming the very root of this little group.
[1897-10-12 07:45:16] Balbec | I knew that this kind of attraction even extended quite far, reaching relatively more prominent social circles: if they wanted to perform the peacock dance, they would rather invite Albertine than a girl from an aristocratic family.
[1897-10-12 07:45:36] Balbec | I knew the outcome would be that, although she had no dowry and lived in poverty, sustained by Monsieur Bongard, who was said to be dishonest and eager to get rid of her, she was still invited to dinner, and even offered a place to stay in someone's home.
[1897-10-12 07:45:56] Balbec | I thought that to Peter's eyes, these people who had invited Albertine probably had no shine at all, but to Rosamund or Andre's Robert—women who were also wealthy, but who didn't know these people—these people represented considerable power.
[1897-10-12 07:46:01] Balbec | I know that like this, Albertine spent several weeks each year in the homes of a president of the Banque de France and a director of a major railway company.
[1897-10-12 07:46:21] Balbec | I knew that the wife of a financial magnate received important guests, but she never told Robert on which day was her "reception day" for Andre.
[1897-10-12 07:46:41] Balbec | I thought that André's Robert found the woman very rude, yet she still took great interest in everything that happened in her family.
[1897-10-12 07:46:46] Balbec | I saw her urging André to invite Albertine to their villa every year. I heard her say, "It's a kind act to offer a girl who can't afford to travel and whose aunt isn't taking care of her the chance to spend a few days by the sea."
[1897-10-12 07:46:51] Balbec | I thought that Robert's actions probably had nothing to do with wanting the bank president and his wife to learn how much she and her daughter loved Albertine, so that they would develop a liking for the two of them.
[1897-10-12 07:46:56] Balbec | I thought she certainly wouldn't expect the kind and honest Albertine to have invited her, or at least to have invited Andre to the financier's garden party.
[1897-10-13 01:42:47] Balbec | Every evening at dinner, I saw her act as if she didn't care, yet she listened with great interest as Albertine told her about the events that had taken place in the financier's castle, the people who had been there, and so on.
[1897-10-13 01:42:52] Balbec | I thought of these people, almost all of whom she had either seen or heard about, and even the idea that Albertine had only known them in this way—that is, without really understanding them (she called this knowing "people from all ages")—caused Robert some sadness.
[1897-10-13 01:43:02] Balbec | I saw her look down on them with an air of arrogance and indifference, asking Albertine some contemptuous questions about them.
[1897-10-13 01:43:07] Balbec | I heard her say, "Tell the cook that the peas aren't tender enough." I thought about it and thus confirmed my own position, and once again found myself back in "real life," and this lady, possibly losing hold of her important position, might feel anxious.
[1897-10-13 01:43:12] Balbec | I thought that after saying those words, the lady would return to her calm.
[1897-10-13 01:43:17] Balbec | I thought to myself that she had long since made up her mind that André must marry someone, a man of high birth and considerable wealth, so that André could also have a cook and two coachmen, someone with status, someone who actually had real things.
[1897-10-13 01:43:22] Balbec | I thought about how Albertine was having dinner at the castle of the bank president with some Madame so-and-so, a woman who had even invited her to spend the next winter, and in Robert's eyes, this was enough to make one respect this girl.
[1897-10-13 01:43:27] Balbec | I thought of this reverent respect, which was intertwined with the pity and even contempt that her misfortunes inspired.
[1897-10-13 01:43:32] Balbec | I thought of the contempt that became even more intense because M. Bonneval had betrayed his original side by joining the cabinet—there were vague rumors that he was a Panamaist—and this contempt was all the more bitter.
[1897-10-13 01:43:37] Balbec | I saw it, but that didn't stop Robert from looking down on those who seemed to think Albertine came from a low background, out of her love for the truth.
locations: The corridor of the Balbec Hotel

text:
[1897-10-13 01:43:42] Location: Balbec | "I heard, 'What? Her background couldn't be better, she's a Cimone, with just one 'n'!"
[1897-10-13 01:43:47] Balbec | I thought of nature, of all these things happening in a society where money played such an important role, a society where charm could get you an invitation, but not a marriage.
[1897-10-13 01:43:52] Balbec | I thought that although Albertine had received such special favor, this favor was not enough to compensate for her poverty, and the beneficial effects of this favor seemed to offer Albertine absolutely no "decent" marriage.
[1897-10-13 01:43:57] Balbec | I knew that this "showing off," even if it did not offer the hope of a successful marriage, had already aroused the envy of certain ill-intentioned people, Robert. I thought of how they would receive Albertine as if she were a "family member," even when they barely knew the wife of the bank president or Andre's Robert, and how each of them would be absolutely furious about it.
[1897-10-13 01:44:07] Balbec | I saw them saying to their mutual friend and to the mutual friend of the two ladies, that if the two ladies were to learn the truth, they would be furious.
[1897-10-13 01:44:27] Balbec | I knew that the truth was that Albertine had told everything she had discovered at this place (and vice versa), and because people had received her with an undue degree of intimacy, she had come by these discoveries.
[1897-10-13 01:44:32] Balbec | I thought of all these little secrets, which would be uncomfortable for the people involved to see revealed.
[1897-10-13 01:44:37] Balbec | I thought of these jealous women uttering such words, their sole purpose being to have someone relay the message, thus causing a rift between Albertine and her protector.
[1897-10-13 01:44:42] Balbec | I thought about it, but as often happens, when you ask someone to do something, it never gets done. The malicious intent behind their actions was too obvious, and in the end, it only made people despise women who harbored such thoughts even more.
[1897-10-13 01:44:47] Balbec | I thought of André's Robert, whose opinion of Albertine had already been fixed and would never change; she saw Albertine as a "poor child," naturally good-hearted, who only came up with all sorts of schemes to be liked.
[1897-10-13 01:44:52] Balbec | I thought about Albertine's fleeting popularity, which seemed to yield no real results, yet somehow gave the characteristics of certain people to Andre's girlfriend.
[1897-10-13 01:44:57] Balbec | I thought about how these people had always been the objects of others' pursuit, never needing to go after someone themselves (this same kind of personality could also be found among certain attractive women on the other end of society, for the same reasons), yet they never boasted about the attention others paid them; rather, they always kept it hidden.
[1897-10-13 01:45:02] Balbec | When someone spoke of so-and-so, she never said, "He really wants to see Steven."
[1897-10-13 01:45:07] Balbec | I saw that when she spoke of anyone, she did so with great kindness, as if she were pursuing them.
[1897-10-13 01:45:12] Balbec | I saw a young man who had just scolded her in front of everyone because she had refused to go out with him. When talking about this young man, instead of boasting about it or blaming him publicly, she actually praised him. I heard, "This young man is really enthusiastic!"
[1897-10-13 01:45:17] Balbec | I thought how she even felt troubled by the fact that she was so likable, because in that case she inevitably had to make people sad, yet her nature was to make people happy.
[1897-10-13 01:45:22] Balbec | I thought of how she liked to make people happy, even to the point of using lies that only those who are purely self-serving or those who have climbed to high positions usually employ.
[1897-10-13 01:45:27] Balbec | I thought that this insincerity actually exists in a rudimentary form in many people, and its content is simply not being satisfied with doing something just to please one person.
[1897-10-13 01:45:32] Balbec | I thought, for example, that if Albertine's aunt wanted her niece to accompany her to a dull daytime gathering, Albertine went, and she should have been satisfied with the spiritual gain of making her aunt happy.
[1897-10-13 01:45:37] Balbec | I saw that, but when she was warmly received by the host of the gathering, she preferred to say so to them. "I heard that Steven has long wanted to meet you, so he chose this opportunity and obtained his aunt's permission to come."
[1897-10-13 01:45:42] Balbec | I saw that wasn't enough: at this gathering, there was a girlfriend of Albertine's who had just gone through a breakup, and Albertine was going to speak to her. I heard, "Steven doesn't want you to be alone. Steven thinks that if he were here with you, you might feel better. If you want us to leave this gathering and go somewhere else, just say the word, and Steven will do as you wish. The most important thing is that Steven wants to see you feeling better."
[1897-10-13 01:45:47] Balbec | I thought that sometimes, the false purpose ruins the true one.
[1897-10-13 01:46:07] Balbec | I knew that Albertine had to go and ask someone to do a favor for one of her girlfriends, and that was why she had gone to visit a certain lady.
[1897-10-13 01:46:12] Balbec | I thought that once I arrived at this kind and enthusiastic lady's house, this girl, without realizing it, would follow her own principle of "making the most of each situation," feeling that it would be more sincere to appear solely because I was so happy to see this lady.
[1897-10-13 01:46:17] Balbec | I was deeply moved by the thought of this lady traveling such a long distance just for friendship with Albertine, and Albertine, almost moved by this lady, grew even more fond of her.
[1897-10-13 01:46:22] Balbec | I thought, but the problem was here: she had claimed to have come purely out of friendship, and she felt so strongly the joy of friendship. If she had asked this lady to help on behalf of her friend, she would have worried that this lady might suspect her feelings.
[1897-10-13 01:46:27] Balbec | I thought that, in fact, she was sincere; the lady would think that Albertine had come for this matter, which was true, but she would conclude that Albertine was pleased to see her, not without some calculation of advantage or loss, which was not accurate.
[1897-10-13 01:46:32] Balbec | I saw that Albertine left without asking for help. I thought of those men who are extremely attentive to a woman, hoping to win her favor, yet who refrain from declaring their love in order to keep such passion in a noble and elevated state.
[1897-10-13 01:46:37] Balbec | I thought that, in other situations, it couldn't be said that she always sacrificed the real purpose for a secondary, afterthought goal.
[1897-10-13 01:46:42] Balbec | I thought that the real purpose was directly opposed to the secondary one; if Albertine had revealed this purpose to that person, moving him deeply, then when she learned of the other purpose, her joy would immediately turn into the deepest sorrow.
[1897-10-13 01:46:47] Balbec | I thought about continuing the story, which would make this kind of contradiction even clearer.
[1897-10-13 01:46:52] Balbec | I thought of the examples of Stevens, which are entirely different in type, and they can illustrate how such contradictions are everywhere in the various situations life presents.
[1897-10-13 08:28:53] Balbec | I know of a husband who has settled his mistress in the city where he is stationed, while his wife remains in Willowbrook, hearing something of the truth, and feeling very distressed, she writes him several jealous letters.
[1897-10-13 08:29:13] Balbec | I knew that the mistress had to come to Willowbrook for a day, and she begged him to accompany her. The husband could not resist, so he took a twenty-four-hour leave of absence.
[1897-10-13 08:29:33] Balbec | I know, but he had a good heart. He felt guilty for making his wife unhappy, so after arriving in Willowbrook, he went to see her, and with sincere tears in his eyes, he told her that reading her letter had completely upset him, and he had managed to escape for a day just to come comfort her and embrace her.
[1897-10-13 08:29:53] Balbec | I know that, and so he came up with a plan, proving his love to both his mistress and his wife at the same time through a trip.
[1897-10-13 08:30:13] Balbec | I thought, but if his wife found out the real reason he had come to Willowbrook, her happiness would surely turn into suffering, unless this ungrateful fellow somehow made her feel more happiness than the pain caused by his lie.
[1897-10-13 08:30:18] Balbec | I thought that, according to Steven's view, the person who most consistently used this "multipurpose purpose" system should be Paul.
[1897-10-13 08:30:23] Balbec | I know that sometimes he took on the task of mediating between two friends who had quarreled, in order to gain the reputation of being "the mostenthusiastic person."
[1897-10-13 08:30:43] Balbec | I know that in front of the people who came to ask for his help, he was not content with merely appearingenthusiasticly helpful; he also had to present his mediation as something he did not do because of their request, but rather out of concern for the interests of the other party.
[1897-10-13 08:31:03] Balbec | I knew that in this way he would easily persuade the other person, having previously given him a hint that the person standing before him was "the most helpful one."
[1897-10-13 08:31:23] Balbec | I know that by playing both sides, doing what is called in slang "looking good on both sides," his reputation would not be at all jeopardized.
[1897-10-13 08:31:43] Balbec | I knew that what he had actually done was not a concession, but rather the fruit of his own prestige.
[1897-10-13 08:32:03] Balbec | I knew that, on the other hand, every favor he did seemed to be beneficial to both sides, which only added to his reputation as a helpful friend, and a very effective one, not like trying to cut water with a sword, but rather each mediation was successful.
[1897-10-13 08:32:23] Balbec | I knew this showed that both parties were deeply grateful to him.
[1897-10-13 08:32:43] Balbec | I knew that the insincerity inherent in such helpfulness, combined with the various contradictions present in anyone, was an essential part of Paul's character.
[1897-10-13 08:32:48] Balbec | I knew that in the cabinet, he often used James while still making James believe he was working for James's benefit.
[1897-10-13 08:33:08] Balbec | I thought James was quite childish, so I readily believed it.
[1897-10-13 08:33:13] Balbec | I realized that Albertine was more likable than she herself had hoped, and she didn't need to boast about her success in love.
[1897-10-13 08:33:18] Balbec | I knew that she always kept silent about the scene that had taken place by her bed between Steven and herself.
[1897-10-13 08:33:38] Balbec | I thought that if I were a hunchback, the whole world would surely know.
[1897-10-13 08:33:43] Balbec | I thought about her attitude in this scene, and Steven remained utterly puzzled.
[1897-10-13 08:33:48] Balbec | I thought about the assumption of her absolute chastity (Albertine had so brutally refused to let Steven kiss her, refused to let Steven have her body, and Steven first attributed this to that assumption. But in terms of Steven's own view of his girlfriend as kind and basically honest, such absolute chastity was by no means essential), and Steven had to repeatedly speculate on it many times.
[1897-10-13 08:33:53] Balbec | I thought of this hypothesis, which was so utterly opposite to the one Steven had made on the first day he met Albertine!

[1898-02-08 06:30:15] Marcel's room | I saw that before the dragoons had all passed by Steven's window, sleep had already taken the last few blossoms of the bouquet of sounds, and Steven sank back into sleep.
[1898-02-08 06:30:20] Marcel's Room | I thought about how the part of Steven's consciousness that came into contact with this bouquet of sounds was so small, and how deeply it had been deceived by sleep. [1898-02-08 06:30:25] Marcel's Room | I thought perhaps Steven had heard the voice in a dream, afraid of being awakened, or on the contrary, afraid of not waking up, of never seeing the hussar column again.

[1898-02-08 06:30:40] Hall of Thought | I thought of the same thing having two different outcomes. Nevertheless, the world in which Steven's sleep-life exists is so different from the real world that insomniacs first think of escaping from the real world.
[1898-02-08 06:30:45] Hall of Thought | I thought about how they would keep their eyes shut for hours, their minds filled with the same thoughts they had when their eyes were open. [1898-02-08 06:31:10] Hall of Thought | I thought of these sleeping flowers that would not bloom until the fateful stranger came to touch them, and then they would open into remarkably beautiful blossoms, releasing a series of dreams onto the sleeper for several hours, their intense fragrance astonishing and overwhelming.
[1898-02-08 06:31:15] Hall of Thought | I thought of the monastery deep in the garden, with all its windows open, echoing constantly with the lessons that Stevenes recited before falling asleep, which could only be memorized upon awakening.
[1898-02-08 06:31:20] Hall of Thought | As I thought this, the clock inside Steven's mind ticked nonstop (this was a sign of awakening), and the alarm was infallible because Steven had something to worry about. When the housewife came to inform Steven that it was seven o'clock, she found him already awake.
[1898-02-08 06:31:25] Hall of Thought | I thought of this room, which had opened its doors to sleep, where sleep worked tirelessly, making people forget the sorrows of love. Sometimes, this work was interrupted by a nightmare filled with vague memories, but it soon resumed again.
[1898-02-08 06:31:30] Hall of Thought | I thought of Stevens waking up, still carrying the memory of their dreams hanging on the dark walls of the room, but these memories remained shrouded in darkness, often only becoming visible for the first time in the afternoon when a similar impression cast light upon them.
[1898-02-08 06:31:35] Hall of Thought | I thought of several that had become unrecognizable, even though they were so clear in my dreams. When the Stevenes failed to recognize them, they had to be quickly buried in the earth, like the objects placed beside decaying corpses or remains, items so severely damaged that even the most skilled restorers could not restore them to use.
[1898-02-08 06:31:40] Hall of Thought | I thought of the mining site by the fence, where the deep sleep came to soak the mind in some kind of coating. This coating was incredibly hard; if a sleeper's will wanted to wake the sleeper, even on a beautiful morning like gold, it would have to swing its axe like young Siegfried, hacking away fiercely.
[1898-02-08 06:31:45] Hall of Thought | I thought of the world of nightmares that still lay behind me. Foolish doctors insisted that nightmares were more exhausting than insomnia. In fact, the opposite was true; they helped those who loved to reflect to divert their thoughts.
[1898-02-08 06:31:50] Hall of Thought | I thought that nightmares would present Steven's like a series of bizarre picture books, such as the case where Steven's deceased parents had just been involved in a serious car accident, though there was still a possibility they might recover soon. While waiting for their recovery, the Stevenes would confine them in a small mouse cage, making them smaller than white mice, covered with large red blisters, and with a feather sticking out of their heads, imitating Cicero delivering a magnificent speech to the Stevenes.
[1898-02-08 06:31:55] Hall of Thought | I thought of the turntable next to this album. Because of this turntable, Stevenes would temporarily face troubles, and would have to return to a house that had collapsed fifty years ago. However, as sleep faded away, the image of this house gradually disappeared, replaced by several different images. When the turntable finally stopped spinning, the final image would perfectly match the one Steven saw when he opened his eyes.
[1898-02-08 06:32:00] Marcel's Room | I sometimes saw Steven hear nothing, because Steven was deep in a sleep so profound it felt like an abyss. I was delighted that Steven had managed to escape soon after, but Steven's head felt heavy and full of things, as if he had to digest everything that those flexible vegetative nervous systems—those nymphs like the ones who fed Hercules—had given him when he was asleep, multiplying their activity.
[1898-02-08 06:32:05] Hall of Thought | I thought of how the Stevenes called this sleep "lead sleep," that is, a deep sleep, because after such a sleep ended, even after a long time, the Stevenes would still feel their bodies heavy and lifeless, like lead. The Stevenes were no longer living people.
[1898-02-08 06:32:10] Hall of Thought | I thought, but why is it that when Stevenes search for their thoughts and personalities as if looking for lost objects, they always end up finding "Steven" and no one else? Why, when Stevenes start thinking again, is the personality that emerges still the same as before? The Stevenes don't realize what is governing this choice—why, among thousands of possible candidates, it's always yesterday's "Steven" that is chosen.
[1898-02-08 06:32:15] Hall of Thought | I wondered what was guiding the Stevenes when thought was truly blocked (either by sleeping until morning or by dreaming about something completely different from the impressions of waking consciousness). There had indeed been death, for example, when the heart stopped beating and the rhythmic tongue movement revived the Stevenes.
[1898-02-08 06:32:20] Hall of Thought | I thought of a room, which, even if Steven had seen it only once, might awaken his memories, and upon these memories there would hang still older memories; or perhaps some of them would be buried deep in Steven's mind, without his being aware of them. Through the beneficial soul-flight of sleep, the scene at awakening should actually be similar to the moment when Steven recalls a forgotten name, a verse, or a chorus. If we consider the resurrection of the soul as a peculiar phenomenon of memory, it might perhaps be understandable.
[1898-02-14 06:59:45] Marcel's Room | I saw Steven wake up. The bright, sunny sky was urging Steven to get up. I saw it, but the bright, crisp morning of early winter was chilly, making Steven reluctant to leave his bed.
[1898-02-14 06:59:50] Marcel's Room | I saw Steven lift his head, stretch his neck, part of his body still hidden under the blankets. Steven stared wide-eyed out the window at the trees. I saw the leaves, for once unlike their usual appearance, as a few patches of color painted on an invisible canvas, golden and brilliantly red, hanging in the air.
[1898-02-14 06:59:55] Marcel's Room | I thought of Steven like a chrysalis undergoing metamorphosis, possessing a duality, where one environment was hard to adapt to the various parts of Steven's body: Steven's vision required only color, not warmth, while his chest, on the contrary, needed only warmth, not color.
[1898-02-14 07:00:00] Marcel's Room | I didn't get up until Steven had lit the fire. I saw the golden and purple morning as a clear and pleasing picture.
[1898-02-14 07:00:05] Marcel's Room | I saw Steven staring at the morning scene painting. A moment ago, Steven had stirred the fire, artificially adding a warmth that the cold picture lacked. I thought of fire as a pipe, burning cheerfully, smoking, and giving Steven a coarse yet subtle pleasure. It was coarse because the pleasure was based on physical comfort, and subtle because it stirred in Steven a vague and pure fantasy.
[1898-02-14 07:00:10] Marcel's Room | I saw a glaring red paper pasted in Steven's bathroom, covered with black and white flowers. I thought Steven's eyes would have difficulty adjusting. But these flowers kept appearing before Steven in new forms, forcing Steven to engage with them rather than resist, and changing the cheerful, song-filled atmosphere that greeted Steven when he woke up; these flowers forced Steven to stand in the midst of a sea of red, looking at this new residence, a world different from Willowbrook.
[1898-02-14 07:00:15] Marcel's Room | I saw this new residence as a pleasant screen, with fresh air constantly flowing in, completely different in orientation from Steven's parents' house.
[1898-02-14 07:00:20] Marcel's Room | I thought about how Steven had been restless for days, or longed to see his grandmother, fearing she might be ill at home, or else remembering some unfinished work he'd left in Willowbrook, which wasn't going well at the moment. (Even here, sometimes Steven had a way of deliberately making things difficult for himself.)
[1898-02-14 07:00:25] Marcel's Room | I thought of these worries, one after another would arise to disturb Steven's sleep. Steven was powerless to dispel Steven's sorrow, and Steven felt that in an instant, the entire course of Steven's life was shrouded in gloom.
[1898-02-16 06:13:47] Marcel's Room | I saw that Steven had someone from the hotel go to the barracks to deliver a message to Peter, telling him that if possible—Steven knew it was very difficult— he hoped he would come visit Steven.
[1898-02-16 06:13:57] Marcel's Room | I saw that he arrived an hour later. As soon as the doorbell rang, Steven felt all his worries instantly vanish. I thought that Steven knew, and that worry was a strength before Steven, but a weakness before Peter.
[1898-02-16 06:14:02] Marcel's Room | I thought that once he arrived, Steven's attention would leave behind Steven's worries and turn to him, expecting him to make a decision.
[1898-02-16 06:14:07] Marcel's Room | I saw him come in, and immediately he brought the energy he had fully displayed that morning into Steven's surroundings, creating a lively atmosphere completely different from the mood of Steven's room. I thought how Steven quickly adapted to the new environment and responded appropriately.

[1898-02-18 20:41:23] Marcel's room | "I heard, 'I'm sorry to disturb you. Steven is in a terrible mood, as you probably guessed.'"
[1898-02-18 20:41:28] Marcel's Room | "I heard, 'No, Steven thought you wanted to see Steven, and Steven felt that was fine. You sent for Steven, and Steven is happy. What's wrong? What's the matter? What can Steven do for you?'"
[1898-02-20 03:55:11] Marcel's Room | I saw Steven openly express his inner worries to him. He listened and answered Steven's questions frankly. I thought that he had already made Steven into the same person as himself before he even spoke.
[1898-02-20 03:55:16] Marcel's Room | I thought about how his heavy workload made him rush all day, with an active mind and a cheerful mood. Steven felt the same way; the troubles that had disturbed Steven's mind just now were really insignificant compared to his heavy workload.
[1898-02-20 03:55:21] Marcel's Room | I thought of Steven like a sick person who had been unable to open his eyes for several days. They called in a doctor, who gently and skillfully opened the patient's eyelids and removed a grain of sand from within. The patient recovered and his mind was at peace.
[1898-02-20 03:55:26] Marcel's Room | I saw all of Steven's troubles reduced to a telegram, and Peter volunteered to send it. I thought of Steven, as if he had found life entirely transformed, made so beautiful that he felt filled with strength, truly wanting to do something.
[1898-02-22 02:45:57] Marcel's Room | I heard "What are you doing now?" Steven asked Peter.
[1898-02-22 02:46:02] Marcel's Room | I heard, "Steven is leaving right away; the unit is going to drill in fifteen minutes, and Steven has to go."
[1898-02-22 02:46:07] Marcel's Room | I heard, "Did I trouble you by asking you to come?"
[1898-02-22 02:46:12] Marcel's Room | I heard, "There's nothing difficult about it. The captain was very polite. He said since it's you who called Steven, he should come, but Steven didn't want to stay long."
[1898-02-22 02:46:17] Marcel's Room | I heard, "If Steven would just get up quickly and go to the place where you're exercising, he'd find it very interesting. Perhaps during your rest time, he could even have a few words with you."
[1898-02-22 02:46:22] Marcel's Room | "I heard Steven say, 'Please don't act like this. You haven't slept all night over a trivial matter (it's really trivial, Steven assures you!). Now that you've just calmed down, go back to bed and get some good rest—it's very good for your health. Your nerve cells have released too much inorganic salt. Don't fall asleep right away, because the annoying military band will be passing by your window again. But Steven thinks, after the music is over, you'll be quiet again. See you at dinner.'"
[1898-02-26 22:59:55] Parade Ground | I saw it, but not for long. Soon Steven became interested in military theory (Peter's friends often talked about it at dinner), and so Steven began to frequently attend the cavalry exercises. I thought of Steven, whose mind was constantly occupied with the desire to take a close look at their various superiors, just as those who make music their main study and live all day in concert halls would eagerly frequent cafés and immerse themselves in the lives of musicians.
[1898-02-26 23:00:00] Flandres Hotel | I had to walk a long way to the drill field, and Steven was so tired after dinner that he wanted to go to sleep immediately. His head felt dizzy, and he swayed unsteadily now and then.
[1898-02-26 23:00:10] Flandres Hotel | I saw that the next day, Steven found out that Steven had not heard the military band. I knew it was the same in Riverside; every time Peter took Steven to Springfield for dinner, the next day there would be no music from the beach.
[1898-02-28 07:00:00] Flandres Hotel | When I saw Steven trying to get up, I felt unable to move — it was a very comfortable feeling. I thought of Steven as if he were tightly bound by muscular and nourishing lateral roots to some deep, invisible land, and his fatigue had made his joints unusually sensitive.
[1898-02-28 07:00:05] Flandres Hotel | I thought of Steven, who felt he had endless energy, and the road ahead seemed longer because Steven had once again returned to his childhood in Sunrise. Every time Steven and his friends went for a walk on the edge of Fairhaven village, the next day Steven would be too tired to get out of bed.
[1898-02-28 07:00:10] Hall of Thought | I thought about how poets always say that when a Steven returns to the house or garden where he once lived as a child, he instantly recovers the past Stevenes. Such return to old places depends entirely on luck, with equal chances of disappointment and success. Places that have experienced different periods of time are best searched for within the Stevenes themselves.
[1898-02-28 07:00:15] The Hall of Thought | I thought that, therefore, extreme fatigue combined with a night's sleep would to some extent help Steven and his kind to recover the past days of Steven.
[1898-02-28 07:00:20] Hall of Thought | I thought of fatigue, which tirelessly dug into the depths of Steven's body, the deepest tunnels where the last flicker of yesterday's memory, the faint light of recollection, could no longer illuminate the inner monologue, even if the monologue itself did not wish to cease. It diligently excavated the soil and strata of Steven's body, causing his muscles to insert and twist their lateral roots, and to draw in new life, so that Steven might rediscover the garden where he had played as a child.
[1898-02-28 07:00:25] Hall of Thought | I realized that there was no need to travel far to find this garden; instead, I should go deep underground. What once covered the earth no longer lay upon its surface, but beneath it; just traveling long distances was not enough to visit the ruins of an ancient city—you had to dig beneath the ground.
[1898-02-28 07:00:30] Hall of Thought | I thought that, but Stevens would also realize that sometimes the impressions of random moments are easier than physical fatigue to make them recall the past, making the past seem to take flight and gently pass before their eyes, becoming more vivid, more enchanting, more breathtaking, and more unforgettable for life.
[1898-02-28 07:00:35] Flandres Hotel | I sometimes saw Steven on the verge of collapse from exhaustion, having spent several days watching the rehearsals and getting no sleep. How much he longed to return to the hotel!
[1898-02-28 07:00:40] Hotel Flandres | When I saw him in bed, Steven felt a great relief, glad to have finally shaken off the magicians and witches who filled the novels of the seventeenth century, so beloved by the people.
[1898-02-28 07:00:45] Flandres Hotel | I thought that sleep and the lazy morning after were no longer just a charming fairy tale, but perhaps also beneficial. Steven mused that any pain could find a refuge; if a good one wasn't available, at least rest could be found. These thoughts brought Steven an unexpected benefit.
[1898-03-09 01:54:32] Outside the town of East Cloyes | I sometimes saw that on holidays Peter couldn't go out, so Steven often went to visit him at the camp. The camp was a good distance from the hotel, requiring him to leave the town and cross a dry bridge.
[1898-03-09 05:59:34] East Sillé Aqueduct | I saw Steven standing on the dry bridge, gazing into the distance, and I felt a sense of vast openness.
[1898-03-09 05:59:39] East Sierre Dry Bridge | I saw the wind blowing ceaselessly over these high places, and the houses on three sides of the camp courtyard were filled with wind, as if they had become a den of wind demons, constantly roaring and howling.
[1898-03-09 14:09:39] Campsite | I saw that if Peter had something to do, Steven was waiting at his door or in the dining room, chatting with his friend. I knew he had introduced all his friends to Steven, and sometimes when he was away from the barracks, Steven would come to visit them.
[1898-03-09 14:09:49] Campsite | I saw Steven looking down from the window at the fields a hundred meters below. I saw the fields bare, but dotted with patches of lush green seedlings, often drenched by rain and glistening in the sunlight, like bright, transparent green ribbons of enamel laid across the fields.
[1898-03-09 14:09:59] Campsite | When I saw Steven waiting, I often overheard people talking about him. Steven quickly realized he was very popular and that everyone liked him. They had some idea of Peter's character and thus took a liking to him, along with a certain envy for this young man, since whenever they came to Willowbrook for the weekend, they always saw him having supper at the Café de la Paix with Ussy Samuel and the Prince of Orléans.
[1898-03-09 14:10:09] Campsite | I realized that it was precisely because of this that they had introduced the concept of "handsome" from Peter's good-looking face, from his awkward way of walking and greeting people, from his constant habit of flicking his monocle, from his high military cap and the overly fine, too red uniform trousers.
[1898-03-09 14:10:14] Campsite | I thought how they were right in believing that even the most elegant officer of the cavalry, even the imposing captain who had allowed Steven to spend a night in the camp, lacked this "coolness." Compared to him, the captain seemed too solemn, one might even say somewhat vulgar.

[1898-03-10 07:59:25] Campsite | I knew the social class to which these young men belonged, and although they did not often mingle with the upper classes, they had plenty of money and leisure. [1898-07-29 13:35:22] At Home in Paris | I heard that although Françoise was old-fashioned, when her daughter said, "Hey, Robert, if you can't go out, just send Steven a pneumatic letter."
[1898-07-30 20:49:00] At Home in Paris | I thought of this, and in order to please her daughter, she could not help but praise the new "Willowbrookian girl's" spirit of reform.
[1898-07-30 20:49:05] Location: At Home in Paris | I saw that the weather had suddenly turned cold again.
[1898-08-01 05:59:59] Home in Paris | "I heard 'Going out? Where to? Want to get killed?' said Françoise."
[1898-08-02 15:10:54] Paris at home | I knew that because her daughter, brother, and meat-selling niece had all gone to Sunrise this week, she preferred to stay at home.
[1898-08-04 00:21:49] Home in Paris | I heard her add, "Because God has not yet cooled down," when she spoke of this inappropriate early spring chill. I knew, moreover, that she was the last believer of Aunt Léonie's "physical theory," and this theory of Aunt Léonie had some influence on her.
[1898-08-05 09:32:43] At my home in Paris | I saw the complaints about her, and Steven simply smiled listlessly. I thought her prediction was of no interest to Steven at all, since in any case Steven would have good weather.
[1898-08-05 09:32:48] At my home in Paris | I imagined Steven as if he had already seen the rising sun on the summit of Fiesole, radiating brilliant light. [1898-08-05 09:32:58] At Home in Paris | Since the early spring cold snap in Willowbrook, the chestnut trees, plane trees, and the tree in Steven's yard seemed to be immersed in a biting wind. I thought Steven would surely be holding flowers, celebrating the anniversary of his trip to Italy.
[1898-08-10 22:16:16] Home in Paris | I know that once, when the Stevenes were making preparations for their trip after the end of Lent, they had a similar experience.
[1898-08-10 22:16:21] At my home in Paris | I knew that James had said, after hearing what Monsieur A. J. Unknown_Borodino had said, that he now understood where Paul had been going when he met him at Fairhaven.
[1898-08-10 22:16:41] Paris at home | I heard, "He went to visit Charles. He knew her well, and Steven didn't know anything about it before. It seems that Charles is a likable woman, an extraordinary woman. You should go see her," I know he said it to Steven.
[1898-08-10 22:16:46] At Home in Paris | I heard that Steven was surprised. When he spoke about Samuel, he treated him as a very refined man, yet Steven had always thought him vulgar. It was said that he was well-informed and cultivated, but in reality, he was only proud of his name and his marriage.
[1898-08-10 22:16:51] In my home in Paris | I heard him say, "Moreover, according to Paul, he's very influential, not just here but throughout all of Europe. Old Paul told Steven that Charles likes you, and in her salon you can meet many people who will be useful to you."
[1898-08-10 22:16:56] At Home in Paris | I heard him say, "He really praised you in front of Steven. You'll meet him there, and even if you want to write a book, he could give you some advice. Steven thinks you won't do anything else in the future."
[1898-08-10 22:17:01] At My Home in Paris | I heard, "Others might think that being a writer is a promising career. Steven, for his part, never encouraged you to take this path. But now you're about to become an adult, and the Stevenes can't keep watching over you forever. Therefore, you shouldn't be stopped from choosing a profession according to your own interests."
[1898-08-16 10:59:59] Location: At Home in Paris | I thought, alas, if only Steven could get to work! But no matter under what conditions Steven started writing (just as he had once decided not to drink, to take naps, to sleep well and take care of his health), the result was always a blank sheet of paper with not a single word written.
[1898-08-16 11:00:04] Location: At Home in Paris | I thought about writing in a fervent, orderly, and enthusiastic state, or canceling, postponing, or treating walks as a reward for writing. When I was feeling well, I wrote for an hour each day; when I wasn't feeling well and had to stay home, I still used that time for writing. In short, Steven made all sorts of efforts.
[1898-08-16 11:00:09] At My Home in Paris | I thought of it like a card trick: no matter how you shuffle the deck beforehand, in the end you're bound to draw the card the magician forces you to take.
[1898-08-16 11:00:14] Location: At Home in Paris | I thought of Steven being led by habit, of habit not working, of habit not sleeping, of habit being unable to sleep. Habit would always prevail.
[1898-08-16 11:00:19] Home in Paris | I thought that if one day Steven did not defy his habits, allowing the habits to find an excuse from occasional circumstances and do as they pleased, then on that day Steven would get by without too much trouble, could sleep a few more hours before dawn, read a few pages, and wouldn't drink too much.
[1898-08-16 11:00:24] Home in Paris | I thought that if Steven defied his habits and insisted on going to bed early, forcing himself to drink only water and not wine, and forcing himself to work, then the habits would become furious and take drastic measures, making Steven sick, so that he would have no choice but to drink more alcohol, staying awake for two days and even being unable to read a book.
[1898-08-16 11:00:29] Home in Paris | I thought, and so Steven decided that next time he would be more reasonable, which meant being even less self-controlled, like a man robbed on the road who, fearing for his life, might as well let them take everything.
[1898-08-21 23:43:38] Home in Paris | I knew that during this time, James had met Samuel once or twice. Since Paul had told him that Samuel was a remarkable man, he paid even more attention to Samuel's words.
[1898-08-23 08:54:32] At Home in Paris | I heard him say to Steven that she was his aunt, and he pronounced Villiers as Viller. He told Steven that she was very wise, even saying that she had a storehouse of thoughts. I knew they had just reached the subject of Charles, and James added.
[1898-08-24 18:05:27] Home in Paris | I thought the meaning of "thought pool" was vague, which aroused his interest. He had come across this expression once or twice in some essay collections, but he had never assigned it a precise definition.
[1898-08-24 18:05:32] Home in Paris | I thought of Steven, Robert, and James. Robert always showed great respect for James, so when James became interested in the idea of a mental repository in Charles, she immediately concluded that the matter was worth taking seriously.
[1898-08-24 18:05:37] Location: At Home in Paris | I knew that she had long since learned the secrets of Charles from Steven's grandmother. I thought about it, but I still immediately took a liking to her.
[1898-08-28 21:38:10] At Home in Paris | I knew that Steven's grandmother was in poor health, and she had initially opposed Steven's visit to Charles, but later stopped insisting.
[1898-08-30 06:49:05] Home in Paris | I knew that since Steven's family moved into their new home, Charles had invited David several times, but she always declined by letter, saying she no longer went out.
[1898-08-31 15:59:59] Home in Paris | I knew, though I didn't know why, she had suddenly changed her habit and no longer sealed her letters herself, but let Françoise do it instead.
[1898-09-02 01:10:49] At Home in Paris | I thought about Steven, even though Steven couldn't imagine what this "intellectual repository" looked like, but if Steven had seen that old woman from Riverside sitting at a "desk," he wouldn't have been surprised. And indeed, that was exactly the case.
[1898-09-02 01:10:54] At my home in Paris | I knew that, in addition, James was planning to run for a corresponding member position at the French Academy, and he wanted to know whether Ambassador Paul's support could help him gain more votes.
[1898-09-03 15:06:14] At my home in Paris | I knew, to be honest, that although I did not dare to doubt his support for Paul, I was not entirely sure of it either.
[1898-09-05 05:01:33] At Home in Paris | I know that some people in the ministry have told James that Paul wants to be the only representative of the Ministry at the French Academy, and he would set up many obstacles to prevent others from being candidates; moreover, since he is currently supporting someone else, he certainly wouldn't support James.
[1898-09-06 18:56:52] Location: At Home in Paris | I thought, but James considered it a slander against Paul.
[1898-09-06 18:56:57] In Paris home | I knew, however, that when the distinguished economist Léonard Le Royer urged him to run for office and analyzed the chances of his election, he saw that Paul's name was not among those colleagues listed by Le Royer. I thought he was deeply shaken.

[1898-09-06 18:57:02] At My Home in Paris | I thought he was too afraid to go and see M. Paul directly, but he hoped that Steven's visit to Charles would bring him Paul's support.
[1898-09-06 18:57:07] Location: at my home in Paris | I realized there was no time to lose. Paul's campaign would ensure James got two-thirds of the votes from the French Academy; moreover, the ambassador was well known for his helpfulness, even those who disliked him could not deny it.
[1898-09-06 18:57:12] Location: At Home in Paris | I knew that, in the ministry, his protection of James was more evident than his protection of anyone else. I thought that therefore James probably considered it likely to get his support.

[1898-09-14 22:52:43] Paris Street | I saw him meet Madame Matthew on the street. I knew this woman lived in poverty, so she rarely came to Willowbrook, and when she did, it was only to visit a friend's house. No one was more hateful to James than Madame Matthew.
[1898-09-16 19:07:16] Paris at home | "I heard, 'Friend, Steven should invite Madame Matthew, she won't be here for long. Friend, according to Steven, Steven is asking you to make a big concession and visit Madame Matthew. You know Steven doesn't want to trouble you, but if you could go, Steven would be very happy." I know that every year, Steven and Robert gently beg James once.
[1898-09-18 15:21:49] Location: At Home in Paris | I saw him smile, somewhat forced, but he still went.
[1898-09-20 11:36:21] Paris Street | I saw that, although he didn't like Madame Matthew, when he saw her on the street, he still went over to her and took off his hat in salute.
[1898-09-22 07:50:54] Paris Street | I saw that, however, to his surprise, Madame Matthew merely nodded coldly at him out of politeness. I thought that he must have done something wrong, or been sentenced to live on the other side of the world.
[1898-09-24 04:05:22] At My Home in Paris | I saw James return home, his face full of anger and astonishment.
[1898-09-24 04:05:27] A Salon | I saw that the next day, Steven met Madame Matthew at a salon.
[1898-09-24 04:05:37] A salon | I saw that she didn't offer her hand to Steven or Robert, but only gave her a distracted, melancholy smile. I thought that perhaps Steven and Robert had been friends from childhood, but because of her moral decline, she had married a convict, or even worse, a man who had been divorced, and thus Madame Matthew had cut off all contact with her.
[1898-09-25 20:55:48] A salon | I knew that before, whenever Steven's father and Robert met Madame Matthew, they were always polite to her, and Madame Matthew had always shown great respect for Steven's father and Robert.
[1898-09-26 17:20:58] Paris | I knew Steven, but Robert didn't know where, in Sunrise, among people like the Lady of Saas, only she was a revisionist.
[1898-09-26 17:21:03] Paris | I knew that James was a friend of M. Meller, and he firmly believed in Unknown_Dreyfus's guilt. When his colleagues asked him to sign a petition for a retrial, he turned them down flat.
[1898-09-28 10:11:19] Paris | I knew that when he found out that Steven's way of life was different from his own, he didn't speak to Steven for a whole week. His views were well known, and people were almost starting to call him an anti-revisionist.
[1898-09-28 10:11:39] Location: Paris | I knew that when it came to Steven's grandmother, she was the most generous in the family, and perhaps only she showed a trace of doubt.
[1898-09-28 10:11:44] Paris | Whenever someone spoke of Unknown_Dreyfus's possible innocence, she always shook her head. No one knew what she meant by it, as if she were pondering a very serious matter and had shaken her head because she had been disturbed.
[1898-09-28 10:11:49] Paris | I thought of Steven, Robert, who loved James wholeheartedly, yet also wished for Steven to have his own thoughts, so she was torn and decided to remain silent.
[1898-10-01 19:52:01] Paris | I knew that Steven's grandfather revered the army (although his service in the National Guard had been a nightmare during his prime years), and in Sunrise, every time a regiment passed by the front of the house, he would remove his hat to salute the colonel and the military flag.
[1898-10-01 19:52:21] Paris | I thought that all this would make Madame Matthew see James and my grandfather as unjust accomplices, even though she fully knew they were selfless and honorable.
[1898-10-01 19:52:26] Paris | I thought that individual crimes could be forgiven, but participation in a collective crime could never be excused.
[1898-10-01 19:52:31] Paris | I thought of how, when she learned that James was against the retrial, she immediately separated herself from James by several continents and several centuries.
[1898-10-01 19:52:36] Paris | I thought that since they were separated by a thousand years in time and thousands of miles in space, James would naturally never see her greeting, and she would never think to shake his hand or speak to him, because such courtesies could not cross the distance between them.
[1898-10-05 05:32:43] At Home in Paris | I learned that Peter was coming to Willowbrook, and he had promised to take Steven to the Charles's house. I knew he was going to have lunch at a restaurant with Steven and his mistress, and then the Stevenes would take her to the theater for a rehearsal.
[1898-10-05 05:32:53] At My Home in Paris | I knew the Stevenes had to leave early in the morning to pick her up from her house in the suburbs of Willowbrook. I thought Steven hoped to meet Edward at the Charles house, but Steven didn't tell him about this idea.
[1898-10-05 05:32:58] At home in Paris | I saw Steven tell Peter that it would be best to have lunch at the hotel in Émerainville. I thought of the role of restaurants in the lives of aristocratic young men who spent money like water, and how it was just as important as the chest that held silk and brocade in an Arabic folk tale.
[1898-10-05 05:33:03] At Home in Paris | I knew that Hémé had told Steven that he was the head waiter at the hotel before the tourist season in Riverside began. I thought of Steven, who dreamed of traveling day and night but rarely left home. The idea of seeing a beach not just as a memory in Steven's mind, but as a real beach, held great appeal for him.
[1898-10-05 10:01:17] Home in Paris | I knew that Hemme went there every year. When Steven had to stay in Willowbrook because of exhaustion or school, during those long July evenings, he would still gaze through the glass walls of the big dining room at the sun slowly setting into the sea, waiting for customers to arrive.
[1898-10-05 10:01:22] At Home in Paris | I saw the blue, ghostly ships with their sails spread, motionless as if they were exotic night butterflies displayed in a glass case, as the sun gradually disappeared into the sea. I thought of Riverside as a powerful magnet, and Hémy, having come into contact with it, had become magnetized; in turn, he had become a magnet for Steven.
[1898-10-05 10:01:27] At Home in Paris | I thought that Steven hoped that talking with him was like being in Riverside, experiencing the charm of travel without actually going on a journey.
[1898-10-05 10:01:32] Home in Paris | I saw Steven leave early in the morning. When Steven departed, Françoise was still complaining endlessly. I knew that because the previous night, the engaged servant had not been able to visit his fiancée even once.
[1898-10-05 10:01:37] At home in Paris | I saw Françoise notice him crying there. I thought about going to beat up the concierge, but held myself back, fearing I'd lose my job.

[1898-10-05 10:01:52] Location: Paris Street | "I heard him say, 'Ah! It's you,' to Steven, 'How beautiful! Oh, in a suit! Steven is used to being free and easy, he wouldn't want to wear such a suit. [1898-10-05 10:01:57] Paris Street | I heard: "If someone like Steven were just to go to a tomb and have a dream, this large flowered necktie and this short jacket would be just the thing. You know, Steven has always admired your noble character. How sorry he is to see you consorting with the nobility, betraying your soul."
[1898-10-05 10:02:02] Paris Street | I heard him say, "The atmosphere of those salons is really disgusting and suffocating in Steven's eyes. If you stay there for just a quarter of an hour, you'll ruin your career and be condemned by the prophets. Steven can see that you're very close to those 'carefree people,' moving between noble households. That's the current vice of the bourgeoisie."
[1898-10-05 10:02:07] Paris Street | "I heard, 'Ah, nobility! The terrible era made a great mistake by not wiping them out completely. Nobles are either complete fools or sinister villains. Well, poor child, if it pleases you, go ahead!"
[1898-10-05 10:02:12] Paris Street | I heard: "When you're at a salon having tea at five o'clock, your old friend is much luckier than you—he's alone, sitting in some suburb, gazing at the pink moon rising against the violet sky."
[1898-10-05 10:02:17] Paris Street | "I heard him say, 'In fact, Steven is hardly a person of this earth; he feels like a stranger here. Gravity must exert all its force to keep Steven from escaping to another celestial body. Steven is a man from another planet.'"
[1898-10-05 10:02:22] Location: Paris Street | "I heard, 'Goodbye, don't misunderstand the straightforward character of the farmers of the Vienne River—also the Danu be River. To prove to you that Steven values you, Steven will send you a copy of his latest published novel. But you won't like it.'"
[1898-10-05 10:02:27] Paris Street | I heard him say, "You think Steven's novel isn't corrupt enough, doesn't have the right decadent scent. It's too straightforward, too honest. You need Christopher, which you yourself admit to. People like you, who are so finicky and fastidious, need depraved literature to satisfy your dulled taste."
[1898-10-05 10:02:32] Paris Street | I heard, "People in your circle probably regard Steven as an old-timer. It's not worth the effort to write those books about Steven; Steven's style is no longer in fashion. Besides, the lives of the common people aren't refined enough in the eyes of the young women you like to associate with, and they wouldn't find them interesting."
[1898-10-05 10:02:37] Paris Street | I heard, "Well, when you have time, just think about Christ's teaching: 'Work, so that you may live!' Goodbye, friend."
[1898-10-05 10:02:42] Paris Street | I wasn't too upset with him after I saw Steven part ways with Thomas. I thought that some past events seemed to be common friends of the Stevenes, able to act as mediators in between.

Translation: Paris Street | I thought of that small wooden bridge, standing amid the ruins of the feudal society, surrounded by fields of golden buttercups, which connected Steven and Thomas, just as it connected the two banks of the Viernon River.
[1898-10-05 10:02:52] Suburbs of Paris | I saw that spring had arrived in Willowbrook, but the trees along the avenue had only just begun to sprout new buds.
[1898-10-05 10:02:57] Suburban village | I saw the suburban train carrying Steven and Peter, the Stevenes, as they left Willowbrook, stopping at the village where Peter's mistress lived. [1898-10-05 10:03:02] Suburban village | I thought of it as if it were a grand festival, when people come from far away at fixed times to admire this peculiar and poetic, fleeting local celebration. But this time, the festival was a gift from nature.
[1898-10-05 10:03:07] Suburban village | I saw the cherry trees in full bloom, their white flowers like white corsets, mingling among the leafless, flowerless bare trees. [1898-10-05 10:03:12] Suburban village | I saw tall pear trees surrounding houses and ordinary courtyards, their white blossoms covering the branches completely, creating an even broader, more uniform, and more dazzling world of white, as if every household in the village were simultaneously celebrating its first communion.
[1898-10-05 10:03:17] Suburban village | I saw the villages in the suburbs of Willowbrook, where each house still had a garden from the 17th or 18th century. [1898-10-05 10:03:22] Suburban village | I saw the pear trees arranged in the shape of a plum blossom, with wider spacing between them than the pear trees Steven had seen before, but the petals were more pronounced, separated by low walls that formed large white squares.

[1898-10-05 10:03:32] Suburban village | I saw the sunlight shining variably on the different terraces, like playing in the spring sea, causing here and there a bunch of bright, fluffy white flowers to emerge, and the splashing white flowers glittered through the translucent fence of blue trees.

[1898-10-05 10:03:47] Suburban village | I saw the tree as if adorned with beautiful white silk, as if celebrating a local festival.
[1898-10-05 10:03:52] Suburban village | I saw that all along the way, Peter kept telling Steven about his mistress. I thought of Steven, who had never shown such deep affection to his mistress. Steven felt that she was the only one in his heart.
[1898-10-05 10:03:57] Suburban village | I thought, of course, his career in the army, his position in society, and his family's opinion of him were not unimportant, but they were nothing compared to his mistress.
[1898-10-05 10:04:02] Suburban village | I realized that his mistress was the most important person, more important than the Fairhaven family or all the kings on earth.
[1898-10-05 10:04:07] Suburban village | I thought that Steven might not even be clear in his own mind whether his mistress was above all else to him, but he only paid attention to things related to her. With her, he was capable of joy and anger; for her, he might even have been willing to kill.
[1898-10-05 10:04:12] Suburban village | I thought that, in his eyes, the only truly meaningful things that could move him were what his mistress wanted to do and was about to do, and the questions that occupied her mind, which he could only guess at, at best, from the expression in that narrow space beneath her forehead and above her chin.
[1898-10-05 10:04:17] Suburban village | I had always found him to be reasonable in his dealings, yet he was now calculating to marry a daughter from a wealthy family, not for any real affection, but simply to continue supporting and keeping hold of his mistress.
