[1898-10-05 10:04:22] Suburban village | I thought he didn't marry her because, out of a pragmatic instinct, he knew that once she no longer had any expectations of him, she would leave him, at least living as she pleased. [1898-10-05 10:04:52] Suburban village | I heard her say, "She might not be very talkative in front of you, but Steven is already feeling happy just thinking about how she'll one day talk to Steven about her impressions of you. [1898-10-05 10:05:37] Suburban village | I saw the pear blossoms trembling and convulsing in the cold wind, yet they were coated with a shimmering silver light, forming a tangible, touchable veil of light.
[1898-10-05 10:05:42] Suburban village | I saw, suddenly, Peter appeared before Steven, accompanied by his mistress. [1898-10-05 10:05:47] Suburban village | I saw Peter and felt that I would never truly understand her; he often asked himself, "What is hidden behind her, behind her gaze and her flesh?" I thought of this woman, and Steven immediately recognized her as Brian.
[1898-10-05 10:05:52] Suburban village | I knew that a few years ago, she had told the madam of a brothel (a woman, once she changes her circumstances, does so with an astonishing speed): "Then it's settled, Steven will be free tomorrow; if anyone comes, please don't forget to call Steven."
[1898-10-05 10:05:57] Suburban village | I know that when there were really guests "to see her," and she was left alone with this "guest" in the room, she was so experienced that, after locking the door—out of a woman's caution or out of habit—she would immediately start taking off her clothes, moving very quickly, as if a doctor were about to examine her.
[1898-10-05 10:06:02] Suburban village | I knew that she had stopped halfway only because this "guest" disliked nudity, and she had been told not to take off her undergarments (like some doctors who are sensitive to sound yet also afraid of their patients catching cold, listening to their lungs and heart through their clothes).
[1898-10-05 10:06:07] Suburban village | I thought about the woman's life, her thoughts and past, which men had possessed her body, all of which seemed so insignificant to Steven. If she were to tell Steven these things, he would listen out of politeness, but hardly pay any attention.

[1898-10-05 10:06:17] Suburban village | I thought of these two Brian's, who had nothing to do with each other (because Steven had met Brian in a brothel), and suddenly it occurred to Steven that men live for women, suffer for them, even commit suicide for them, but many of them are Brians, and their value to others is no different from Brian's value to Steven.

text:
[1898-10-05 10:06:22] Suburban village | I thought about how some people approach life with a sense of curiosity and sorrow, and Steven was stunned by this. Steven could have told Peter that Brian often slept with other people; in Steven's eyes, it was nothing serious, but it would have caused Peter so much pain!
[1898-10-05 10:06:27] Suburban village | I thought about all the things he had done just to find out with whom she had slept. In the end, it was all for nothing!
[1898-10-05 10:06:32] Suburban village | I thought to myself that Steven realized, if a man comes to know a woman through imagination, he would imagine that behind her small face lies an infinite number of beautiful things; conversely, if he meets her in the crudest way, the things he longs for might break down into insignificant, meaningless material components.
[1898-10-05 10:06:37] Suburban village | I thought to myself that Steven realized, in Steven's eyes, a woman he paid twenty francs for at a brothel was nothing more than a woman who wanted twenty francs, and in fact she wasn't worth twenty francs.
[1898-10-05 10:06:42] Suburban village | I thought, but if Steven had at the outset imagined her as a wonderful and mysterious woman, difficult to obtain and even harder to keep by his side, then she would have become an invaluable treasure, more precious than any enviable status, even more than the warmth of family.
[1898-10-05 10:06:47] Suburban village | I thought it was interesting that Steven and Peter saw the same thin, elongated face, but Stevens approached her from two opposite roads that would never cross, and the Stevenes would never see the same face.
[1898-10-05 10:06:52] Suburban village | I thought of this face, its look, its smile, the movement of its mouth—Steven had known it from the outside. This face was no different from that of any woman who would sell her body to Steven for twenty francs.
[1898-10-05 10:06:57] Suburban village | I thought that the look, smile, and movements of the mouth on this face were, to Steven, merely ordinary gestures, without personality or meaning, and Steven had no interest in trying to find out which particular person they belonged to.
[1898-10-05 10:07:02] Suburban village | I thought that, to say, what Steven had from the beginning—the face that could be touched and kissed—was for Peter a final goal. How great were his hopes, doubts, suspicions, and dreams as he approached this goal!
[1898-10-05 10:07:07] Suburban village | Yes, I thought, for the woman who sold her body for twenty francs, Peter had paid not just millions, but far more to keep her from falling into someone else's hands!
[1898-10-05 10:07:12] Suburban village | I thought about how he spent so much money, yet sometimes still failed, perhaps because of some unexpected situation, and the woman who had intended to give herself to him suddenly ran away, or perhaps she had another appointment, or something happened that made her particularly difficult that day.
[1898-10-05 10:07:17] Suburban village | I thought that if she were dealing with a sentimental man, even if she wasn't aware of it, and especially if she was aware, there would be a terrible chase.
[1898-10-05 10:07:22] Suburban village | I thought of this sentimental man, discouraged yet unable to do without this woman, chasing her relentlessly while she struggled desperately to escape. In his quest for a single smile, a smile he dared not hope to receive again, he would pay a price a thousand times greater than the cost of winning a woman's body.
[1898-10-05 10:07:27] Suburban village | I thought that in such situations, sometimes due to a mistake in judgment or cowardice before pain, you might passionately regard a prostitute as an untouchable idol, and thus you would never be able to obtain her tenderness, never even get her first kiss, and you wouldn't even dare to ask for it, fearing that you would violate your belief in this Platonic spiritual love.
[1898-10-05 10:07:32] Suburban village | I thought of how painful it must have been for you, not even having had the chance to taste the kiss of the woman you loved, when you left this world. But Peter was luckier; he had experienced every tender affection Brian had to offer.
[1898-10-05 10:07:37] Suburban village | I thought, of course, that if he now knew his mistress had sold her body for a single louis to any man, he might feel an agonizing pain, but in order not to lose her favor, he would still pay her a million francs.
[1898-10-05 10:07:42] Suburban village | I thought that because what he knew was not enough to make him return to his senses (important matters for people are often not under their own control, but governed by some natural law), he still imagined her face in a dream, and thus could not see her true face.
[1898-10-05 10:07:47] Suburban village | I saw her thin face now motionless, expressionless. I thought of myself as a piece of paper subjected to two immense atmospheric pressures, maintained in balance by two infinite forces. Both forces converged on her, but never met, because she stood between them.
[1898-10-05 10:07:52] Suburban village | I saw Steven and Peter both staring at her, each seeing a different mystery in her. I thought that Steven did not consider Brian particularly remarkable, but rather believed that human imagination and fantasy possessed great power, and that the pain of love was caused by human fantasy.
[1898-10-05 10:07:57] Suburban village | I saw Peter realize that Steven was excited. Steven turned his head to look at the pear and cherry trees in the opposite garden, so that Peter would believe it was the beauty of the fruit trees that had moved Steven. I thought, and indeed, these beautiful scenes did move Steven's heart, presenting to him not only things to be seen with the eyes, but also things to be felt with the heart.
[1898-10-05 10:08:02] Suburban village | I thought that Steven might have regarded these fruit trees in the garden as unseen angels, just as he might have misrecognized someone like Robert. On the day of Jesus' resurrection, it was also in a garden that Robert saw a figure and "thought it was a gardener."
[1898-10-05 10:08:07] Suburban village | I thought, how could these admirable young girls in white, who bend their bodies under the shade of trees suitable for napping, fishing, and reading, not be angels? These young girls preserve the memory of the golden age for Stevenes, assuring them that reality is not as beautiful as people imagine, but if Stevenes strive to be worthy of it, reality might, in return, shine with a poetic, pure, and wondrous light.
[1898-10-05 10:08:12] Suburban village | I saw Steven and Peter's mistress exchange a few words. Steven and his companions took a shortcut through the village. The houses were dirty. I saw him, and even before the filthiest, as if scorched by acid rain, houses, there stood a mysterious traveler, staying for a day in this cursed town.
[1898-10-05 10:08:22] Suburban village | I saw this radiant, glorious angel, spreading dazzling white wings to protect a filthy house: this was a pear tree covered with white blossoms.
[1898-10-05 12:29:55] Suburban village | I saw Peter and Steven take a few steps forward. I heard, "Steven wasn't planning to come here. The Stevens were waiting for her in town. Steven would even have preferred having lunch with you alone, staying alone until it was time to go to Steven's grandmother's house."
[1898-10-05 12:30:00] Suburban village | "I heard, 'But that poor girl, how much she wanted Steven to come and pick her up! She was so good to Steven, you know, Steven couldn't refuse her. Besides, she'd be pleasant company—she has a literary talent and is very emotional. And it's very pleasant to have lunch with her at the hotel. She's so lovely, so down-to-earth, always satisfied with everything.'"
[1898-10-05 12:30:05] Suburban village | I thought, but Steven believed that that very morning, perhaps for the only time, Peter had momentarily freed himself from the woman he had slowly constructed through a series of tender impressions, and suddenly saw another Brian standing not far away, identical in appearance to his Brian, yet a completely different person—a silly little prostitute.

[1898-10-05 22:37:25] Station | After leaving the pleasant orchard, the Stevenes went to catch the train back to Willowbrook. At the station, Brian walked ahead of the Stevenes, a few steps away.
[1898-10-05 22:37:35] Train Station | I saw, suddenly, two other vulgar "hens" like her recognized her. Thinking she was alone, they started shouting noisily. [1898-10-05 22:37:40] Train Station | I saw them about to introduce their lovers—two "department store clerks" standing beside them—to her, when I noticed Brian looking slightly uneasy. Curious, I glanced aside and spotted the Stevenes. I quickly apologized and said goodbye to her.
[1898-10-05 22:37:50] Train Station | I saw her say goodbye to them as well, a bit awkward but very friendly. I knew they were two pitiful little hens, the scarf was made of fake mink. When Peter first met Brian, she was about the same age.
[1898-10-05 22:38:00] Train Station | I thought that Peter didn't know them, nor did he know their names. Seeing how closely they were connected to his mistress, I suddenly felt suspicion: his mistress might have once led, and perhaps still led, a life that was hidden from view, a life completely different from both his and hers, a life of selling her body for a single louis.
[1898-10-05 22:38:05] Train Station | I thought that not only did he vaguely see this life, but also vaguely saw another Brian, an unfamiliar Brian, a Brian like those two hens, a Brian worth twenty francs.
[1898-10-05 22:38:10] Train Station | I thought that, in the end, he felt Brian had split in two, and beside his Brian he faintly saw the little chicken Brian, the real Brian— if one could say that the chicken Brian was more real than the other Brian.
[1898-10-05 22:38:15] Train Station | I thought that at this very moment, Peter might be thinking that he had intended to make a deal by using his noble lineage, marrying a wealthy girl so he could continue to support Brian with ten thousand francs a year. Now it seemed there was no longer any need for that. He could easily escape from the hell of his current life by spending just a little money to please his mistress, just like those two shop assistants who had bought the favor of those two prostitutes for very little money.
[1898-10-05 22:38:20] Train Station | What could I do? She had no fault at all. He gave her too little money, and her enthusiasm for him would fade; she wouldn't anymore whisper those sweet words that drove him wild.
[1898-10-05 22:38:25] Train Station | I knew that in order to show off, he often read his mistress's letters to his colleagues, letting them know how tender she was, but never revealing how much he spent supporting her. I thought that no matter what she gave him--a dedication on a photo, or the final polite words in a telegram--these simplest and most precious forms of language were all transformed into money.
[1898-10-05 22:38:30] Train Station | I thought that even if he didn't mention that Brian's rare displays of tenderness were bought at a high price, the Stevenes couldn't possibly think he was acting out of pride and vanity, although this simple and one-sided reasoning is often absurdly applied to all lovers who support women financially and to so many husbands.
[1898-10-05 22:38:35] Train Station | I thought Peter was no fool. He knew that all the pleasures which satisfy vanity could be easily obtained by him, without cost, thanks to his noble birth and handsome face; on the contrary, his ambiguous relationship with Brian could only distance him from the upper class and make him less valued in people's eyes.
[1898-10-05 22:38:40] Train Station | I thought of his desire to show, without spending a penny, the tender affection he had won from his lover—that was nothing more than a byproduct of love, a need to demonstrate to himself as well as to others that he was deeply loved by the one he cherished.
[1898-10-05 22:38:45] Train Station | I saw Brian walking toward Steven and the others, and the two women also got into the car. I thought of Lucienne and Sylvie, whose names, like their fake mink scarves and the affected mannerisms of department store clerks, briefly sustained the image of the new Brian.
[1898-10-05 22:38:50] Train Station | I thought that at this very moment, Peter imagined Willowbrook as a life of the Place de l'Étoile, with unfamiliar friends, dirty money, and aimless afternoons of pleasure; he seemed to feel that the sun on the streets connecting the Champs-Élysées was no longer as bright and radiant as when he used to walk there with his mistress, because love, along with the inevitable suffering that goes with it, can make Steven's senses more refined, just like sobriety after drunkenness.
[1898-10-05 22:38:55] Train Station | I thought of how he imagined there was another city within Willowbrook; he felt that being with Brian was like exploring a life he knew nothing about, even though when Brian was with him, she seemed like his equal, since their shared life was indeed a part of her real life, even its most precious part, because he gave her an endless amount of money, which could make her girlfriends envious, and also enable her, one day, to save enough to retire to the countryside or join the big theater.
[1898-10-05 22:39:00] Train Station | I thought Peter had wanted to ask her who Lucienne and Sermane were, and what they might tell her if she went to their compartment. I thought about how she would spend the day with her girlfriends. He imagined that, if he and Steven weren't there, they might go to the Olympia Hotel for some more sophisticated entertainment after ice-skating.
[1898-10-05 22:39:05] Train Station | I thought that for a moment, the Hotel Olympia and everything around it—which he had always hated—aroused in him both curiosity and pain; the bright springtime on Comte de Martel Street stirred up a faint sense of nostalgia. If Brian had not known him, she might have gone there later to earn a louis d'or.
[1898-10-05 22:39:10] Train Station | I thought, but what was the point of asking these questions of Brian? There was no need to ask—he already knew that her answer would either be silence, or a lie, or something that didn't explain anything but would only bring him pain. The two Brians lasted a long time.
[1898-10-05 22:39:15] Train Station | I saw the conductor about to close the door, and Steven's group hurriedly boarded a first-class compartment. I thought of Brian, surrounded by jewels, which made Peter feel once again that she was an invaluable treasure.
[1898-10-06 02:20:10] Train compartment | I saw him caressing her, then fitting her into his heart, silently gazing at her within himself, just as he had always done—except for the moment when he first saw her on the Place de Bessières—when the train started moving.
[1898-10-06 02:20:20] Train compartment | I saw that she indeed had a bit of "literary talent." She talked endlessly to Steven about books, about the new art and Tolstoyism, only pausing occasionally to scold Peter for drinking too much.

[1898-10-06 02:20:35] Train compartment | "I heard 'A deal is a deal, Steven, they've gone very far away.'"
[1898-10-06 02:20:40] Train Carriage | "I heard, 'But you know Steven has a lot to do. Besides, what will your family say?'" I knew because she took the art of drama very seriously.

[1898-10-06 05:41:19] Hotel | I was sorry to see that it was Emma who recognized the Stevenes, and she came over to give them a bill, while the high priests of the operetta went to other tables.

[1898-10-06 05:41:29] Hotel | I saw him introduce Steven with great emotion. I saw that he looked intelligent, full of energy, and polite in his manner. I knew because he was a man with strong family values.
[1898-10-06 05:41:39] Hotel | I saw Peter's mistress begin to gaze at him intently. I saw that Emile's sunken eyes were deeply set in a face devoid of expression, revealing no reaction. His slight myopia made his gaze appear inscrutable and impassive.

[1898-10-07 04:33:37] Backstage at the theater | "I heard, 'No one can give it to you, because Steven had Boulanger keep it for Steven, and he promised not to sell it to anyone other than Steven.'"
[1898-10-07 04:33:42] Backstage at the theater | "I heard, 'Exactly, you want to swindle Steven, you had everything planned in advance. No wonder they say that Mansart means Mater Semita, this name reeks of Jews!" I knew Brian had made a mistake in her etymology, saying "sheep's path" instead of "Semitic." The retrialists applied this etymology to Peter because he had advocated for the retrial of the Unknown_Dreyfus case.
[1898-10-07 04:33:47] Backstage at the theater | I thought, but Peter's being a reactionary was entirely due to this actress (who was the least qualified of all to call Madame de Mauves a Jew, besides, those social ethnologists had only discovered that Peter's Robert was related to the Jewish Levy-Mirbeau family, and nothing else).
[1898-10-07 04:33:52] Backstage at the theater | "I heard, 'But Steven will find a way to get that necklace, just believe me. Bussolin's promises are worthless in such situations. You've betrayed Steven, and Bussolin will find out. Someone will pay double for his necklace. Don't worry, you'll hear from Steven soon.'"
[1898-10-07 04:33:57] Backstage at the theater | I thought of a hundred reasons for Peter. But things are always so complicated and messy, and someone with a hundred reasons might still be without one once. Steven couldn't help but recall the unpleasant yet innocent words Peter had said at Riverside: "In this way, Steven will be able to control her."
[1898-10-07 04:34:02] Backstage at the theater | "I heard you say, 'You misunderstood Marcel's meaning about the necklace. Marcel isn't making a random wish. Since you've been trying every way to get Marcel to leave you, it's only natural that Marcel wouldn't give you the necklace. Marcel doesn't understand how he's betrayed you. Where is Marcel being selfish? How can you say Marcel is showing off his wealth? Marcel has always told you he's broke, penniless. You're wrong, my dear Marcel. You know full well that Marcel's only concern has always been you."
[1898-10-07 04:34:07] Backstage at the theater | I saw her mock him, making a gesture of contempt, then turned her face toward the dancer. "I heard, 'Yes, yes, go ahead. Oh! His hands were incredible. Steven is a woman, but Steven couldn't make such graceful movements.'"
[1898-10-07 04:34:12] Backstage at the theater | I saw her turn her face toward him, pointing with her finger at Peter's convulsing face. I heard, "You see, he can't take it anymore."
[1898-10-07 04:34:17] Backstage at the theater | I saw her whispering to the dancer. I thought of how a momentary impulse had made her as cruel as a tyrant, yet this was not the true feeling she had for Peter.
[1898-10-07 04:34:22] Backstage at the theater | "I heard, 'Listen, one last time, Steven swears to you that in a week you'll regret it so much you'll beg Steven to come back, but Steven won't come. The glass is already full. Be careful, there's no way to undo it. You'll regret it one day, and then it'll be too late.'"
[1898-10-07 04:34:27] Backstage at the theater | I thought perhaps this was his true feeling. Leaving his mistress was certainly painful for him, but in his eyes, it was better to break up sooner rather than suffer like this by her side.
[1898-10-07 04:34:32] Behind the Theater | I heard, "Dear, don't stay there, Steven is telling you, you'll cough." I know he said it again to Steven.
[1898-10-07 04:34:37] Backstage at the theater | I saw Steven point to the set beside him, meaning that Steven couldn't move. He gently touched his hat on his head and said to the reporter beside him: I heard, "Sir, would you please throw away your cigarette, Steven's friend can't stand the smell of smoke."
[1898-10-07 04:34:42] Backstage at the theater | I saw his mistress leave without waiting for him, heading toward her dressing room. She took a few steps, then turned back.
[1898-10-07 04:34:52] Behind the theater | I saw her pretending to be innocent, shouting in an affected, pleasing voice toward the male dancer in the depths of the stage. I heard, "When he's with a woman, are his little hands just as skillful? You really do look like a woman, Steven believes, and Steven would get along with you just as well as he would with one of Steven's girlfriends."
[1898-10-07 04:34:57] Backstage at the theater | "I heard 'As far as Steven knows, there's no rule against smoking here! If you're sick, you should stay at home!'" I know what the journalist said.
[1898-10-07 04:35:02] Backstage at the theater | I saw the male dancer smile mysteriously at the female comedian.
[1898-10-07 04:35:12] Behind the Theater | I saw her shouting at him. "I heard, 'Ah! Don't speak, you're driving Steven crazy, Steven will go on dates again later!"
[1898-10-07 04:35:17] Behind the theater | I heard, "Anyway, sir, you're not very polite." I thought of Peter's remarks to the journalist, how he remained calm and polite, as if merely confirming a fact, like delivering a post-event verdict on an accident.
[1898-10-07 13:58:39] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw, after a while, a tall old woman entering gracefully. I saw her with a solemn expression, her white hair, styled in the high pile of Marie Antoinette, peeking out from under her curled hat.
[1898-10-07 13:58:49] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I knew these three women came from the same noble background as the Baroness de Charles, but for various reasons (reasons that had long since faded into darkness), only a few forgotten and insignificant people now visited their salons. I thought that at that time, Steven did not know that she was one of the three exceptional ladies still seen in Willowbrook society.
[1898-10-07 13:58:54] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I knew that each of these three ladies had her own "Galmont Edward," which was her niece. This dazzling niece came to pay her respects, but she never managed to draw the other two ladies' "Galmont Edwards" into her aunt's salon.
[1898-10-07 13:59:14] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I knew that Charles was on close terms with these three ladies, but I did not like them. I thought that perhaps because their situation was similar to hers, it might make her feel sad upon seeing them.
[1898-10-07 13:59:19] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I knew that, in addition, they were just as sharp-tongued and learned, and that they hoped to form so-called salons by frequently performing one-act comedies.
[1898-10-07 13:59:39] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I knew the competition between them was fierce, and this rivalry had turned into a struggle for survival, since they had squandered their entire fortunes over the years and were now almost penniless, forced to eke out a living by relying on or exploiting the unpaid assistance of some actor.

text:
[1898-10-07 13:59:59] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I knew that, whenever this lady with the Marie Antoinette hairstyle saw Charles, she inevitably thought of Edward de Fairhaven, who had never attended her Friday gatherings.
[1898-10-07 14:00:04] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I know, but every Friday, her faithful relative Princess de Fairhaven came to visit, which gave her some comfort. This was her "Edward de Fairhaven." Although the Princess de Fairhaven was a good friend of Edward de Fairhaven, she never visited the Charles family.
[1898-10-07 14:00:24] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought that, yet Steven felt a relationship of mutual dependence and mutual hatred bound the three exiled goddesses closely together, from the mansion on the Quai de Malakoff to the salons of Rue Duroc, Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, and Rue des Écoles.
[1898-10-07 14:00:29] The drawing room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I wished I could look up the social mythology dictionary to find out exactly what scandalous affair they had gotten into, which divine law they had violated to deserve such a tragic punishment. Perhaps it was largely because they came from noble families and were now all in difficult circumstances that they had to hate each other while remaining closely entangled.
[1898-10-07 14:00:34] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought to myself, they had all found excellent ways to flatter their guests. Imagine, when they introduced their guests to a lady of high rank, who had a sister married to a certain Count Sagan Samuel or a Prince Ligny, how could their guests fail to feel they had stepped into the most exclusive salon of aristocratic women?
[1898-10-07 14:00:39] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I know, and besides, the newspapers talk all day about these so-called salons, but they rarely report on real ones. Even those nephews and nieces, the so-called "finest" of the upper class (especially Peter), when they hear a fellow student ask them to introduce his friends to the upper class, will say: "Let Steven take you to Steven's Aunt Verdurin's house, or to some other aunt's... it's a very interesting salon."
[1898-10-07 14:00:59] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I knew they clearly understood that introducing a friend to the salon of the Charles family might be easier than taking them to the homes of these ladies' beautiful and refined nieces or sisters-in-law.
[1898-10-07 14:01:19] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I know that some old men and young women told Steven that these elderly women were not accepted by the upper class because of their past behavior, which was too scandalous. When Steven argued that such behavior shouldn't prevent them from being refined, they reminded him that their scandalous conduct exceeded people's imagination today.
[1898-10-07 14:01:39] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought of these solemn, properly seated ladies, whose improper behaviors, once whispered about, took on an unfathomable sense of prehistoric mystery, like that of the mammoth. In short, these three fates with white, blue, or red hair had spun the threads of life for countless men.
[1898-10-07 14:01:44] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought of Steven, who, like modern people, exaggerated the misfortunes of mythological times, just as the Greeks created Icarus, Theseus, and Hercules. Yet these figures had nothing in common with the people who, long afterward, worshipped them as gods.
[1898-10-07 14:01:49] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I thought that people always wait until a person is no longer likely to do wrong before they come to reckon with his past misdeeds, seeing only that he is now suffering social punishment, and then measuring, imagining, even exaggerating the extent of his crimes according to the severity of the punishment.
[1898-10-07 14:01:54] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I knew that she received as many people as she could, not just whoever she wanted, and immoral women dared not enter her salon; the Pope of Northgate often bestowed upon her a "golden rose." She occasionally wrote a book about Lamartine's youth, which had been praised by the French Academy. I thought of the long corridor of symbolist paintings in the "upper society" exhibition, where truly frivolous women, utter sluts, always appeared as an elderly lady, dignified and haughty.
[1898-10-07 14:01:59] The drawing room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Charles speak to the lady with the Marie Antoinette hairstyle, who cast a sharp glance around the drawing room, trying to find a target useful for her salon. I heard "Hello, Alex."
[1898-10-07 14:02:04] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I thought she would have to find out for herself, because there was no doubt that the cunning Charles would never introduce her to someone valuable.
[1898-10-07 14:02:09] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Charles being careful, deliberately not introducing her to Richard. I thought to myself, it's really like that! She was afraid that Richard would take the one-act comedy he had performed at her place and put it on at the Quai de la Malaquerie.
[1898-10-07 14:02:14] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I knew it was just a case of tit for tat. The previous day, the lady on the Malakoff River had invited Madame Léonie to recite poetry, and she kept it a secret from Charles, because this Italian actress had been taken away from her.
[1898-10-07 14:02:34] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought of the lady on the Malakoff embankment, who didn't want Charles to find out about it from the newspaper, and also feared her resentment, so she came to tell her, as if she had done nothing wrong.
[1898-10-07 14:02:39] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Charles tell her Steven's name. I thought she probably believed that Steven was unlike Richard, and introducing Steven to the Mary Antoinette on the riverbank would cause no trouble.
[1898-10-07 14:02:44] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Madame de Bournand trying not to move her body. I knew she wanted to keep her aging appearance in the lines of the Venus of Gavroche (in a distant past, dashing young men had been entranced by her, and even now, many pretenders to literature still praised her in rhymed verses)—besides, she had developed the habit of always posing with an air of haughty dignity.
[1898-10-07 14:02:54] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw her coldly and solemnly give a slight nod, then turn her face away and never look at Steven again, as though Steven didn't exist. I thought that anyone who is specially humiliated and yet forced to approach others will adopt this compensatory expression.
[1898-10-07 14:02:59] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I thought she was killing two birds with one stone, as if saying to Charles, "You see, Steven doesn't care about one or two more connections. Steven isn't interested in young boys. They're always spreading rumors about people."
[1898-10-07 14:03:04] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I saw it, but when she was leaving an hour later, she secretly invited Steven to her compartment for the following Friday, slipping away in the commotion. I thought this was one of the famous private compartments, and its name—besides, she was a de Charlus—produced a strange impression on Steven.
[1898-10-07 14:03:09] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I saw Charles speaking to the Jansenist historian, as if complaining in a low voice. I heard, "Sir, Steven probably thinks you're writing about Edward de Montmorency."
[1898-10-07 14:03:14] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I thought to myself that she could not possibly know that her gentle and amiable expression had been wrinkled, torn, and marred by this sullen muttering, by the physiological irritability caused by aging, and by the unnaturalness of imitating the coarse, peasant-like tone of old nobility.

text:
[1898-10-07 14:03:19] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I heard, "Steven is going to show you her portrait right away. This one is the original, the one at the Valleyview is a copy."
[1898-10-07 14:03:24] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw her set down the brush beside the flowers, stand up, and reveal the little apron around her waist. I knew she was wearing the apron to keep her clothes from getting paint on them.
[1898-10-07 14:03:34] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw that her wide-brimmed soft hat and heavy glasses already made her look like a country woman, and with that little apron tied around her, she looked even more rustic.
[1898-10-07 14:03:49] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw that her servants, the steward who served tea and pastries to the guests, and the servant who had been ordered to illuminate the portrait of Montmorency Edward (she was a nun-abbess of a renowned Eastern convent), were all dressed in splendid uniforms, in sharp contrast to Charles's shabby attire.
[1898-10-07 14:04:04] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw everyone standing up. "I find it interesting," she said, "that the great-aunts and aunties of the Stevenes were often the nuns who ran these councils, yet the daughters of French kings were not admitted. These councils were very difficult to get into."
[1898-10-07 14:04:09] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Richard was astonished and asked. "I heard 'not absorbed? The king's daughter? Why?'"
[1898-10-07 14:04:14] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I saw Richard even more surprised. "I heard, 'Because since the French royal family married non-royals, their territory shrank.'" "Married non-royals? The French royal family? What's going on?"
[1898-10-07 14:04:19] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Charles answer in an extremely natural tone, saying again. I heard, "It's the Medici family, of course. This portrait is very beautiful, isn't it? It's in excellent condition."
[1898-10-07 14:04:24] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw the lady with the Marie Antoinette hairstyle say. "I heard 'Steven, dear friend, do you remember? The day Steven brought Liszt to you, he said to you that this painting was a copy.'"
[1898-10-07 14:04:29] The drawing room of the Villeparisis Mansion | "I heard 'If it's about music, Steven would certainly respect Liszt's opinion, but not when it comes to painting! Besides, he's already old and senile. Steven doesn't remember having said that. But then, it wasn't you who brought him here. Before that, Steven had dined with Princess Szechenyi at least twenty times."
[1898-10-07 19:00:10] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Alexs, realizing this move had failed, shut his mouth and stood motionless. I saw her face, powdered with layer upon layer of perfume, as lifeless as a plaster mask. Her profile was dignified and luxurious, like a weathered goddess statue in a park, her short cloak concealing the moss-covered triangular pedestal.
[1898-10-07 19:00:15] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I heard, "Ah! Another beautiful portrait." I know that historians say.
[1898-10-07 19:00:25] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I saw the door open, and Edward entered.
[1898-10-07 19:00:30] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Charles say something, not even bothering to lift his head, he pulled out a hand from the pocket of his apron and handed it to Edward, who had just entered, then immediately turned his head back to the historian, ignoring her completely. I heard, "You're here, hello. This is the portrait of La Rochejouan, Edward..."
[1898-10-07 19:00:40] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw a young servant enter carrying a tray, on which was a business card. I saw that he looked very courageous, and his face was quite handsome (though, in order to be perfectly flawless and impregnable, he had shaped his face just right, with a slightly reddish nose and skin that was faintly glowing, as if it still bore the traces of being freshly carved with a knife).
[1898-10-07 19:00:45] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | "I heard, 'That's the gentleman who's come to visit Charles several times.' 'Did you tell him that Steven has a guest?' 'He heard the sound of someone speaking.'"
[1898-10-07 19:00:50] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | "I heard, 'Well, let him in. He was introduced to Steven by someone else, and he told Steven he really wanted to be received here. Steven never agreed. But he's come five times now. You can't just make people unhappy, can you?'" I knew that Charles said.
[1898-10-07 19:00:55] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I saw her say something to Steven, then point to the Jansenist historian. I heard, "Sir, and you too, sir, Steven is introducing his niece, Edward de Fairhaven."
[1898-10-07 19:01:00] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw the historian bow as deeply as Steven, his mouth just about to open, but Edward's expression instantly cooled him half to death. I thought that he believed that after making a bow, he would always receive some sign of friendliness, and his eyes would light up.
[1898-10-07 19:01:10] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Edward, with her independent upper body, bowing forward with an exaggerated gesture, then lifting her head so that her gaze seemed not to notice the two people standing in front of her.
[1898-10-07 19:01:15] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw her give a soft snort, then her nostrils flared. I thought this perfectly showed how her attention was utterly bored, and neither Steven nor the historian had left any impression on her.
[1898-10-07 19:01:25] The drawing room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw an unwelcome guest come in, and he kept heading toward Charles. I saw him with a childlike and earnest expression. It was Thomas!
[1898-10-07 19:01:30] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw him say it, emphasizing the words "ming gan." "I heard, 'Madame, you have granted Steven the honor of receiving him. Steven is deeply grateful. You have given an old man a most extraordinary and exquisite happiness. Steven assures you that the effect of this...'"
[1898-10-07 19:01:40] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw him catch sight of Steven and abruptly stopped speaking.
[1898-10-07 19:01:45] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I heard, "Steven is showing the gentleman the beautiful portrait of Edward de La Rocheferme, the wife of the author of the Maxims, which is a family heirloom."
[1898-10-07 19:01:50] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Edward greeting Alix, and she expressed her regret at not having been able to visit her this year, like everyone else. She also said. I heard, "Steven often hears from you through the madeleine."
[1898-10-07 19:01:55] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I heard, "She had lunch with Steven today." I know what Albertine said. I thought about how Charles would never be able to say that, and I felt a swell of pride.
[1898-10-07 19:02:00] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw that while they were chatting, Steven was talking to Richard. Afraid that Richard might be envious of Steven's life, he told him that he must be living a happier life than Steven. I knew that because Steven had heard that his father's attitude toward him had worsened. I thought it was merely a polite phrase, but people with strong self-esteem often easily believe that they have truly been fortunate, or they are very eager to convince others that they have had good luck.

text:
[1898-10-07 19:02:05] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I saw Richard cheerfully saying something to Steven. I heard, "Yes, Steven is living very happily. Steven has three inseparable friends; another Steven wouldn't be needed. Steven has a mistress to envy, and Steven is extremely happy. The father of the gods, Zeus, rarely grants such happiness to anyone."
[1898-10-07 19:02:10] The drawing room of the Villeparisis estate | I thought that Steven believed he was mainly trying to show off, to make people envious, but perhaps beneath his optimism there was also a desire to cultivate a unique style. It was obvious that he didn't want to give the usual, commonplace answer of "Ah, it's nothing," and so on.
[1898-10-07 19:02:30] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | I know that once, one afternoon, there was a ball at his house, and Steven had been unable to attend for some reason. When Steven asked him, "Was it fun?" he replied in a calm and indifferent manner, as if talking about someone else's affair: "Yes, it was very fun, there was no more successful ball. It was so enjoyable that one forgot to go home."
[1898-10-07 19:02:35] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | "I heard that you told Steven stories that interested him very much," Mr. Thomas said to Charles, "that day Steven thought your style was very similar to his own, concise and direct. If I were to use two contradictory words to descri be it, it would be 'motion with stillness, eternity in an instant.'"
[1898-10-07 19:02:40] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I heard, "Tonight, Steven really wanted to write down everything you said, but Steven will certainly remember it all in his mind. What you said, as Joubert would say (Steven thinks that's what he meant), is a valuable teacher and friend worth remembering."
[1898-10-07 19:02:45] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | "I heard, 'You've never read Jules's books? Oh! If you read them, he'd be so happy in his grave! Please allow Steven to send you his books from tonight on. Steven is proud to introduce you to his thoughts. He may not have your talent, but his writing is just as beautiful as yours."
[1898-10-07 19:02:50] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Steven about to go over and greet Thomas, but he always tried to stay as far away from Steven as possible. I realized clearly that he didn't want Steven to hear his endless, charming flattery about Charles.
[1898-10-07 19:02:55] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw her smiling and shrugging her shoulders as if she had heard a mocking remark, then she turned her head toward the historian. I heard, "This woman is the famous Marie de Rohan, that is, Edward de Sefler, whose first husband was Monsieur de Luyne."
[1898-10-07 19:03:00] The drawing room of the Villa Parisis | "I heard 'Dear, speaking of Madame de Fairhaven, it made Steven think of Yvonne. She came to Steven's yesterday. If Steven had known you didn't have guests last night, he would have sent for you. Madame Rastignac arrived suddenly and recited the lines of Queen Cyméa in front of the author. It was beautiful!"
[1898-10-07 19:03:05] The drawing room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I heard, but she replied, "Steven wasn't busy yesterday, but even if you asked Steven, Steven wouldn't go. Steven saw her perform when Madame Lestrade was lucky, but her golden age has passed. Besides, Steven doesn't like the lines of Queen Célimène." I thought, "How despicable!" Charles said to himself, "That day, she was whispering with Madame de Broussard and Madame de Charlus, surely about this."
[1898-10-07 19:03:10] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I heard that "Madame Lestrade had come here once, brought by Edward d'Astier. She recited a passage from Dante's Inferno. She did it beautifully, absolutely incomparable."
[1898-10-07 19:03:20] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw Alice withstand the blow with strength, remaining cold and indifferent as ever. I saw her with sharp, expressionless eyes, and her aquiline nose gave her an air of dignity and nobility.
[1898-10-07 19:03:25] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | I saw that one side of her face looked mottled, as if covered with scales. A sparse collection of strange growths, some green and others red, grew on her chin. I thought that perhaps by the next winter, she would be lying on the ground, unable to get up again.
[1898-10-07 19:03:30] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Charles stop Thomas mid-sentence with this remark. "I heard, 'Oh, sir, if you like painting, you might take a look at the portrait of Madame de Montmorency.'"
[1898-10-07 19:03:35] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Thomas going to look at the paintings, and Edward seized the opportunity to ask her aunt with a mocking and inquisitive look who the man was. Charles whispered: I heard, "It's Mr. Thomas, he has a sister, Madame de Cambremer, whose name you probably, like Steven, have never heard of."
[1898-10-07 19:03:40] The drawing room of the Villeparisis mansion | I saw Edward put her hand to her mouth and gasped. "I heard, 'How come I've never heard of her? Steven is familiar with her, or rather, Steven doesn't know her. However, Samuel somehow met her husband and, by some strange coincidence, called this fat woman to see Steven.'"
[1898-10-07 19:03:45] The Drawing Room of the Villeparisis Mansion | "I heard her say, 'What kind of visit is that! As soon as she saw Steven, she told him she had gone to London and then proceeded to list every painting in the British Museum as if she were an expert.' You see, Steven, after leaving your place, still has to go to this monster's house to leave a calling card. Don't think it's an easy task. She pretends to be dying, spends all day at home, and no matter whether you come at seven in the evening or nine in the morning, she'll just make you eat strawberry tarts. Yes, that's right, she's a monster."

[1898-10-14 18:05:32] Paris Street | "I heard 'Steven often thinks, sir, that Steven has a treasure of experiences, something like a precious document. [1898-10-14 18:05:37] Paris Street | I heard him say, "Steven is going to pass on to this young man all the experience he has accumulated over thirty years, perhaps only possessed by Steven himself, in just a few months. [1898-10-14 18:05:42] Location: Paris Street | I saw that when he used this expression, it was like a prayer, and he often pressed his hands together, though his fingers remained straight.
